This chapter explains the review, appeal, collection and reimbursement processes.

We accept most tax returns as they are filed by taxpayers. If we require information about your tax return or if we select your return for review, this does not mean you are dishonest. The review or investigation may or may not result in additional tax payments. We may close your case without making changes or you may receive a refund. The process of selecting a tax return for review usually begins in one of two ways. One way is to use computer programs to identify returns that may have incorrect amounts. These programs may be based on informative returns, such as Forms 1099 and W-2, on studies of past revisions or on certain issues identified by other special projects. Another way is to use information from tax compliance projects that indicate that a return may include incorrect amounts. These sources may include newspapers, public records and individuals. If we determine that the information is accurate and reliable, we may use it to select a return for review. Publication 556, Examination of Returns, Appeal Rights, and Claims for Refund, explains the rules and procedures we follow during the reviews. The sections below provide a summary of how we conduct audits.

If you disagree with the changes proposed by the examiner, you can appeal them to the IRS Independent Appeals Office. Most disagreements can be resolved without the time and expense of going to court. Your appeal rights are explained in detail in Publication 5, Your Appeal Rights and How to Prepare a Protest If You Disagree, and Publication 556. If you do not want to use the Independent Appeals Office or if you disagree with its determinations, you can appeal your case to the U.S. Tax Court, the U.S. Court of Federal Claims or the U.S. District Court that serves the area where you live. If you take your case to court, the IRS will have a duty to prove certain facts if you maintained adequate records showing your tax debt, co-operated with the IRS in most of the determinations in your case and met certain other conditions. If the court agrees with you in most of the determinations in your case and finds that our position was largely unjustified, you may be able to recover some portion of the administrative and litigation costs you incurred. You will not be entitled to recover these costs unless you have tried to resolve your case through administrative means, including following the appropriate procedures through the appeals process and providing us with the information necessary to resolve your case.
Your rights to appeal collections are explained in detail in Publication 1660, Rights to Appeal Collections.

Generally, you and your spouse are jointly and severally responsible for paying the full amount of any tax, interest, or fine due on your joint return. To request relief from any liability related to your spouse (or ex-spouse), you must file Form 8857, Application for Innocent Spouse Relief. In some cases, you may have to file Form 8857 within 2 years of the date the IRS first attempted to collect the tax from you. Do not file Form 8857 together with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 971, Innocent Spouse Relief, and Form 8857, or call the Innocent Spouse office toll-free at 855-851-2009.

Generally, the IRS will deal directly with you or your duly authorized representative. However, sometimes we contact other people if we need information that you have not been able to provide to us or to verify information we have received. If we contact other people, such as a neighbor, bank, employer or employees, we will usually need to tell them limited information, such as your name. The law prohibits us from disclosing more information than is necessary to obtain or verify the information we are looking for. Our need to contact other people may continue for as long as there is activity in your case. If we contact other people, you have the right to request a list of the people we have contacted. You can make your request by phone, in writing or in person during the interview.

You can file a refund claim if you believe you have paid too much tax. You generally have to file the claim within 3 years from the date you filed your original return or 2 years from the date you paid the tax, whichever is later. Publication 556 contains additional information about refunds. If you were entitled to a refund but did not file a return, then you will have to file a refund claim within a period of 2 years from the date you paid the tax in order to receive the refund. The law generally stipulates that interest is paid on the amount of your refund if you are not paid within a period of 45 days from the date you filed your return or claimed the refund.

This part explains if you have to file an income tax return and when to do so, and how to pay taxes.

You must file an income tax return for 2024 if you had $400 or more in net income from self-employment. If you had less than $400 in net income from self-employment, you still have to file an income tax return if you meet any of the other filing requirements listed in the Form 1040 Instructions. to

File your tax return using Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and attach a Schedule C. Enter the net gain or loss from Schedule C in Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Use Schedule C to calculate the net gain or loss of your business. If you operated more than one business as the sole owner of a business, you must attach a separate Schedule C for each business.

Electronic filing is easier than you think, and is available to most taxpayers who file electronically — including first-time taxpayers who were 16 years of age or older at the end of 2024. If you file electronically using tax filing software or the services of a tax professional, you will sign your return using the IRS Personal Identification Number (PIN) self-select method. If you are married filing jointly, you and your spouse will need to create a PIN for each of you and use them as your electronic signatures. To create a PIN, you need to know your adjusted gross income (AGI) from your original 2023 income tax return (not the amended return on Form 1040-X, Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return), or the AGI that appears on a notice of mathematical error received from the IRS. You will also need to provide your DOB. Make sure your DOB is correct and matches the information on your SSA records before using the e-file system. To verify, check your annual Social Security statement. With a self-selected PIN, there is nothing to sign or mail, not even your W-2 form(s). For more details on the PIN self-select method, visit IRS.gov.

If you are a taxpayer in the United States, you can file a state tax return electronically at the same time as your federal tax return. For more information, contact your state tax agency or a tax professional. ÷ IRS.gov/English.

You can have your refund check mailed to you, or you can have the refund deposited directly into your checking or savings account. With the IRS e-file system, your refund will be issued in half the time it takes with a paper tax return. Most refunds are issued in less than 21 days.

As with a paper tax return, you may not receive your full refund if you (or your spouse, if filing jointly) owe certain amounts overdue or due, such as federal taxes, state taxes, a student loan, or child support. You will be notified if the refund you claimed was used to offset your debts. You can file an injured spouse claim on Form 8379, Injured Spouse Allocation; or on Form 8857, Application for Innocent Spouse Relief, to recover part or all of a joint refund transferred to pay for your spouse’s separate liabilities.

The IRS cannot issue refunds until mid-February 2025 for returns claiming the earned income credit or additional child tax credit, which applies to the full refund, not just the portion related to these credits.

If your return shows you owe taxes, you must pay them by the due date of your return (without taking into account any extensions to file) to avoid late payment penalties and interest. April 15, 2025 is the due date to file your income tax return for the year 2024 if you use a calendar year. You have many options for making your payment, including scheduling an electronic withdrawal of funds from your checking or savings account or by debit or credit card. For more information about your payment options, visit IRS.gov/Payments.

You will be asked to complete Form 8879, Signature Authorization to File Return via IRS e-file, to authorize the provider to enter your self-selected PIN on your return. Depending on the provider and the specific services requested, you may be charged a fee. To find an authorized IRS e-file provider near you, go to IRS.gov/eFile and click on English.

All you need to file your tax return via the IRS e-file system is a computer with Internet access. If you use your personal computer, you can file your return via e-file from home anytime of the day or night. To complete the process, sign your return electronically using the self-selected PIN. No signature forms or W-2s are required.
If your AGI was $84,000 or less in 2024, you can use free computer tax software to prepare and file your tax return electronically.

Some businesses offer their employees, members, or customers the opportunity to file their returns free of charge through the e-file system, while others charge for this service. Ask your employer or financial institution if they offer the use of the IRS e-file system as a benefit to employees, members, or customers.

For the calendar year 2024, the due date for filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR is no later than April 15, 2025. If you use a tax year (which is explained in chapter 2), the due date for filing your tax return is the 15th day of the 4th month after the end of your tax year. If you file your return late, you may have to pay fines and interest. If you cannot file your tax return on time, use Form 4868, Request for Automatic Extension to File the U.S. Personal Income Tax Return, to request an automatic 6-month extension. For taxpayers filing per calendar year, this extends the filing deadline to October 15. However, filing an extension request does not extend the tax payment deadline, but only the tax return filing deadline.

The self-employment tax consists of Social Security and Medicare taxes mainly for people who work for themselves. It is similar to the Social Security and Medicare taxes that are withheld from the paychecks of most people who earn wages and salaries. If you earned income from work as a statutory employee, you do not pay self-employment taxes on that income. Social Security and Medicare taxes should already have been withheld from that income.

Social Security benefits are available to self-employed people in the same way as to people who earn wages or salaries. Your tax payments on self-employment contribute to your coverage under the Social Security system. Social Security coverage provides you with retirement benefits, disability benefits, survivor benefits, and hospital insurance (Medicare) benefits. Be sure to report all your self-employment income. If you do not report all your income, your Social Security benefits may be reduced when you retire.

You must be registered (insured) with Social Security before you can start receiving Social Security benefits.t You will be insured if you have accumulated the required number of credits (also called coverage quarters), explained below.t

In 2024, you received one credit, up to a maximum of four credits, for every $1,730 ($1,810 in 2025) of Social Security taxable income. Therefore, in 2024, if you had $6,920 in income (from self-employment and wages) that was subject to Social Security tax, you received four credits ($6,920 ÷ $1,730). For an explanation of the number of credits you need to have to be insured and the benefits available to you and your family under the Social Security program, consult your nearest SSA office. Making false statements to obtain or increase Social Security benefits may result in you being subject to penalties.
The self-employed tax rate on net income is 15.3% (12.4% Social Security tax plus 2.9% Medicare tax). The tax rate on net income is 15.3% (12.4% Social Security tax plus 2.9% Medicare tax).

Only the first $168,600 of your combined wages, tips, and net income in 2024 is subject to any combination of 12.4% of the Social Security portion of self-employment taxes, Social Security tax, or tier 1 pension tax for railroad employees. Your combined wages, tips, and net income in 2024 are subject to any combination of 2.9% of the Medicare portion of self-employment taxes, Social Security tax, or tier 1 pension tax for railroad employees. If your wages and tips are subject to Social Security tax or tier 1 pension tax for railroad employees, or both, and total at least $168,600, you do not pay the 12.4% of the Social Security portion of self-employment taxes on any of your net income. However, you must pay the 2.9% of the Medicare portion of self-employment taxes on all your net income. Deduct half of your self-employment taxes as an income adjustment on line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

For more information, see Publication 15, Tax Guide for Employers. That publication explains your tax responsibilities as an employer. Don t reduce your Social Security and Medicare tax deduction for the non-refundable and refundable portions of the qualified sick leave and family leave wage credits under the FFCRA and the ARP Act of 2021 claimed on a payroll tax return. Instead, report the credits as income. To help you determine if people working for you are employees, see Publication 15-A. That publication contains information to help you determine if an individual is an independent contractor or an employee. If you incorrectly classify an employee as an independent contractor, you may be liable to pay payroll taxes for that employee, in addition to a fine. an independent contractor is a person who is self-employed. You usually don t have to withhold or pay any taxes on what you pay an independent contractor.

The taxes on goods of use and consumption reported on Form 720, Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return, consist of several broad categories of taxes, including the following: Environmental taxes on the sale or use of ozone-depleting chemicals and imported products containing or manufactured with such chemicals; Communications and air transportation taxes; Fuel taxes; Initial retail sales taxes on heavy trucks, trailers and tractors; Manufacturer taxes on the sale or use of a variety of different items; Tax on indoor tanning services; and Tax on the sale of a vehicle.

There is a federal tax on the use of certain trucks, tractor trucks, and buses on public roads. The tax applies to vehicles that have a gross taxable weight of 55,000 pounds or more. Report the tax on Form 2290, Heavy Vehicle Use on Highways Tax Return. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 2290.

If you are required to file a quarterly return of goods of use and consumption taxes on Form 720, you may have to file your goods of use and consumption taxes before the return filing due date. If you make or receive payments in your business, you may have to report them to the IRS using information returns. The IRS compares the payments shown on the information returns with those shown on each person’s income tax return to see if the payments were included as income. You must give the payee or payer a copy of each information return that you are required to file. In addition to the forms described below, you may have to use other returns to report certain types of payments or transactions. For more details about information returns and when you have to file them, see the General Instructions for Certain Information Returns.
You will also use Form 1099-MISC to report your sales of $5,000 or more in consumer goods to a person who will resell them anywhere other than a permanent retail establishment.

You must also file Form 1099-NEC for each person from whom you have withheld any federal income tax (reported in box 4) under the additional withholding rules regardless of the amount of the payment.If you use Form 1099-NEC to report sales totalling $5,000 or more of consumer goods, then you must file Form 1099-NEC with the IRS by January 31.

You must file Form W-2 to report payments made to your employees, such as wages, tips, and other compensation; and income tax withholdings and Social Security and Medicare taxes. You can file Form W-2 online. For more information about Form W-2, see the General Instructions for Forms W-2 and W-3.

The law provides the following fines if you fail to file Form(s) 1099-MISC, Form(s) 1099-NEC or Form(s) W-2 or if you do not declare the information correctly. For more information, see the General Instructions for Certain Information Returns. For Failing to File Information Returns. This fine applies if you fail to file information returns by the due date, do not include all required information or declare incorrect information. For Failing to Provide the Correct Payment to Recipient Returns. This fine applies if you fail to provide the payment return for the recipient of a payment by the required date, do not include all required information or declare incorrect information.

These fines will not apply if you can prove that the failure was due to reasonable cause and not intentional negligence. In addition, there is no fine for failing to include all required information or for including incorrect information in a de minimis (minimum) number of returns if you correct the errors by August 1 of the year in which the returns are due. (A de minimis number of returns is the greatest of 10 or ½ (half) of 1% of the total number of returns you are required to file for the year.)

You must file Form 8300, Cash Payments Received in Excese of $10,000 in an Occupation or Business Report, if you receive more than $10,000 in cash in a single transaction, or in two or more related business transactions. Cash includes U.S. and foreign currency and foreign exchange. It also includes certain monetary instruments, such as cashier's and traveler's cheques, as well as money orders. Cash does not include checks drawn from an individual's personal account (personal checks). For more information, see Publication 1544, Cash Payments Received in Excese of $10,000 in an Occupation or Business Report.

There are civil and criminal fines, including up to 5 years in prison, for not filing Form 8300, filing (or having a false or fraudulent Form 8300 filed), or structuring a transaction to evade reporting requirements.

If you filed your first income tax return using the natural tax year and later open a business as a sole business owner, you must continue to use the natural tax year, unless you receive IRS approval to change it or are otherwise allowed to make the change without IRS approval. If you adopt the natural tax year, you must keep your books and records and report your income and expenses for the period from January 1 to December 31 of each year.

A tax year consists of a period of 12 consecutive months ending on the last day of any month except December. A 52- or 53-week tax year is a tax year that varies from 52 to 53 weeks but does not have to end on the last day of a month. If you adopt a tax year, you must keep your books and records, and report your income and expenses using the same tax year. For more information about tax years, including a 52- or 53-week tax year, see Publication 538.

You usually need to file Form 1128, Application To Adopt, Change, or Retain a Tax Year, to apply for IRS approval to change your tax year. See the Instructions for Form 1128 for exceptions. If you qualify for automatic approval, you do not have to pay an administrative fee. If you do not qualify for automatic approval, you have to apply for a decision. See the Instructions for Form 1128 for information on administrative fees if you apply for a decision.

A method of accounting is a set of rules that are used to determine when and how to report income and expenses. Your method of accounting includes not only the general accounting method that you use, but also the accounting classification that you use for any substantial items. You choose an accounting method for your business when you file your first income tax return that includes a Schedule C for the business. After that, if you want to change your method of accounting, you will usually need to get the approval of the IRS. See Change in the Method of Accounting, below.
You must use the same method of accounting to calculate your taxable income and keep your books, and you must use an accounting method that clearly shows your income.

To get approval, you must file Form 3115. You can get IRS approval to change your method of accounting under the automatic change procedures or advance consent procedures. You may have to pay a user fee. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 3115.

Certain taxpayers may assume that they have IRS approval to change their accounting methods. Approval is granted for the tax year for which the taxpayer requests the change (the year of change), if the taxpayer meets the provisions of the automatic change procedures. No user fee is required for an application filed under an automatic change procedure generally covered in the Revenue Procedure 2015-13 found on page 419 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2015-5, available at IRS.gov/IRB/2015-05_IRB#RP-2015-13 (or its successor). You usually need to use Form 3115 to request an automatic change. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 3115.

You can account for business and personal items using different accounting methods.За пример, you can calculate your business income using an accrual method, even if you use the cash method to calculate your personal items.

If you have two or more separate and distinct businesses, you may use different accounting methods for each, as long as the method clearly reflects the income of each business.т They are considered separate and distinct only if you keep completely separate books and records for each business.т

Most individuals and many sole proprietors of a business who do not have inventories use the cash-based method because they find it easier to keep cash-based records. However, if you need to keep an inventory to account for your income, you will usually have to use the accrual method for sales and purchases, unless you are a small business taxpayer (defined later in this chapter). For more information, see Inventories, later.

You receive income implicitly when an amount is credited to your account or made available to you without restriction. You do not need to be in possession of the income. If you authorize someone else to be your agent and receive income on your behalf, you are deemed to have received the income when your agent receives it.

You cannot withhold checks or defer the taking of possession of similar property from one tax year to another to avoid paying income tax. You must report income in the year you receive the property or when it is made available to you without restrictions. 1.
A receipt of a valid check at the end of the tax year is implicitly a receipt of income for that year, even if you can't cash or deposit the check until the following year.

If you have a debt that is paid off by another person or if your creditors write off your debt, you may have to report all or part of that debt relief as income. If you receive income in this way, you receive the income implicitly when the debt is written off or settled. For more information, see Cancelled Debt under Types of Income in chapter 5.

If you include an amount in your income and in a subsequent year you have to refund it in whole or in part, you can usually deduct the refund in the year you make it. If you refund an amount greater than $3,000, a special rule applies. For details of the special rule, see Refunds in chapter 8 of Publication 17.

Under the cash-based method, you generally deduct expenses in the tax year in which you actually pay them, including business expenses for which you dispute the liability. However, you may not be able to deduct an expense that was paid in advance or you may have to capitalize certain costs, as explained below under the Uniform Capitalization Rules.

Under an accrual (accounting) method, you usually report your income in the year you accrue it and deduct or capitalize expenses in the year you incur them.The purpose of an accrual (accounting) method is to make income and expenses match in the correct year.

Under an accrual method of accounting, you generally include an amount in your gross income for the tax year in which all the conditions establishing your entitlement to receive the income have occurred, and you can determine the amount with reasonable accuracy. For a taxpayer with an applicable financial statement or other financial statement as specified by the Secretary, the proof of all events for a gross income item is deemed to be met at the latest when it is taken into account in an applicable financial statement or other similar financial statement. 1.
The following are special rules that apply to advance payments, estimated revenue, and changes to the payment for services program.

If you include a reasonable estimated amount in your gross income and then determine that the exact amount is different, take the difference into account in the tax year that you determine the difference.

If you perform services at a basic rate specified in a contract, you must accrue income based on the basic rate, even if you agree to receive payments at a lower rate until you complete the services and then receive the difference.

You usually report an advance payment as income in the year in which you receive the payment. However, if you receive an advance payment, you can choose to defer the inclusion of the advance payment in your income until the next tax year. You cannot defer the inclusion of the payment beyond that tax year. For more information, see Publication 538 and section 451 of the Internal Revenue Code.

If your expense relates to goods or services provided to you, or your use of goods, economic performance occurs when you are provided with the goods or services, or as you use the goods. If your expense relates to goods or services you provide to others, economic performance occurs as you provide the goods or services. An exception allows certain recurring items to be treated as if they were incurred during a tax year, even if economic performance has not occurred. For more information on economic performance, see Economic Performance under Accrual Method in Publication 538.

When the production, purchase, or sale of goods is an activity that generates income for your business, you generally have to account for inventories at the beginning and end of your tax year, unless you are a small business taxpayer. If you have to account for inventories, you usually have to use the accrual method of accounting for your purchases and sales. For more information, see Inventories, below.

If you produce, buy, or sell goods in your business, you usually have to maintain an inventory and use the accrual method of accounting for the purchases and sales of goods.

If you are a small business taxpayer, you may choose not to maintain an inventory, but you still have to use an accounting method for the inventory that clearly reflects revenue. If you choose not to maintain an inventory, it will not be considered as not clearly reflecting revenue if your accounting method for the inventory treats the inventory as non-incidental materials or supplies, or is consistent with your financial accounting treatment of inventories. However, if you choose to maintain an inventory, you generally have to use an accrual accounting method and value the inventory each year to determine the cost of goods sold under Part III of Schedule C.

You qualify as a small business taxpayer if (a) you have average annual gross revenues of $30 million or less over the previous 3 tax years and (b) you are not a tax haven (as defined in section 448(d)(3)). If your business has not existed for the entire 3-tax year period used to calculate your average gross revenues, base your average on the period that actually existed, and if your business has a predecessor entity, include the predecessor entity's gross revenues from the 3-tax year period when calculating your average gross revenues. If your business (or predecessor entity) had short tax years for any of the years in the 3-tax year period, annualize your business's gross revenues for the short tax years that are part of the 3-tax year period. See Publication 538 for more information.
If you want to change your method of accounting for inventory, you must file Form 3115, Application for Change in Accounting Method (see Change in Accounting Method below).t

If you are required to account for inventories, include the following items when accounting for inventory: Commodity or commercial stocks Raw materials Production in process Finished products Supplies that are physically made part of an item for sale.

You must value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine your cost of goods sold (Line 42 of Schedule C). To determine the value of your inventory, you need a method for identifying the items in your inventory, as well as a method for valuing those items. The rules for valuing your inventory cannot be the same for all types of business. The method you use to value your inventory must be in accordance with the generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) for similar businesses and must clearly reflect revenue. Your inventory management practices must be consistent from year to year.

This chapter explains if you do have a disposal, how to calculate the gain or loss, and where to report the gain or loss.

Certain property exchanges are not taxable. That means that no gains from the exchange are recognized and you cannot deduct any losses. Your gain or loss is not recognized until you sell or otherwise dispose of the property you receive.

A like-kind exchange is the exchange of one type of property for another of the same type. It is the most common type of non-taxable exchange. To constitute a like-kind exchange, both the property transferred and the property received must be both (a) real property and (b) commercial or investment property. Report like-kind exchanges on Form 8824, Like-Kind Exchanges. For more information about like-kind exchanges, see Chapter 1 of Publication 544.

A sale on instalments is a sale of property in which you receive at least one payment after the tax year in which the sale was made. If you provide financing to the buyer of your property, rather than the buyer getting a loan or mortgage from a third party, you are likely to have made a sale on instalments. For more information about sales on instalments, see Publication 537.

Generally, the sale of a business is not the sale of a single asset. Instead, all of the business's assets are sold. Usually, when this happens, each asset is treated as if it were sold separately for purposes of determining how to treat the gain or loss. Both the buyer and the seller involved in the sale of the business must report to the IRS the allocation of the sale price among the business's assets. Use Form 8594, Asset Acquisition Statement Under Section 1060, to provide this information. Both the buyer and the seller must attach Form 8594 to their respective federal income tax returns for the year in which the sale occurred. For more information on selling a business, see Publication 544.

Fair market value (FMV) is the price that the assets would have had if ownership had changed between a buyer and a seller, without either being forced to buy or sell and both having reasonable knowledge of all relevant facts.

Your gain or loss from the disposal of property generally constitutes a recognized gain or loss for tax purposes. Recognized gains must be included in gross income. Recognized losses are deductible from gross income. However, a gain or loss from certain types of property exchanges is not recognized. See Non-taxable Exchanges, above. In addition, you cannot deduct a loss from the disposal of property held for personal use.

You must classify your gains and losses as ordinary or capital gains or losses. You must do so in order to calculate your net capital gain or loss. You will generally have a capital gain or loss if you dispose of capital property. Most of the property you own and use for personal or investment purposes is capital property. Certain property you use in your business is not capital property. A gain or loss on the disposal of that property is an ordinary gain or loss. However, if you owned the property for more than 1 year, you may be able to treat the gain or loss as a capital gain or loss. These gains or losses are referred to as gains and losses under section 1231. For more information on ordinary and capital gains and losses, see chapters 2 and 3 of Publication 544.

If you have a capital gain or loss, you have to determine whether it is a long-term or short-term gain or loss. Whether the gain or loss is long-term or short-term depends on how long you owned the property before you disposed of it. The period of time you owned a property before you disposed of it is called the period of tenure.

An example of a service that is not normally provided for a guest's convenience is housekeeping. However, providing heating and lighting, cleaning stairs and lobbies, and collecting garbage are services that are normally provided for the convenience of guests.

Advance payments received for a lease that does not impose any restrictions on its use or enjoyment are income in the year you receive them, regardless of the accounting method or accounting period you use.
A bonus you receive from a tenant for granting a lease is an addition to the rent and should be included in your gross income for the year you received it.
Report payments you receive from your tenant for cancelling a lease on your gross income for the year in which you received them.

If your tenant makes payments to another person under an agreement to pay his or her debts or obligations, include those payments in your gross income when the tenant makes the payments.l A common example of this type of income is the tenant’s payment of property taxes on leased real property.l

Payments you receive to settle a tenant’s obligation to restore leased property to its original condition constitute income for the amount by which the payments exceed the adjusted basis of the improvements to leased real estate that were destroyed, damaged, removed or disconnected by the tenant.

If you operate a business of renting movable property (equipment, vehicles, formal clothing, etc.), include the amount of rent you receive in your gross income on Schedule C. Advance-paid rent and other payments described under Real Property Rentals above may also be received for renting movable property. If you receive any of those payments, include them in your gross income as explained in that section.

The following discussion explains how to treat other types of business income that you may receive.

Restricted property is property with certain restrictions that affect its value. If you receive restricted stock or other restricted property in exchange for services, the fair market value of the property that exceeds its cost is included in your income on Schedule C when the restriction is removed. However, you can choose to pay taxes in the year you receive the property. For more information about including restricted property in your income, see Publication 525, Taxable and Nontaxable Income.
This rule does not apply to depreciation, which is recovered under the rules explained below.
In the following situations, you must recover the depreciation deduction, which means that you will include in your income some or all of the depreciation you deducted in previous years.

If the business use of listed property (explained in chapter 8 under Depreciation) decreases to 50% or less during a tax year after the tax year in which you put the property into use, you may have to recover some of the depreciation deduction by including some of the depreciation you deducted in previous years in income on Schedule C. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to calculate the amount to include on Schedule C. For more information, see What Is the Business-Use Requirement? in chapter 5 of Publication 946. That chapter explains how to determine if the property is used for more than 50% of your business.

If you take a section 179 deduction (explained in chapter 8 under Depreciation) for an asset, and before the end of the recovery period for the asset the percentage of business use is reduced to 50% or less, you must recover part of the section 179 deduction by including part of the deduction you took in income on Schedule C. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to calculate the amount to include on Schedule C. See chapter 2 of Publication 946 to find out when the deduction is recovered.

If you sell or trade depreciable property and make a gain, you may have to treat all or part of the gain due to depreciation as ordinary income. Income due to depreciation recovery is calculated in Part III of Form 4797. For more information, see Chapter 4 of Publication 544.

Do not report on Schedule C a gain or loss on the disposal of property other than business inventory or property held primarily for sale to customers. Instead, you must report these gains and losses on separate forms. 10 For more information, see Chapter 3.

Report bills of exchange and other evidence of debt that were issued to you in a sale or exchange of property that is commercial stock or that is held primarily for sale to customers in Schedule C. You usually report them at their principal amount stipulated (less any interest not stipulated) or issue price (for OID debt instruments) when you receive them.

If you reduce or suspend your business activities, use Schedule C to report any payments you receive for your business's loss of income from insurance or other sources. Report it on Schedule C even if your business is inactive when you receive the payment. 10.

You must include in your gross income the compensation you receive during the tax year as a result of any of the following damages related to your business: Patent infringement. breach of contract or fiduciary duty. antitrust damages.

If you are entitled to a deduction from your income if it compensates you for actual economic damage, your deduction is the lesser of the following: The amount you receive or accrue for damages during the tax year less the amount you pay or incur during the tax year to recover that amount. your loss for damages that you have not yet deducted.

If you receive clandestine commissions, include them in your income on Schedule C. However, do not include them if you properly treat them as a reduction of a related expense item, a capital expenditure, or the cost of goods sold.

If you recover a bad debt or any other item deducted in a previous year, include the recovery in income on Schedule C. However, if all or part of the deduction in previous years did not reduce your taxes, you can exclude the part that did not reduce your taxes. If you exclude part of the recovery from income, you must include with your return a calculation showing how you calculated the exclusion.
In some cases, the property or money you receive is not income.
Increases in the value of your property are not income until you accrue the increases through sale or other taxable disposition.

If a tenant erects buildings or makes improvements to your property, the increase in the value of the property due to the improvements does not constitute income for you; however, if the facts indicate that the improvements constitute the payment of rent to you, then the increase in value would constitute income.
Money borrowed through a bona fide loan is not income.
State and local sales taxes levied on consumers, which you had to collect and pay to the state or local government, are not income.

Consignments of goods for others to sell for you do not constitute sales. The title to the goods remains with you, the consignor, even after the consignee possesses the goods. Therefore, if you ship goods on consignment, you have no profit or loss until the consignee sells the goods. The goods you have sent on consignment are included in your inventory until they are sold. Don’t include in your inventory the goods you receive on consignment. Include your profit or commission on the goods consigned to you in your income when you sell the goods or when you receive your profit or commission, depending on the accounting method you use.

If you enter into a lease after August 5, 1997, you can exclude from your income the construction grant you receive (in cash or as a rent reduction) from your landlord if you receive it under both of the following conditions: Under a short-term lease of a commercial premise.t For the purpose of building or improving long-term real estate that qualifies for use in your business in that commercial space (store).t
You can exclude construction grants to the extent that they do not exceed the amount you spent on the construction or improvements.

A short-term lease is a lease (or other occupancy or use agreement) of a commercial space for 15 years or less. The following rules apply when determining whether the lease is for 15 years or less: Consider renewal options when calculating whether the lease is for 15 years or less. However, do not consider any renewal options at fair market value determined at the time of renewal. Two or more successive leases that are part of the same transaction (or a series of related transactions) for the same or substantially similar commercial space are treated as a single lease.
A commercial space is a property that you rent, occupy, or otherwise use as a tenant in your business of selling tangible movable property or services to the general public.
A qualifying long-term real estate is a non-residential real estate that is part of, or otherwise present in, your commercial space and that returns to the landlord when the lease endst.

In general, if you trade real estate used for business or for investment purposes only for other real estate used for business or for investment purposes of a similar type, no gain or loss is recognized. This means that the gain is not subject to tax and the loss is not deductible. For more information, see Form 8824.

You are a securities or commodity trader if you engage in the business of buying and selling securities or commodities on your own account. As a securities or commodity trader (even if you elected under section 475(f) of the adjusted market value as a securities or commodity trader), your gain or loss on the disposal of securities or commodities is not reported on Schedule C. Termination payments you receive as a self-employed former insurance agent from an insurance company because of services you provided to that company are not reported on Schedule C if all of the following conditions are met: You received payments after your agreement to provide services to the company ended. Public officials generally do not declare what they earn for serving in public office on Schedule C. Accounting for your income for income tax purposes sometimes differs from accounting for financial purposes. This section discusses some of the most common differences that can affect business transactions. Calcule your business income on a tax year basis and according to your regular accounting method (see Chapter 2). If selling products is a revenue-generating activity in your business, you usually have to use inventory to clearly show your income. Real estate agents are not allowed to use inventory. You are subject to tax on all income you earn, and you cannot avoid tax by having your income paid to a third party.

If you receive an insurance payment or other refund for a casualty or theft loss, you must subtract it from the loss when you calculate your deduction. You cannot deduct the reimbursed portion of a casualty or theft loss. For more information about casualty or theft losses, see Publication 547.

If you produce or purchase goods for sale, you can deduct the cost of goods sold from your gross income on Schedule C. However, to determine these costs, you must value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year. This chapter applies to you if you are a manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer, or if you conduct any business that produces, buys, or sells goods for income. This chapter does not apply to a personal service business, such as the business of a doctor, lawyer, carpenter, or painter. However, if you work in a personal service business and also sell or charge for materials and supplies that are normally used in your business, this chapter applies to you. There are exceptions for small business taxpayers that could change how you calculate the cost of goods sold for your business. For more information, see Chapter 2.

If you are a merchant, the opening inventory is the cost of the goods in stock (available) at the beginning of the year that you will sell to customers. If you are a manufacturer or producer, it includes the total cost of raw materials, production in process, finished goods, and materials and supplies used in the manufacture of the goods (see Inventories in Chapter 2). the opening inventory will generally be identical to the previous year's closing inventory. you have to explain any differences in an appendix to your return.

If you donate inventory (goods you sell in the course of your business), the amount you can claim as a donation deduction is the lesser of the fair market value on the day you donated it or its basis. The basis of the donated inventory is any cost incurred for the inventory in a previous year that you would otherwise include in your initial inventory for the year of the donation. You must remove the amount of your donation deduction from your initial inventory. It is not part of the cost of goods sold. If the cost of the donated inventory is not included in your initial inventory, the inventory basis is zero and you cannot claim a charitable donation deduction. Treat the cost of the inventory the way you would normally treat it under your method of accounting. For example, include the purchase price of the inventory purchased and donated in the same year in the cost of goods sold that year. A special rule applies to certain grocery inventory donations. See Publication 526, Charitable Contributions.

If you are a merchant, use the cost of all the merchandise you purchased for sale; if you are a manufacturer or producer, this includes the cost of all raw materials or parts purchased to make a finished product.

The differences between the nominal prices of items and the actual prices you pay for them are called commercial discounts. You must use the prices you pay (not the nominal prices) when calculating your purchase costs. Don't show the discount amount separately as a gross income item. A car dealer must record the cost of a car in inventory reduced by any manufacturer's discount that constitutes a commercial discount.

Cash discounts are amounts that your suppliers allow you to deduct from your purchase invoices for timely payment. There are two accounting methods for cash discounts. You can either credit them to a separate discount account or deduct them from the total purchases for the year. Regardless of the method you use, you must be consistent. If you want to change your method of calculating inventory costs, you must file Form 3115. For more information, see Change in Accounting Method in Chapter 2. If you credit cash discounts to a separate account, you must include this credit balance in your business income at the end of the tax year. If you use this method, do not reduce your cost of goods sold by the amount of cash discounts.

If you withdraw goods for your personal or family use, you must exclude this cost from the total amount of goods purchased for sale. Do so by crediting the purchase or sales account with the cost of the goods you withdraw for personal use. You must also charge the amount to your advance account. An advance account is a separate account that you must keep to account for the business income you withdraw to pay for personal and family expenses. As noted above, you also use it to account for withdrawals of goods for personal or family use. This account is also known as a withdrawal account or personal account.

Labour costs are generally an element of the cost of goods sold only in manufacturing or mining businesses. Small traders (wholesalers, retailers, etc.) usually do not have labour costs that can be properly charged to the cost of goods sold. In a manufacturing business, labour costs that can be properly allocated to the cost of goods sold include the direct and indirect labour used to convert raw materials into finished products that can be sold.

Direct labour costs are the wages you pay to employees who work all their time directly on the manufacture of products, and include a portion of the wages you pay to employees who work directly on the products part-time, if you can determine that portion of the wages.

Indirect labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who perform general factory functions that have no immediate or direct connection to the manufacture of the product for sale, but are a necessary part of the manufacturing process.

Other labour costs that cannot be properly charged to the cost of goods sold may be deducted as sales or administrative expenses.ο Generally, the only types of labour costs that can be properly charged to your cost of goods sold are direct or indirect labour costs, as well as certain other types of costs that are treated as overheads properly charged to the manufacturing process, as explained below under Line 39 – Other Costs.ο

The costs of delivery freight, express delivery and transportation of raw materials delivery, supplies you use in production and the merchandise you buy for sale are all part of the cost of merchandise sold.

Overhead expenses include expenses such as rent, heating, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor, and supervision. overhead expenses that you incur as direct and necessary expenses of the manufacturing operation are included in your cost of goods sold. overhead expenses are expenses that are not included in your cost of goods sold.
The total of lines 35 to 39 equals the cost of goods available for sale during the year.

Subtract the value of your closing inventory (including, as applicable, the allocable parts of the cost of raw materials and supplies, direct labor, and overhead expenses) from line 40. When you subtract your closing inventory (the inventory at the end of the year) from the cost of goods available for sale, the remainder is your cost of goods sold during the tax year.

Calculate your gross profits by first calculating your net income. Calculate your net income on Schedule C (line 3) by subtracting any returns and discounts (line 2) from your gross income (line 1). Returns and discounts include cash or credit refunds you make to customers, sales discounts, and other discounts from the actual purchase price. Then subtract the cost of goods sold (line 4) from your net income (line 3). The result is your gross profits from the business.

You do not have to calculate the cost of goods sold if the sale of goods is not a factor generating income for your business. Your gross profits are equal to your net income (gross income minus any refunds, rebates, or other discounts). Most professions and businesses that sell services rather than products can calculate their gross profits directly from net income in this way.

At the end of each business day, make sure your records match your actual cash and credit entries for the day. You may find it helpful to use cash registers to keep track of entries. You will also need to use a proper billing system and maintain a separate bank account for your business.

If you collect state and local sales taxes from the buyer that are imposed on you as a seller of goods or services, you must include the amount collected in gross receipts. If you are required to collect state and local taxes that are imposed on the buyer and to remit them to the state or local government, you will usually not include these amounts in revenue.

If you take items from inventory for your personal use (for yourself, for your family, for personal gifts, etc.), make sure to remove them from the cost of goods sold. For details on adjusting the cost of goods sold, see Retired Goods in Chapter 6.

Make sure you verify that your inventory procedures are adequate. These procedures must ensure that all items have been included in the inventory and that correct pricing techniques have been used. Use inventory forms and calculator tapes as the only evidence of your inventory. Inventory forms are available at office supplies stores. These forms have columns to record the description, quantity, unit price, and value of each inventory item. Each page has space to record who did the physical count, who priced the items, who made extensions, and who verified the calculations. These forms will help you corroborate that the total inventory is accurate. They will also provide a permanent record to support its validity. Inventories are explained in Chapter 2.

If you operate a retail or wholesale business, you can check the accuracy of your gross profit figure. First, divide your gross profits by your net intake. The resulting percentage measures the average difference between the cost of goods sold and the sale price of the goods. Then, compare that percentage with your profit margin policy. A small or non-existent difference between these two percentages shows that your gross profits figure is accurate. A large difference between these two percentages may show that you did not calculate sales, purchases, inventory or other cost items accurately. You will need to determine the reason for the difference.

You operate a retail business. On average, you add a profit margin to the merchandise so that you accrue 331/3% in gross profit on your sales. The net income (gross income minus returns and discounts) shown on your income statement is $300,000. Your cost of merchandise sold is $200,000. This results in a gross profit of $100,000 ($300,000 − $200,000). To check the accuracy of this year’s results, you divide the gross income ($100,000) by the net income ($300,000). The resulting 331/3% percentage confirms your 331/3% profit margin percentage.

If your business has income from a source other than regular business operations, enter the income on Schedule C, line 6, and add it to your gross profits. This is your gross business income. Examples include income from a checking account that accrues interest, income from the sale of waste (scrap), income from certain fuel tax credits and refunds, and amounts recovered from bad debt.

You can deduct the costs of operating your business. These costs are known as business expenses. They are costs that you do not have to capitalize or include in the cost of goods sold, but you can deduct in the current year. To be deductible, a business expense must be both ordinary and necessary. An ordinary expense is one that is common and accepted in the scope of your business. A necessary expense is one that is useful and appropriate for your business. An expense does not have to be essential to be considered necessary. For more information on the general rules for deducting business expenses, see section 162 and its regulations. If you have an expense that is partly business and partly personal, separate the personal part from the business part. The personal part is not deductible.

SEP, SIMPLE and qualified plans provide you and your employees with a way to save for retirement with tax benefits. You can deduct the contributions you make to the plan on behalf of your employees on line 19 of Schedule C. If you are a sole business owner, you can deduct the contributions you make to the plan for yourself on line 16 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). You can also deduct trustee fees if they are not covered by your contributions to the plan. Income generated on contributions generally remains tax-free until you or your employees receive distributions from the plan. You may also be able to claim a tax credit if you start a new qualified defined benefit plan or a qualified defined contribution plan (including a 401(k) plan), a SIMPLE plan or a SEP plan. For more information about this credit and credits for self-enrollment and military spouse participation, see Form 8881 and its separate instructions. Under certain plans, employees can have you contribute limited amounts of their pay before tax to the plan. These amounts (and income generated on them) generally remain tax-free until your employees receive distributions from the plan. For more information about small business retirement plans, see Publication 560. Publication 590-A, Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs), explains other ways to save for retirement with tax benefits.

Rent is any amount you pay for the use of property that you do not own. You can usually deduct rent as a business expense only if the rent is for property that you use in your business. If you have or will have capital invested in the property or receive title to the property, you cannot deduct rent for that property.

You cannot take a deduction for unreasonable rents. Normally, the question of reasonability arises only if you and the landlord are related. Rent paid to a related person is reasonable if it is the same amount that you would pay to a stranger for the use of the same property. Rent is not unreasonable simply because it is calculated as a percentage of gross income. Related persons include members of your immediate family, including siblings (whether of the same parents or half-siblings), your spouse, your ancestors and your lineage descendants. For a list of other related persons, see section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code.

Rent paid in the course of your business is generally deductible in the year in which it is paid or accrues. If you pay the rent in advance, you can deduct only the amount corresponding to your use of the rented property during the tax year. You can deduct the remainder of your payment only for the period to which it corresponds.

On Schedule C, you can deduct state taxes on gross income (as opposed to net income) directly attributable to your business. If you detail your deductions, you can deduct other state and local income taxes on Schedule A (Form 1040).

You can deduct the Federal Social Security, Medicare, and Unemployment (FUTA) taxes you paid as an employer from your own funds. Taxes on payroll are briefly explained in Chapter 1. You can deduct half of your self-employment taxes on line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).Taxes on self-employment are explained in chapter 1 and chapter 10.

On Schedule C, you can deduct any taxes levied by a state or local government on movable property used in your business. You can also deduct registration fees for the right to use the property within a state or local area. 10.

On Schedule C, you can deduct any real estate taxes you pay on your business property. Deductible real estate taxes are all state, local, or foreign real estate taxes that are levied for the general welfare of the public. The tax authority must levy these taxes uniformly at a similar rate on all properties under its jurisdiction and the revenue must be for community or general government purposes.

Taxes on gasoline, diesel, and other motor fuels you use in your business are usually included as part of the cost of fuels. Do not deduct those taxes as a separate item. You may be entitled to a credit or rebate for federal goods of use taxes you pay on fuels used for certain purposes. For more information, see Publication 510.

To deduct expenses related to the part of your home (residence) used for business, you must meet specific requirements. However, your deduction may be limited. To qualify for expenses for business use of your home, you must meet the following requirements: 1. Your use of the business part of your home must be: 1. Exclusive (but see Exclusive Use Exceptions below), 2. Regular, and 3. For your business. 2. The business part of your home must be one of the following: 1. Your main place of business (defined below), 2. A place to meet or deal with your patients or customers in the normal course of your business, or 3. A separate structure (not attached to your home) that you use in connection with your business.

To qualify under the exclusive use requirement, you must use a specific area of your home only for your occupation or business. The area used for business may be a room or other separate and identifiable space. The space does not have to be marked by a permanent partition wall. You do not meet the conditions of the exclusive use requirement if you use the area in question for both business and personal purposes.

To qualify under the regular use requirement, you must use a specific area of your home continuously for business. You do not meet the requirement if your use of the area for business is only occasional or incidental, even if you do not use the area for any other purpose.

If, after taking into account your places of business, your home cannot be identified as your main place of business, you cannot deduct the expenses of an office at home. However, for other ways to qualify for the deduction of an office at home, see Publication 587. 2012-13 Tax Returns: Tax Returns for 2012-13

Do not include your half-self-employment tax deduction in item (2) above. Use Form 8829, Expenses for Business Use of Your Home, to calculate your deduction. If you are a self-employed person, you may be required to file a separate tax return for your self-employment tax deduction.

The IRS provides a simplified method to determine your expenses for the use of your home for business purposes. The simplified method is an alternative to calculating and justifying actual expenses. In most cases, you will calculate your deduction by multiplying $5 by the area of your home used for qualifying business use. The area you use to calculate your deduction is limited to 300 square feet. For more information, see the Instructions for Appendix C.

10. You generally have to capitalize the costs of acquiring or producing tangible real or movable property used in your occupation or business, such as buildings, equipment, or furniture. However, if you choose to use the de minimis safe harbor for tangible property, you may deduct de minimis amounts paid to acquire or produce certain tangible property if these amounts are deducted by you for financial accounting purposes or in maintaining your books and records. If you have an applicable financial statement, you may use this safe harbor to deduct amounts paid for tangible property up to $5,000 per item or invoice. If you do not have an applicable financial statement, you may use the de minimis safe harbor to deduct amounts paid for tangible property up to $2,500 per item or invoice.
For details on how to make this choice and the requirements for using the de minimis safe harbor for tangible property, see the Tangible Property Regulations.

If you use your car or truck for business, you may be able to deduct the costs of operating and maintaining your vehicle, and you may be able to deduct other local transportation costs and travel away from home that requires overnight stays for business purposes.

Local transportation expenses do not include expenses you incur during trips away from home that require overnight stays outside of your home. These expenses are deductible as travel expenses and are explained below under Travel and Meals. However, if you use your car during trips away from home that require overnight stays outside of your home, use the rules in this section to calculate your deduction for car expenses. Your tax domicile is usually your principal place of business, regardless of where you maintain your family domicile. It covers the entire city or general area in which your business or work is located.
Your workplace can be your home if you have an office at your home that qualifies as a principal place of business. For more information, see Commercial Use of Your Home below. § 10.

You may be able to use the standard mileage rate to calculate the deductible costs of operating your car, van, pickup truck, or delivery truck for business purposes. The standard mileage rate for business travel for 2024 is 67 cents per mile. If you choose to use the standard mileage rate for a year, you cannot deduct your actual car expenses in that year except for parking and toll charges that are related to your business.

You cannot use the standard mileage rate if: 1. You operate five or more cars at a time; 2. You claimed a depreciation deduction for the car using a method other than the uniform (constant) depreciation method, for example, ACRS (Accelerated Cost Recovery System) or MACRS (Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System); 3. You claimed a deduction on the car under section 179; 4. You claimed the special depreciation allowance on the car; 5. You claimed the actual expenses of a leased car; or 6. You are a rural postman who has received a qualifying rebate.

In addition to using the standard mileage rate, you can deduct all parking and toll charges that are related to your business (parking charges you pay for parking your car at your workplace are non-deductible commute expenses).

If you acquire goods for use in your business that are expected to last more than 1 year, you usually cannot deduct the entire cost as a business expense in the year you acquire them. You must spread the cost over more than 1 tax year and deduct part of the cost each year on Schedule C. This method of deducting the cost of business goods is called depreciation. The explanation given here is brief. More information about depreciation is in Publication 946.

You can depreciate property if it meets all of the following requirements: It must be property that you own. It must be used in business or held to produce income. You can never depreciate inventory (explained in chapter 2) because you do not hold it for use in your business. It must have a useful life that extends substantially beyond the year in which it is put into service. It must have a determined useful life, which means it must be something that wears out, deteriorates, wears out, becomes obsolete or loses its value by natural causes. You can never depreciate the cost of land because land does not wear out, become obsolete or wear out. It cannot be exempt property. This includes property put into use and disposed of in the same year.

You usually do not depreciate the costs of repairs or maintenance if they do not improve your property. Instead, you deduct these amounts on Schedule C, line 21. Improvements are amounts paid for improvements to your property, restorations of your property, or work that adapts your property to a new or different use.

You can make an election to treat certain repairs or replacements in your occupation or business as depreciable improvements if you treat these amounts as capital expenditures in your books and records used regularly to calculate your income and expenses.

You can elect to deduct a limited amount of the cost of certain depreciable property in the year you put the property into use. This deduction is known as the section 179 deduction. The maximum amount you can elect to deduct in 2024 is usually $1,220,000 (higher limits apply to certain property). This limit is generally reduced by the amount by which the cost of the property put into use during the tax year exceeds $3,050,000. The total amount of depreciation (including the section 179 deduction) you can take for a passenger car you use in your business that was first put into use in 2024 is $12,400 ($20,400 if you take the special depreciation allowance for qualifying passenger cars put into use in 2024). Special rules apply to trucks and vans. For more information, see Publication 946. This explains which property qualifies for the deduction, what limits apply to the deduction, and when and how to recover the deduction. Your section 179 election for the cost of any sports utility vehicle (SUV) and certain other vehicles is limited to $30,500. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 4562 or Publication 946.

Use Form 4562, Depreciation and Amortization, if you claim any of the following: Depreciation of property put into use during the current tax year. A deduction under section 179. Depreciation of any listed property (regardless of when it was put into use).
You cannot deduct your own salary or any withdrawals you make from your business for personal purposes.As a sole owner of a business, you are not an employee of the business.

Some of the ways you can pay your employees are: Rewards Bonuses Educational expenses Marginal benefits (explained below) Loans or advances that you do not expect employees to pay back if they are for personal services that have actually been done Property you transfer to an employee as payment for services Refunds of employees’ business expenses Sickness compensation Vacation pay.

You can generally deduct the cost of the marginal benefits you provide on your Schedule C in any category in which the cost falls. For example, if you allow an employee to use a car or other property that you lease, deduct the cost of the lease as a rental or lease expense. If you own the property, include your deduction on its cost or other basis as a deduction under section 179 or a depreciation deduction. You may be able to exclude all or part of the marginal benefits you provide from your employees' wages. For more information about marginal benefits and exclusion of benefits, see Publication 15-B.

You can generally deduct the premiums you pay for the following types of insurance related to your business: 1. Insurance against fire, theft, flood or similar events. 2. Credit insurance that covers losses from bad commercial debts. 3. Hospitalization and medical group insurance for employees, including long-term care insurance. 4. Liability insurance. 5. Professional negligence insurance that covers your personal liability for professional negligence resulting from injury or damage to patients or customers. 6. Workers' Compensation Insurance for work-related accidents established by state law that covers any claims for work-related physical injury or illness suffered by employees in your business, regardless of liability. 7. Contributions to the state unemployment insurance fund are tax deductible if taxed under state law. 8. Overhead insurance that covers the overhead of your business incurred during extended periods of disability caused by injury or illness. 9. Automobile and other vehicle insurance that covers vehicles used in your business against liability, damages and other losses. If you operate a vehicle in part for personal use, deduct only the portion of the insurance premium that applies to the commercial use of the vehicle. If you use the standard mileage rate to calculate your automobile expenses, you cannot deduct any automobile insurance premium. 10. Life insurance that covers your employees if you are not the direct or indirect beneficiary of the contract. 11. Business interruption insurance that pays for profits you lose if your business closes due to fire or other cause.

You cannot deduct premiums for the following types of insurance: 1. Self-insurance reserve funds. You cannot deduct amounts credited to a reserve established as self-insurance. This applies even if you cannot obtain commercial insurance coverage for certain business risks. However, your actual losses may be deductible. For more information, see Publication 547. 2. Loss of income. You cannot deduct premiums for a policy that pays for your loss of income due to illness or disability. However, see item (8) of the list above. 3. Certain life insurance and annuities. 1. For contracts issued before June 9, 1997, you cannot deduct premiums for a life insurance policy covering you, an employee, or any other person who has a financial interest in your business if you are the direct or indirect beneficiary of the policy. You are included as a potential beneficiary of the policy if the policy holder is required to use the profits from the policy to repay a loan made by you. A person has a financial interest in your business if that person owns or partially owns the business, or has lent money to the business. 2. For contracts issued after June 8, 1997, you generally cannot deduct premiums for any life insurance policy, endowment contract, or annuity contract if you are the direct or indirect beneficiary. This prohibition applies regardless of who is covered by the policy. 4. Insurance to obtain a loan. If you obtain an insurance policy on your life or the life of another person who has a financial interest in your business to obtain or protect a business loan, you cannot deduct the premiums as a business expense. Nor can you deduct premiums as interest on commercial loans or as a loan financing expense. In the event of death, the gains from the policy are not taxed.
You may be able to deduct the amount you pay for health and dental insurance, and qualified long-term care insurance for yourself and your family.

See Form 8962, Premium Tax Credit (PTC), and its instructions separately and use Publication 974 if the insurance plan established, or deemed to be established, under your business was obtained through the Health Insurance Marketplace and you are claiming the health insurance premium tax credit.

You cannot deduct expenses paid in advance, even if you pay them in advance. This rule applies to any expenses paid in advance sufficiently to effectively create an asset with a useful life that extends substantially beyond the end of the current tax year. l

The rules for a loan with a below-market interest rate. (This is usually a loan on which no interest is charged or on which interest is charged at a rate below the applicable federal rate.)

Legal and professional fees, such as accountants' fees, which are ordinary and necessary expenses directly related to the operation of your business are deducted on Schedule C. However, you normally cannot deduct legal fees you pay to acquire business assets. Add them to your property base. If the fees include payments for work of a personal nature (such as writing a will), you can take a business deduction only for the part of the fee that is related to your business.
