Schedule C can also be used to deduct the amount you pay or incur to resolve certain tax deficiencies related to your business as a sole proprietor of a business or as a statutory employee. Schedule C can be used to deduct the amount you pay or incur to resolve certain tax deficiencies related to your business as a sole proprietor of a business or as a statutory employee.

A non-resident alien (and certain resident aliens) of a country with which the United States has an income tax treaty may qualify for certain benefits. Most treaties require the non-resident alien to be a resident of the treaty country to qualify in the year in which the benefit is claimed. However, in the case of certain students, apprentices, teachers or researchers, some treaties require the non-resident alien to be a resident of the treaty country only immediately before arriving in the United States.

You can access the tax treaty tables at IRS.gov/TreatyTables. In addition, you can access the text of newly signed U.S. income tax treaties, protocols and tax information exchange agreements (TIEAs) and the accompanying technical explanations of the treaties from the Treasury Department as soon as they are available to the public, as well as the U.S. Model Income Tax Convention at Home.Treasury.gov/Policy-Issues/Tax-Policy/International-Tax. Note that treaty and TIEA documents are available on that website after they are signed and prior to their ratification and entry into force. The full text of tax treaties is also available at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. For more information on tax treaties, go to IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Tax-Treaties. You can usually arrange for reduced or eliminated withholding taxes on wages and other income that qualifies for benefits under a tax treaty. See Income Eligible for Tax Treaty Benefits in chapter 8.

Treaty-subject income of a nonresident alien is gross income on which tax is limited by a tax treaty. Treaty-subject income includes, for example, dividends from sources within the United States that are subject to tax at a rate under a tax treaty that does not exceed 15%. Non-treaty-subject income is gross income of a nonresident alien on which tax is not limited by a tax treaty. To determine tax on treaty-subject income items, calculate the tax for each income item separately that is subject to the reduced rate that applies to that income item under the tax treaty. To determine tax on non-treaty-subject income, calculate the tax either at the 30% rate or at the incremental rate, depending on whether or not the income is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States. Your tax liability is the sum of treaty-subject income tax plus non-treaty-subject income tax, but it cannot be greater than the tax liability calculated as if the tax treaty had not come into force.

The following paragraphs briefly explain the exemptions that are available under tax treaties for personal services income, remittances, scholarships, career development grants, and capital gains income. The conditions for claiming exemptions vary by tax treaty. For more information about conditions under a particular tax treaty, download the full text of most tax treaties with the United States at IRS.gov/Business/International-Business/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. Technical explanations for many of these treaties are also available on that website. See also Publication 901. Tax treaty benefits also cover income such as dividends, interest, rents, royalties, pensions, and annuities. These types of income may be exempt from U.S. tax or subject to a reduced rate of tax. For more information, see Publication 901 or the applicable tax treaty.

Under most income tax treaties, non-resident aliens of treaty countries and dual resident residents who are temporarily present in the United States to provide services may be eligible to exempt some or all of their personal services income from U.S. taxation if they meet the requirements of the relevant treaty article.
Some income tax treaties contain different requirements, such as a different maximum period of presence.for more information, see Publication 901.

Some income tax treaties contain an “independent personal services” clause that allows residents of a treaty country to exempt income earned as an independent contractor or self-employed from U.S. taxation if they are present in the United States for a period not exceeding a certain number of days and if they do not have a regularly available fixed base in the United States.

Under many income tax treaties, teachers or professors who are non-resident aliens and who temporarily visit the United States for the primary purpose of teaching at a university or other accredited educational institution are not subject to U.S. income tax on teaching compensation received during the first 2 or 3 years after their arrival in the United States. Many treaties also provide an exemption for participation in research. Typically, the teacher or professor must be in the United States primarily to teach, lecture, instruct, or participate in research. A substantial portion of that person's time must be devoted to those tasks. The normal duties of a teacher or professor include not only formal classroom work involving regularly scheduled lessons, demonstrations, or other student-engagement activities, but also the less formal method of presenting ideas in seminars or other informal groups and in joint efforts in the laboratory. If you entered the United States as a non-resident alien, but are now a resident alien, the treaty exemption may still apply. See Students, Apprentices, Practitioners, Teachers, Professors, and Researchers Who Became Resident Aliens, below under Resident Aliens.

Under some tax treaties, students, apprentices, and interns are exempt from taxes on remittances received from abroad for study and maintenance. In addition, under some treaties, scholarships and grants for research, and a limited amount of compensation received by students, apprentices, and interns, may be exempt from tax. If you arrived in the United States as a non-resident alien, but are now a resident alien, the treaty exemption may still apply. See Students, Apprentices, Interns, Teachers, Professors, and Researchers Who Became Resident Aliens, below, under Resident Aliens.
Most treaties provide for the exemption of gains from the sale or exchange of movable property.• Generally, gains from the sale or exchange of real property located in the United States are taxable.
Resident aliens may qualify for tax treaty benefits in the situations explained below.

Foreign residents generally do not qualify for tax treaty benefits, because most tax treaties contain a “saving clause” that preserves or “protects” the United States’ right to tax its citizens and residents as if the tax treaty had not come into force. However, many tax treaties have exceptions to the safeguard clause, which may allow a resident alien to continue to claim treaty benefits. Some exceptions to the safeguard clause apply to all resident aliens (e.g., under the treaty between the United States and the People’s Republic of China); others apply only to resident aliens who are not legal permanent residents of the United States (green card holders). In certain cases, you do not need to report your income on Form 1040 or 1040-SR as the income will be treaty-exempt from U.S. tax. However, if the income has been reported as taxable income on a Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099 or other informational form (e.g., on line 1a in the case of wages and salaries reported in box 1 of Form W-2), you must report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. Enter in the space provided “Exempt income”, the name of the treaty country and the treaty article providing for the exemption. For income that is subject to a reduced rate of tax, instead of an exemption, under the treaty, attach a written statement to Form 1040 or 1040-SR showing the calculation of the tax at the reduced rate.

If you receive social security benefits from Canada or Germany, they are treated for U.S. income tax purposes as if they were received under U.S. social security law. If you receive social security benefits from Canada or Germany, enter them on line 1 of your Social Security Benefits Worksheet in the Form 1040 Instructions for purposes of determining the taxable amount you must report on line 6b of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. You do not need to file a Form 8833 for those benefits.

Generally, you must be a non-resident foreign student, apprentice, practitioner, teacher, professor or researcher to claim a treaty exemption for remittances from abroad for U.S. education and maintenance, for scholarships, grants and professional development grants, and for wages or other compensation for personal services. Once you become a resident foreigner, you generally can no longer claim a treaty exemption for this income. However, if you entered the United States as a non-resident foreigner but are now a resident foreigner for U.S. tax purposes, the treaty exemption will continue to apply to you if the treaty safeguard clause (explained above) provides an exception to it and you otherwise meet the requirements for the treaty exemption (including any time limits for claiming treaty exemptions, explained below). This is true even if you are a non-resident spouse treated as a resident, as explained in chapter 1. If you qualify under an exception to the treaty safeguard clause, you can avoid withholding income tax by providing the payer with a Form W-9 with the return required by the Instructions for Form W-9.

In some cases, you do not need to report income on your Form 1040 or 1040-SR because the income will be exempt from U.S. tax under a treaty. However, if the income has been reported as taxable income on a Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099, or other reporting form, you must report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, the amounts reported in box 1 of Form W-2). Enter the amount for which treaty benefits are claimed, in parentheses, on line 8z of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Enter “ Exempt income ” in the space provided, the name of the treaty country, and the treaty article providing for the exemption.

If you claim treaty benefits that override or modify any provision of the Internal Revenue Code and, by claiming these benefits, your tax is reduced, or could be reduced, you must attach a completed Form 8833 to your tax return.See Exceptions, below, for situations where you are required to file Form 8833.
These are the most common situations where a Form 8833 is required.For additional provisions, see the Form 8833 instructions.

You do not have to file Form 8833 for any of the following: 1. You claim a reduced rate under a treaty for the withholding of tax on interest, dividends, rents, royalties or other fixed or determineable income paid annually or periodically normally subject to the 30% rate. 2. You claim that a treaty reduces or modifies taxation on income from personal service(s); dependents; pensions; annuities; social security and other public pensions; or income of artists, athletes, students, apprentices, or teachers. This includes taxable scholarships and career development grants. 3. You claim a reduction or modification of income taxation under an International Social Security Agreement or a diplomatic or consular agreement. 4. You are a partner in a partnership or a beneficiary of a legacy or trust and the partnership, legacy or trust reports the required information on your return. 5. Payments or items of income that are otherwise required to be disclosed do not exceed $10,000. 6. You claim treaty benefits for amounts that are: 1. Reported to you on a Form 1042-S; and 2. Received by you: 1. As a related person of a reporting corporation as stipulated in section 6038A (related to disclosure returns on a Form 5472 filed by U.S. corporations that are 25% owned by a foreign person); or 2. As a beneficial owner who is the direct holder or beneficiary of an account with a U.S. financial institution or qualified broker, or a direct partner, beneficiary or owner of a foreign legacy partnership or trust, of that U.S. financial institution, qualified broker, or foreign legacy partnership or trust.
If you are required to declare treaty benefits but do not, you may be subject to a $1,000 fine for each failure.

Employees of an international organization may be able to exempt their salaries under a provision, if any, in the international agreement establishing that international organization, or by meeting the requirements for exemption for such salaries under United States tax law.o An “international organization” is an organization designated by the President of the United States through an Executive Order to qualify for the privileges, exemptions and immunities provided for in the International Organizations Immunities Act.o The exemption explained in this chapter applies only to pay received for official services performed for a foreign government or international organization.o Other income from United States sources received by persons qualifying for this exemption may be fully taxable or may be given favourable treatment under a provision of an applicable tax treaty.o The appropriate treatment of such income (interest, dividends, etc.) is explained earlier in this publication.o

First, you need to check the tax exemption provisions under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular treaty, if any, to see if your wages qualify for exemption from U.S. income tax under those provisions. You generally do not qualify for the income tax exemption available under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular treaty if you are a U.S. citizen or a foreign resident in the U.S. For more information about the Vienna Conventions and bilateral consular treaties, email the Office of Foreign Missions of the Department of State at OFMAssistants@state.gov.

If you are not eligible for the tax exemption provided under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular treaty but are from a country that has a tax treaty with the United States, you should consult the tax treaty to find out if there is a provision that exempts your wages from U.S. income tax. If you are a U.S. citizen or resident alien who works in the United States for a foreign government, your wages are usually not exempt. For more information, see Wages and Pensions Paid by a Foreign Government in Publication 901.

Foreign government employees who do not qualify under the tax exemption provisions of the Vienna Conventions, a bilateral consular convention or a tax treaty may be able to exempt their foreign government salaries from U.S. income tax if they meet the following requirements for an exemption for such salaries under U.S. tax law. The exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current foreign government employees and not to former foreign government employees. Pensions received by former foreign government employees living in the U.S. do not qualify for the exemption explained here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. Common law rules apply to determining whether you are an employee or independent contractor. See Publication 1779 and Publication 15-A. Your salaries do not qualify for exemption under U.S. tax law if a “controlled business entity” employs you or your services are primarily related to a foreign government business activity (in or outside the U.S.). A controlled business entity is an entity in which a foreign government has a 50% (0.50) or greater interest and which carries on a business activity within or outside the U.S..

However, see Aliens who Maintain Immigrant Status (Legal Permanent Resident) below for a special rule that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. To claim the tax exemption, you must be able to show that you meet both requirements of U.S. tax law.

A State Department certification, if issued, is the simplest method of establishing that you meet the requirements for similar services and equivalent tax exemption, but is not required to qualify for exemption under U.S. tax law. For information about whether a certification has been issued and whether such certification is valid and applies to you, email the Department of State's Office of Foreign Missions at OFMAssistants@state.gov. Where no valid certification exists, you must establish with other written evidence that you provide services of a similar nature to those provided by U.S. government employees in foreign countries and that the country of your foreign government employer grants equivalent exemption to U.S. government employees providing similar services in your country.

Many agreements establishing international organizations contain a provision that may exempt your wages from U.S. income tax. If you are employed by an international organization in the United States, first determine if the international agreement establishing the international organization for which you work has such a provision and if you qualify for the exemption under it. These provisions generally do not exempt wages of employees who are U.S. citizens or resident foreigners.

If the international agreement that created the international organization for which you work does not contain a tax exemption provision and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen and also a citizen of the Republic of the Philippines), you may be able to exempt your wages under U.S. tax law. However, see Aliens who retain their immigrant status (legal permanent resident) below for a special rule that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. This exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of international organizations and not to former employees. Pensions received by former employees of international organizations living in the U.S. do not qualify for the exemption explained here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. Common law rules apply to determining whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. See Publication 1779 and Publication 15-A. To claim the exemption, you must be able to demonstrate that you meet the requirements of the tax exemption provision of the international organization agreement or U.S. tax law. You must know the article number of the tax exemption provision of the international organization agreement, if any, and the number of the Executive Order designating the organization as an international organization.

If you sign the waiver provided under section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) to maintain your legal permanent resident status (known as a green card), you no longer qualify for tax exemption under U.S. tax law as of the date of filing the waiver. If you are an employee of a foreign government or international organization who has a green card, in order to claim tax exemption under U.S. tax law you must also be able to demonstrate with written evidence from USCIS that you did not sign and file the USCIS Form I-508.

Before leaving the United States, all foreigners (except those listed under Aliens Who Do Not Need to Obtain Navigation or Exit Permits, below) must obtain a certificate of compliance. This document, commonly known as the “navigation permit” or “exit permit”, is part of the income tax form you must file before leaving. You will receive a navigation or exit permit after filing a Form 1040-C or Form 2063. These forms are explained in this chapter. To find out if you need a navigation or exit permit, read Aliens Who Do Not Need to Obtain Navigation or Exit Permits, below. If none of the categories under that topic apply to you, you must obtain a navigation or exit permit. Read Aliens Who Do Not Need to Obtain Navigation or Exit Permits, below.

If you fall into one of the following categories, you do not need to obtain a navigation or exit permit before leaving the United States.If you fall into one of these categories and do not need to obtain a navigation or exit permit, you must be able to support your claim for the exemption with appropriate identification or provide the authority granting the exemption.

If you are an alien who falls under category (1) or (2) above, and who filed a waiver under section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain a navigation or exit permit.This is true even if your income is exempt from U.S. tax due to an income tax treaty, consular agreement, or international agreement.

Foreign students, industrial apprentices, and exchange visitors, including their spouses and children, who enter only on an F-1, F-2, H-3, H-4, J-1, J-2, or Q visa and who do not receive income from U.S. sources while in the United States on those visas, except: Grants to cover expenses related to study or training in the United States, such as travel, living and tuition costs; The value of any services or food and lodging related to such study or training; Income from employment authorized by USCIS; or Interest income on deposits that is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business (see Interest Income in chapter 3).

Foreign students, including their spouses and children, who enter the United States only on an M-1 or M-2 visa and who do not receive income from U.S. sources while in the United States on those visas, except: Income from employment authorized by USCIS or Interest income on deposits that is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business (see Interest Income in chapter 3).

Certain other foreigners who are temporarily in the United States who have not received taxable income during the tax year up to and including the date of departure or during the previous tax year. If the IRS has reason to believe that an alien has received taxable income and the departure puts the collection of income tax at risk, then it may require the alien to obtain a navigation or exit permit. Aliens in this category are: 1. Foreign military apprentices entering the United States for the purpose of training under the auspices of the Department of Defense and leaving the United States on official military travel orders; 2. Foreign business visitors with a B-1 visa, or both B-1 and B-2 visas, who do not stay in the United States or a U.S. territory for more than 90 days during the tax year; 3. Foreign pleasure visitors with a B-2 visa; 4. Aliens passing through the United States or any of its territories with a C-1 visa or under contract, such as a bond agreement between a shipping line and the Secretary of Justice; and 5. Aliens entering the United States with an identification card to cross the border or for whom passports, visas and identification cards to cross the border are not required, if: 1. They are pleasure visitors; 2. They are business visitors who do not stay in the United States or a U.S. territory for more than 90 days during the tax year; or 3. They are passing through the United States or any of its territories.
Foreigners who are residents of Canada or Mexico and who frequently travel between Canada or Mexico and the United States for work and whose wages are subject to U.S. withholding tax.

If none of the categories listed above under Aliens Who Do Not Need to Obtain Navigation or Exit Permits apply to you, you must obtain a navigation or exit permit. To obtain a permit, file Form 1040-C or Form 2063 (as applicable) at your local TAC office before leaving the United States. See Forms You Must File, below. You also have to pay all taxes shown as due on Form 1040-C and any tax due for previous years. See How to Pay Taxes and Get Refunds, below.

To obtain a certificate of compliance, you must go to a TAC office at least 2 weeks before leaving the United States and file either Form 2063 or Form 1040-C and any other required tax returns that have not been filed. The certificate cannot be issued more than 30 days before your departure. If both you and your spouse are foreigners and will both leave the United States, you both must go to the TAC office. Please note that all TAC offices operate by appointment. You can call 844-545-5640 between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. to schedule an appointment. For more information about your local TAC office, please visit IRS.gov/TAC.

The process of obtaining your sailing or departure permit will be faster if you bring to the TAC office documents and paperwork related to your income and stay in the United States. Bring the following records with you if applicable: 1. Your passport and foreigner registration card or visa. 2. Copies of your U.S. income tax returns filed for the last 2 years. If you were in the United States for less than 2 years, bring the income tax returns you filed for that period. 3. Income tax receipts you paid on those returns. 4. Receipts, bank statements, cancelled checks and other documents proving your deductions, business and dependent expenses claimed on your returns. 5. A written statement from each employer showing the wages paid and tax withheld from January 1 of the current year to the day of departure if you were an employee. If you were self-employed, you must bring a statement of income and expenses up to the date you expect to leave. 6. Proof of estimated tax payments for the previous and this year. 7. Documents showing gains or losses from the sale of personal property and/or real property, including capital property and merchandise. 8. Documents related to scholarships and career development grants, including the following: 1. Verification of the grantor, source and purpose of the grant. 2. Copies of the application for, and approval of, the grant. 3. A report of the amount paid and your duties and obligations under the grant. 4. A list of all previous grants. 9. Documents indicating that you qualify for any special benefits claimed under a tax treaty. 10. Document proving the date of departure from the United States, such as an airline ticket. 11. Document proving your U.S. TIN.

If you need to obtain a navigation or exit permit, you must file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C. Both forms have a section titled “certificate of compliance.” When the certificate of compliance is signed by an Area Director agent of the Taxpayer Assistance Center, it certifies that your U.S. tax obligations are in compliance according to the information available. Your copy of the signed certificate of Form 1040-C, or the cut-off from Form 2063, is your navigation or exit permit.

If you have not filed an income tax return or paid income tax in any tax year, you must file your return and pay income tax before you can be issued a navigation or departure permit on Form 2063. The navigation or departure permit detached from Form 2063 can be used for all departures in the current year. However, the IRS may cancel the navigation or departure permit for any subsequent departure if it believes that the collection of income tax on that subsequent departure is at risk.

If you need to obtain a navigation or departure permit and do not qualify to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Generally, all income received or reasonably expected to be received during the tax year up to and including the departure date must be reported on Form 1040-C and the tax shown as due on it must be paid. When you pay any tax due as shown on Form 1040-C, file all returns and pay any tax due for previous years, you will receive a navigation or departure permit. However, the IRS may allow you to provide a bond to secure payment instead of paying taxes for certain years. See Bond to Assure Payment, below. A navigation or departure permit issued under the conditions in this paragraph is only for the specific departure for which it was issued.

If you provide the IRS with information that shows, to the satisfaction of the IRS, that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure does not put income tax collection at risk, you may obtain a navigation or departure permit by filing Form 1040-C without having to pay the tax shown on it. However, you must file all income tax returns that you have not yet filed as required and pay all income tax due on those returns. Your Form 1040-C must include all income received, and income that is reasonably expected to be received, for the entire departure year. The navigation or departure permit issued with this Form 1040-C can be used for all departures during the current year. However, the IRS may cancel the navigation or departure permit for any subsequent departures if income tax payment appears to be at risk.

If both spouses are resident aliens, they may file a joint return on Form 1040-C if: they can reasonably be expected to qualify for a joint return at the normal close of their tax year and their tax year ends at the same time. if they are resident aliens, they may file a joint return on Form 1040-C if: they can reasonably be expected to qualify for a joint return at the normal close of their tax year and their tax year ends at the same time.

You must pay all tax that is listed as due on Form 1040-C at the time of filing, except when you provide a bond or the IRS is satisfied that your departure will not jeopardize the collection of income tax. You also have to pay any taxes due for previous years. If the tax calculation on Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, there is no tax to pay at the time of filing. However, the IRS cannot provide a refund at departure. If you are owed a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

If you have paid all taxes due for previous years, you can provide a bond to secure the payment instead of paying the income tax shown on your Form 1040-C or tax return for the previous year if the period to file that return has not expired. The bond must be equivalent to the tax due plus interest as of the date of payment as determined by the IRS. Teaching compensation received for the entire tax year (or during the period of a ) qualifies for exemption from withholding federal income tax under a tax treaty between the United States and Greece. I have not previously claimed a treaty tax exemption for income received as a teacher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. I arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States before beginning the teaching services for which the exemption is claimed]. The treaty exemption is available only for compensation received during the period of 3 years from that date.

You must first determine whether, for income tax purposes, you are a nonresident alien or a resident alien. If you are both a nonresident and a resident in the same year, then you have dual residence. See Aliens with Dual Residence, later. See also Nonresident Spouse Treated as Resident and some other special situations discussed in this chapter.

You are a U.S. resident alien for tax purposes if you meet the green card requirement or the substantial presence requirement for the 2024 calendar year (January 1 to December 31). Even if you do not meet either of the requirements, you may be able to elect to be treated as a U.S. resident for part of the year. See First Year Choice under Dual Residence Aliens below.

You are a resident for tax purposes if you are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time during the calendar year 2024. (However, see Aliens with Dual Residence, below.) This is known as the “green card” requirement. You are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time if you have been given the privilege, under U.S. immigration laws, to reside permanently in the United States as an immigrant. You generally have this immigration status if the U.S. Immigration and Citizenship Service (USCIS) (or its predecessor organization) has issued you a Form I-551, Permanent Resident Card, also known as a green card. You continue to be a legal permanent resident under this requirement unless your status is withdrawn or administratively or judicially determined to be abandoned.

Your resident status is considered to have been withdrawn if the U.S. government issues a final administrative or court order of exclusion or deportation. a final court order is an order that you can no longer appeal to a higher court of competent jurisdiction.

When filing by mail, you must send your return by registered mail, requesting acknowledgement of receipt (or a foreign equivalent), and keep a copy and proof that it was sent and received. Until you have proof that your letter was received, you remain a foreign resident for tax purposes, even if USCIS does not recognize the validity of your green card because it is more than 10 years old or because you have been away from the United States for a period of time. If USCIS or a U.S. consular officer initiates this determination, your resident status will be considered abandoned when the final administrative abandonment order is issued. If you are granted an appeal to a federal court of competent jurisdiction, a final court order is required. Under U.S. immigration laws, a legal permanent resident who is required to file a tax return as a resident and does not do so may be deemed to have left the state (of resident) and may lose his permanent resident status. A long-term resident (LTR) who ceases to be a legal permanent resident may be subject to special tax requirements and provisions. See Expatriation Tax in chapter 4.

You are a resident for tax purposes if you meet the substantial presence requirement for the calendar year 2024. To meet this requirement, you must be physically present in the United States for at least: 1. 31 days in 2024 and 2. 183 days during the 3-year period that includes the years 2024, 2023, and 2022, counting: 1. all the days you were present in 2024, 2. 1/3 of the days you were present in 2023, and 3. 1/6 of the days you were present in 2022.

When calculating days of presence in the United States, you can exclude only the days you actually competed at a sporting event. You cannot exclude days you were in the United States to train for the event, to do promotional or other event-related activities, or to travel between events. If you qualify to exclude days of presence as a professional athlete, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 below.

Attach Form 8843 to your 2024 tax return. If you are not required to file a return, send Form 8843 to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file Form 8843 before the due date for Form 1040-NR. The due date for filing the return is explained in Chapter 7. If you are required to file Form 8843 and fail to file it on time, you cannot exclude days that you were present in the United States as a professional athlete or because of a medical condition that arose while you were in the United States. This does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable steps to learn about the filing requirements and the important steps to meet those requirements.

Do not count days when you are in the United States for less than 24 hours and are in transit between two locations outside the United States. You are considered in transit if you engage in activities that are substantially related to completing your trip to your foreign destination. For example, if you travel between airports in the United States to change planes en route to your foreign destination, you are considered in transit. However, you are not considered in transit if you attend a business meeting while in the United States. This is true even if the meeting takes place at the airport.

Don't count days you are temporarily present in the United States as a regular crew member of a foreign vessel (ship or vessel) involved in transportation between the United States and a foreign country or a U.S. territory, however, this exception does not apply if you are otherwise engaged in any occupation or business in the United States on those days.

Do not count days when you intended to leave, but were unable to leave, the United States due to a medical condition or problem that arose while in the United States. Whether you intended to leave the United States on a particular day is determined based on all the facts and circumstances. For example, you may be able to demonstrate that you intended to leave if your purpose of visiting the United States could be fulfilled for a period that was not long enough to qualify for the substantial presence test. However, if you need an extended period of time to fulfill the purpose of your visit and that period would qualify for the substantial presence test, you may not establish the intention to leave the United States before the end of that extended period. In the case of a person who is deemed mentally incompetent, proof of intent to leave the United States can be determined by looking at the pattern of the person’s behavior before he or she is deemed mentally incompetent. If you qualify to exclude days of presence due to a medical condition, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843, below. You cannot exclude any days of presence in the United States in the following circumstances: You were initially prevented from leaving, then were able to leave, but stayed in the United States beyond a reasonable period to arrange for departure. You returned to the United States for treatment of a medical condition that arose during a previous stay. The condition existed before your arrival in the United States and you were aware of the condition. It does not matter if you needed treatment for the illness when you entered the United States.

A foreign government-related individual is a person (or a member of the individual’s immediate family) who is temporarily present in the United States: as a full-time employee of an international organization, by reason of his/her diplomatic status, or by reason of a visa (other than a visa granting legal permanent residence) that the Secretary of the Treasury determines represents a full-time diplomatic or consular status.

If you are present in the United States under an A-3 or G-5 class visa as a personal employee, assistant or domestic worker for a foreign government or an official of an international organization, you are not considered a foreign government-related individual and must count your days in the United States for purposes of the substantial presence requirement.

A foreign employer includes an office or establishment of a U.S. entity in a foreign country or U.S. territory. If you qualify to exclude days of attendance as a teacher or apprentice, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843, below.
If you qualify to exclude days of attendance as a student, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS (see Form 8843, below).

Even if you meet the substantial presence requirement, you may be treated as a non-resident alien if you: Are present in the United States for less than 183 days during the year, Maintain a tax domicile in a foreign country during the year, and Have a closer connection during the year with a foreign country in which you have a tax domicile than the connection you have with the United States (unless you have a closer connection with two foreign countries, explained below).

You can prove that you have a closer connection to two (but not more than two) foreign countries if you meet all of the following conditions: You maintained a tax domicile from the first day of the year in a foreign country. You changed your tax domicile during the year to a second foreign country. You continued to maintain your tax domicile in the second foreign country for the rest of the year. You had a closer connection to each foreign country than to the United States during the period that you maintained a tax domicile in that foreign country. You are taxable as a resident under the tax laws of either of the two foreign countries for the entire year or taxable as a resident in both foreign countries during the period that you maintained a tax domicile in each foreign country.

Your tax domicile is the general area of your main place of work, employment or workplace, regardless of where you maintain your family home. Your tax domicile is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or self-employed. If you do not have a regular or main place of work because of the nature of your work, then your tax domicile is the place where you regularly live. If you are not in any of these categories, you are considered a traveler and your tax domicile is wherever you work. To determine whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country, your tax domicile also has to exist throughout the current year and must be located in the same foreign country with which you claim to have a closer connection.

To determine whether you have a closer connection with a foreign country, the term “foreign country” means: any territory under the sovereignty of the United Nations or a government other than the United States, the territorial waters of the foreign country (as determined under U.S. law), the seabed and subsoil of the subsea areas adjacent to the territorial waters of the foreign country and over which the foreign country has exclusive rights under international law to explore and exploit natural resources, and U.S. Territories.

It does not matter whether your permanent home is a house, an apartment or a furnished room, nor does it matter whether you rent or own your home, but it is important that your home is available at all times, continuously and not only for short stays.

Steps to change your immigration status to permanent resident include, but are not limited to, the submission of the following forms: Form I-508, Waiver of Certain Rights, Privileges, Exemptions, and Immunities; Form I-485, Application to Register Permanent Residence or Adjust Status; Form I-130, Petition for Alien Relative; Form I-140, Immigrant Petition for Alien Workers; Form ETA-9089, Application for Permanent Employment Certification, Appendix A-D, and Final Determination; Form DS-230, Application for Immigrant Visa and Alien Registration; or Form DS-231, Application for Permanent Employment Certification, Appendix A-D, and Final Determination.

You must attach a fully completed Form 8840, Closer Connection Exception Statement for Aliens, to your tax return to claim that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. If you do not have to file a tax return, send the form to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file Form 8840 by the due date of Form 1040-NR. The due date for filing the return is explained later in Chapter 7. If you do not file Form 8840 by the due date, you cannot claim a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. This does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable steps to learn about the filing requirements and the important steps to meet them.

The rules explained here to determine whether you are a U.S. resident do not override the definitions of residency under treaties. If you are a dual resident taxpayer, you can still claim benefits under a tax treaty. A dual resident taxpayer is a resident of both the U.S. and another country under the tax laws of each country. The income tax treaty between the two countries must contain a provision that provides for the resolution of conflicting residency claims (the tie-break rule). If you are treated as a resident of a foreign country under a tax treaty, you are treated as a non-resident alien for the purposes of determining your U.S. income tax. For purposes other than determining your taxes, you will be treated as a resident of the U.S. For example, the rules explained here do not affect periods of time of residence, as explained under Dual Resident Aliens below.

If you are a dual resident taxpayer claiming treaty benefits, you must file a return using Form 1040-NR with Form 8833 attached and determine your tax as a non-resident alien. A dual resident taxpayer may also be eligible for assistance from the U.S. tax authority. See Revenue Procedure 2015-40 on page 236 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2015-35, available at IRS.gov/irb/2015-35_IRB#RP-2015-40, or its successor. See How to Report Treaty Claimed Benefits in chapter 9 for more information on how to report treaty benefits.

Foreign non-resident students of Barbados and Jamaica, as well as apprentices from Jamaica, may qualify for an election to be treated as resident aliens for U.S. tax purposes under U.S. tax treaties with those countries. See Publication 901 for more information. If you qualify for this election, you can make it by filing Form 1040 and appending a signed written statement indicating your election to your tax return. The rules for foreign residents described in this publication apply to you. Once made, the election applies as long as you continue to be eligible, and you must obtain permission from the appropriate U.S. authority to terminate your election.

You can be a nonresident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year, usually in the year you arrive or leave the United States. Aliens who have dual residence should see Chapter 6 for information on how to file a return for a dual residence tax year.

Attach the required written statement to your tax return. If you are not required to file a tax return, send the written statement to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file the written statement on or before the due date of Form 1040-NR. The due date for the tax return is explained in Chapter 7. If you do not file the required written statement as explained above, you cannot claim to have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. Therefore, your first day of residence will be the first day you were present in the United States. This does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable steps to learn the requirements to file the return and to take significant steps to meet those requirements.

If you meet the Green Card requirement at any time during the calendar year, but do not meet the Substantial Presence requirement for that year, your beginning date of residence is the first day of the calendar year in which you are present in the United States as a lawful permanent resident.If you meet the Substantial Presence requirement and the Green Card requirement, your beginning date of residence is the first day of the year in which you are present in the United States under the Substantial Presence requirement or as a lawful permanent resident, whichever comes first.

If you were a U.S. resident for any part of the previous calendar year and are a U.S. resident for any part of the current year, you will be considered a U.S. resident at the beginning of the current year, whether you are a resident under the substantial presence requirement or the green card requirement.

When counting days of presence for conditions (1) and (2) above, do not count days you were in the United States under any of the exceptions explained above under Days of Presence in the United States. If you make the election in the first year, the start date of your residency for 2024 is the first day of the earlier 31-day period (described in condition (1) above) that you use to qualify for the election. You are treated as a U.S. resident for the rest of the year. If you are present for more than one period of 31 days and meet condition (2) above, for each of those periods, the start date of your residency is the first day of the first period of 31 days. If you are present for more than one period of 31 days but meet condition (2) above, for only one subsequent period of 31 days, the start date of your residency is the first day of the subsequent period of 31 days.

You cannot file Form 1040 or 1040-SR or the return until you meet the substantial presence requirement for 2025. If you have not met the 2025 requirement by April 15, 2025, you can request an extension of the deadline to file your 2024 Form 1040 or 1040-SR for a reasonable period after you have met that requirement. To request an extension to file your tax return until October 15, 2025, use Form 4868. You can file the form on paper or use one of the electronic filing options explained in the Form 4868 instructions. You must pay with this extension the amount of tax you expect to owe for 2024 calculated as if you were a non-resident alien all year. You can use Form 1040-NR to calculate the tax. Enter the tax on Form 4868. If you fail to pay the tax due, you will be charged interest on any tax unpaid by the due date of your tax return and may be charged a late payment penalty. Once you make the first year election, you cannot revoke it without the IRS approval. If you do not follow the procedures discussed here to make the first year election, you will be treated as a non-resident alien for the entire year 2024. However, this does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable steps to learn about the filing requirements for a return and the important steps to meet those requirements.

You usually make this election when you file your joint return. However, you can also make this election by filing Form 1040-X, Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR and write “Amended” at the top of the amended return. If you make the election with the amended return, you and your spouse also have to amend any returns you filed after the year for which you made the election. Generally, you have to file the amended joint return within 3 years of the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return, or within 2 years of the date you paid your income tax for that year, whichever is later.

If you are a U.S. resident for any part of 2025 and were a resident for any part of 2024, you will be treated as a resident until the end of 2024, whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country than to the U.S. during 2024 and whether you are a resident under the substantial presence requirement or the green card requirement.

Attach the required written statement to your income tax return. If you are not required to file a tax return, send your written statement to establish the date of termination of your residence to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file the written statement on or before the due date for filing Form 1040-NR. The due date for filing your tax return is explained in Chapter 7. If you do not file the required written statement as discussed above, you cannot claim to have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. This does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable steps to learn about the filing requirements and the important steps to meet those requirements.

If, at the end of the tax year, you are married and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or resident foreigner and the other spouse is a non-resident foreigner, you may elect to treat the non-resident spouse as a resident of the United States. This includes situations where one spouse is a non-resident foreigner at the beginning of the tax year but is a resident foreigner at the end of the year, and the other spouse is a non-resident foreigner at the end of the year. If you make this choice, you and your spouse are treated as residents for tax purposes for the entire tax year. Neither you nor your spouse can claim under any tax treaty to be non-residents of the United States. Both are subject to tax on their income worldwide. You must file a joint income tax return for the year you choose, but you and your spouse may file joint or separate returns in subsequent years. If you file a joint return under this provision, the special instructions and restrictions for dual resident taxpayers in Chapter 6 do not apply to you.

You usually make this election when you file your joint return. However, you can also make the election by filing an amended joint return using Form 1040-X. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR and write “Amended” at the top of the amended return. If you make the election with an amended return, you and your spouse also have to amend any returns you filed after the year for which you made the election. You usually have to file the amended joint return within 3 years of the date you filed your original return or 2 years of the date you paid your income tax for that year, whichever is later.

Once made, the election to be treated as a resident applies to you for all subsequent years, unless it is suspended (as explained above under How to Suspend the Election) or terminates in one of the following ways. If the election terminates in one of the following ways, neither spouse can make this election in any subsequent tax year: 1. Revocation. Either spouse can revoke the election in any tax year, provided that they do so by the due date to file their tax return for that tax year. The spouse revoking the election must attach a signed statement stating that they are revoking the election. The statement must include the name, address, and TIN of each spouse. (If one spouse dies, include the name and address of the person revoking the election of the deceased spouse.) The statement also must include a list of all states, foreign countries, and territories that have community property (or partnership) laws where one spouse is domiciled or where real property is located from which one of them receives income. File the written statement as follows: 1. If the spouse revoking the election must file a tax return, attach the written statement to the tax return for the first year that the revocation applies. 2. If the spouse revoking the election does not have to file a tax return, but does file a tax return (for example, to get a refund), attach the written statement to the tax return. 3. If the spouse revoking the election does not have to file a tax return and does not file a refund claim, send the written statement to the Internal Revenue Service Center where they last filed their joint tax return. 2. Death. Death.

If you are a non-resident alien and a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are subject to tax, with certain exceptions, under the rules for U.S. resident aliens. For more information, see Bona Fide Residents of American Samoa or Puerto Rico in chapter 5. If you are a non-resident alien of American Samoa or Puerto Rico who does not qualify as a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are subject to U.S. tax as a non-resident alien. Resident aliens who were previously bona fide residents of American Samoa or Puerto Rico are subject to U.S. tax under the rules for resident aliens.

The income of a resident alien is generally subject to U.S. taxation in the same way as the income of U.S. citizens. If you are a resident alien, you must declare all interest, dividends, wages or other compensation for services rendered; income from rental property or royalties; and other types of income on your U.S. tax return. You must declare these amounts from sources within and outside the United States.

Non-resident aliens are taxed only on their income from U.S. sources and certain income related to an occupation or business in the U.S. (see chapter 4). The general rules for determining income from U.S. sources that apply to most non-resident aliens are shown in Table 2-1. The discussions below cover the general rules as well as exceptions to these rules. Not all classes of income from U.S. sources are subject to taxation. See chapter 3.

Real property is land and buildings and, in general, everything that is built on, grows on, or is attached to land. Gross income from U.S. sources includes gains, profits, and income from the sale or other disposition of real property located in the U.S.. 10.

Revenue from the sale of products from any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural deposit, or timber located in the United States and sold in a foreign country, or located in a foreign country and sold in the United States, is partly from U.S. sources. For information on the determination of that part, see section 1.863-1(b) of the Regulations.

Personal property is property such as machinery, equipment, furniture, stocks, bonds, and other securities that are not real property. The gain or loss from the sale or exchange of personal property is generally from a U.S. source if you have a tax domicile in the U.S. otherwise the gain or loss is generally considered to be from a source outside the U.S..

Your tax domicile is the general area of your main place of work, employment, or workstation, regardless of where you maintain your family home. Your tax domicile is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or self-employed. If you do not have a regular or main place of business because of the nature of your work, then your tax domicile is the place where you regularly live. If you do not fall under any of these categories, you are considered a traveler and your tax domicile is wherever you work.

Inventory property is movable property that is either stock in the trade or is held primarily for sale to customers in the ordinary course of your occupation or business. The source of income from the sale of inventory that you purchased is determined by the place where the property was sold. Generally, this is where title to the property passes to the buyer. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the United States is from a U.S. source, whether you purchased it in the United States or a foreign country. The source of income from the sale of inventory property that you produced in the United States and sold outside the United States (or vice versa) is determined by the place where the property is produced. These rules apply even if your tax domicile is not in the United States.

To determine the source of any gain from the sale of movable property subject to depreciation, you first have to calculate the portion of the gain that is not greater than the total depreciation adjustments of the property. This portion of the gain is allocated to U.S. sources based on the ratio between U.S. depreciation adjustments and total depreciation adjustments. The rest of this portion of the gain is considered to be from sources outside the U.S. For this purpose, “U.S. depreciation adjustments” are the depreciation adjustments to the property base that are allowed to calculate taxable income from U.S. sources. However, if the property is used primarily in the U.S. during the tax year, all depreciation deductions allowed for that year are treated as U.S. depreciation adjustments. But there are some exceptions for certain transportation, communications and other internationally used property. The source of a loss is determined in the same way as it was determined for depreciation deductions. However, if the property was used primarily in the U.S., the total loss reduces the income from U.S. sources. The property base normally means the cost (money plus the fair market value of other goods or services) of the property you acquire. Depreciation is an amount deducted to recover the cost or other basis of an asset of an occupation or business. The amount you can deduct depends on the cost of the property, when you began using the property, how long it will take to recover the cost, and what depreciation method you use. A depreciation deduction is any depreciation or amortization deduction or any other allowable deduction that treats a capital expenditure as a capital expenditure.

Intangible property includes patents, copyrights, secret procedures and formulas, goodwill, trademarks, trade names, or other similar property. The source of the gain from the sale of amortising or depreciating intangible property, up to previously admissible depreciation or amortization deductions, is determined in the same way as it was determined for the original deductions. This is the same as the source rule for gain from the sale of depreciable property. See Depreciable property, above, for details on how to apply this rule. The source of the gain in excess of depreciation or amortization deductions is determined based on the country where the property is used if the income from the sale depends on the productivity, use, or disposition of that property. If the income does not depend on the productivity, use, or disposition of the property, the source of income is determined based on your tax domicile (discussed above). If goodwill payments do not depend on the productivity, use, or disposition of the property, their source is the country in which the goodwill was generated.

Despite any of the above rules, if you are not a tax domiciled in the United States but maintain an office or other fixed place of business in the United States, treat the income from any sale of movable property (including inventory property) that is attributable to that office or place of business as income from U.S. sources. However, this rule does not apply to sales of inventory property for use, disposal or consumption outside the United States if your office or other fixed place of business outside the United States was substantially involved in the sale. If you are a tax domiciled in the United States but maintain an office or other fixed place of business outside the United States, the income from sales of movable property, other than inventory, depreciable property or intangible property, that is attributable to that office or place of business abroad may be treated as income from U.S. sources. The income is treated as income from U.S. sources if an income tax of less than 10% of the income generated from the sale is paid to a foreign country. This rule also applies to losses if the foreign country would have levied an income tax of less than 10% had the sale resulted in a profit.

The source of a substitute interest payment made to the transferor of a security in a securities lending transaction or a sale with repurchase transaction is determined in the same way as the source of interest on the transferred security, and the source of interest on the transferred security is determined in the same way as the source of interest on the transferred security.

Interest income from U.S. sources does not include the following: 1. Interest paid by a foreign resident or domestic corporation on bonds issued before August 10, 2010 if, for the 3-year period ending at the close of the payer’s tax year prior to the interest payment, at least 80% (0.80) of the payer’s total gross income: 1. Comes from sources outside the United States and 2. Is attributable to the active operation of an occupation or business by an individual or corporation in a foreign country or a U.S. territory. However, the interest will be treated as interest income from a U.S. source if any of the following conditions apply: 1. The person receiving the interest is related to the foreign resident or domestic corporation. See section 954(d)(3) for the definition of “related person.” 2. The terms of the bond are significantly modified after August 9, 2010. Any extension of the term of the bond is considered a significant modification. 2. Interest paid by a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or domestic partnership on deposits or withdrawal accounts with mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, homebuilding societies, loans and other savings societies registered and supervised as savings and loan societies or similar societies under state or federal law if the interest paid or credited is deductible by the corporation. 3. Interest on deposits with a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or domestic partnership, but only if the branch is in the commercial banking business.

In most cases, dividend income received from domestic corporations is income from U.S. sources. Dividend income from foreign corporations is usually income from foreign sources. An exception to the second rule is explained below. The source of an alternative (substitute) dividend payment made to the transferor of a security in a securities lending transaction or a sell-and-buy transaction is determined in the same way that the source of a distribution of a transferred security is determined.

A payment of an amount equivalent to a dividend includes any gross amount referring to a dividend from a U.S. source and used to calculate any net amount transferred to, or from, a taxpayer under a contract if the taxpayer is the long party under the contract. As a result, a taxpayer may be treated as if it had received a payment equivalent to dividends even if the taxpayer makes a net payment or no amount is paid because the net amount is zero. In 2024, an NPC or an ELI will generally be a specified NPC or a specified ELI, respectively, if the contract is a delta one designated transaction. In general, delta is the ratio of the change in the fair market value of an NPC or an ELI to a small change in the fair market value of the number of shares referred to in the contract. Typically, the amount of a dividend equivalent for a specified NPC or a specified ELI is the amount of the dividend per share multiplied by the number of shares referred to in the contract multiplied by the delta of the contract. Special rules apply to complex contracts. See section 1.871-15 of the Regulations and Notice 2024-44 (or its successors) for more information.

All wages and any other compensation for services rendered in the United States are deemed to come from U.S. sources. The only exceptions to this rule are discussed under Employees of Foreign Persons, Organizations or Offices, below, and under Crew Members, above. If you are an employee and receive compensation for work or personal services performed both in and outside the United States, special rules apply to determine the source of compensation. The source of compensation (in addition to certain supplemental benefits) is determined on a time basis. The source of certain supplemental benefits (such as housing and education) is determined on a geographical basis. or, you may be allowed to use an alternative basis to determine the source of compensation. See Alternative Base, below.

If you are self-employed, you determine the source of compensation for work or personal services from self-employment using the basis that most accurately reflects the appropriate source of that income based on the facts and circumstances of your particular case.l In many cases, the facts and circumstances will require a pro-rata time basis, as explained below.l

Generally, the source of multi-year compensation is determined using the time basis for the period to which the compensation is attributed. Multi-year compensation is compensation that is included in your income in 1 tax year, but is attributable to a period that includes 2 or more tax years. You determine the period to which the compensation is attributed based on the facts and circumstances of your case. For example, the amount of compensation that is specifically related to a period of time that includes several calendar years is attributable to the entire multi-year period. The amount of compensation treated as coming from U.S. sources is calculated by multiplying the total of the multi-year compensation by a fraction. The numerator of the fraction is the number of days (or a unit of time less than one day, if applicable) that you worked or provided personal services in the United States in connection with the project. The denominator of the fraction is the total number of days (or a unit of time less than one day, if applicable) that you worked or provided personal services in connection with the project.
The amount of supplementary benefits must be reasonable and justified by appropriate records or by sufficient evidence.

The source of the supplementary benefits listed above, except for a tax refund or pay for dangerous or difficult service, is determined by your main place of work. Your main place of work is usually the place where you spend most of your working time. That place can be your office, plant, store, workshop or any other location. If there is no single place where you spend most of your working time, your main place of work is the place where your work is centered, such as the place where you show up for work or where you are otherwise required to “drop off” your work. If you have more than one job at any time, the main location of your work depends on the facts of each case. The most important factors to consider are: the total time you spend at each place, the amount of work you do at each place, and how much money you earn at each place.

The source of the supplementary education allowance for educational expenses of your dependents is determined on the basis of the location of your main place of employment. A supplementary education allowance includes payments only for the following educational expenses at a primary or secondary school: tuition, school fees, academic tutoring, special needs services for a student with special needs, books, supplies and other equipment, accommodation and meals, and uniforms required or provided by the school in connection with enrolment or attendance.

The source of the local commuting supplement is determined by the location of your main place of work. Your local commuting supplement is the amount you receive as local commuting compensation for yourself or your spouse or your dependents at the location of your main place of work. The amount treated as local commuting supplement is limited to the actual local commuting expenses incurred and the fair rental value of any vehicle provided by the employer used predominantly by you, your spouse or your dependents for local commuting. The actual expenses do not include the cost (including interest) of any vehicle purchased by you or on your behalf.
The source of the supplemental tax refund benefit is determined based on the location of the jurisdiction that imposed the tax for which you are being refunded.

The source of a removal reimbursement is generally based on the location of your new principal place of work. However, the source is determined on the basis of the location of your former principal place of work if you provide sufficient evidence that such determination of the source is more appropriate in the facts and circumstances of your case. Sufficient evidence generally requires an agreement between you and your employer, or a written statement of the company ' s policy, which is put in writing prior to the move and which is made or established to induce you or other employees to move to another country. The written statement or agreement must state that your employer will reimburse you for the removal expenses you incur to return to your former principal place of work, whether or not you continue to work for your employer after returning to that location. It may contain certain conditions on which the entitlement to reimbursement is determined provided that the conditions set out set out rules that are definitively verifiable and that can only be met before, or by the conclusion of, your return to your former principal place of work.

If you are an employee, you may determine the source of your compensation using an alternative basis if you establish to the satisfaction of the IRS that, in the facts and circumstances of your case, the alternative basis determines the source of your compensation more adequately than the time or geographic basis. If you use an alternative basis, you must keep (and make available for inspection) records to document why the alternative basis determines the source of your compensation more adequately. In addition, if your total compensation from all sources is $250,000 or more, check “Yes” for both questions in Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR) item K, and attach a written statement to your tax return that sets out all of the following: 1. Your name and Social Security number (written at the top of the written return). 2. The specific income, or benefit of a specific supplementary benefit, for which you are using the alternative basis. 3. For each item in item (2), the alternative allocation basis of the source used. 4. For each item in item (2), the calculation showing how the alternative allocation was calculated. 5. A comparison of the dollar amount of U.S. compensation and foreign compensation from a given source on the alternative basis and the time or geographic basis discussed above.

Transportation income is income from the use of a ship or aircraft, or from the provision of services directly related to the use of any ship or aircraft. This is true whether the ship or aircraft is owned, contracted or leased. The phrase “ship or aircraft” includes any container used in connection with a ship or aircraft. Any transportation income that begins and ends in the United States is treated as derived from U.S. sources. If transportation begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the transportation income is treated as derived from U.S. sources. For transportation income from personal services, 50% of the income is derived from U.S. sources if transportation is between the United States and a U.S. territory. For non-resident aliens, this applies only to income derived from or in connection with an aircraft. For information on how transportation income from U.S. sources is taxed, see chapter 4.

Generally, the source of scholarships, professional development grants, grants, awards, and rewards is the residence of the payer, regardless of who actually disburses the funds. However, see Activities Performed Outside the United States below. For example, payments for professional development or study in the United States made by the United States, a resident who is not a U.S. corporation or a domestic corporation are from U.S. sources. Similar payments from a foreign government or foreign corporation are from foreign sources, even though the funds may be disbursed through a U.S. agent. Payments made by an entity designated as a public international organization under the International Organizations Immunities Act are from foreign sources.

Scholarships, career development grants, specific grants, and achievement awards received by non-resident aliens for activities performed or to be performed outside the United States are not income from U.S. sources. These rules do not apply to amounts paid as salary or other compensation for services. See Personal Services above for information about the source rules that apply.

If you receive a pension from a domestic trust for services rendered both in and outside the United States, part of the pension payment comes from U.S. sources. That part is the amount attributable to pension plan income and employer contributions made for services rendered in the United States. This applies whether the distribution is made under a qualified or unqualified stock bonus, pension, profit-sharing or annuity plan (funded or unfunded). If you served as a U.S. employee, you may receive a distribution from the U.S. government under a plan, such as the Civil Service Retirement System, that is treated as a qualified pension plan. Your U.S. source income is the amount of the distribution that is otherwise taxable, attributable to your U.S. government basic salary, other than the tax-exempt pay for services rendered outside the United States.

If you are required to file a federal income tax return on U.S. income, you may be entitled to some special disaster-related rules regarding the use of retirement funds. For more information, see Publication 590-B, Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs). Also visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

Special rules provide for tax-benefit withdrawals and repayments from certain retirement plans (including IRAs) for taxpayers who suffered financial losses from certain major disasters. For information on reporting distributions and repayments for qualifying disasters, see Form 8915-F, Qualified Disaster Retirement Plan Distributions and Repayments, and its instructions. l

Your income from U.S. sources includes rent and royalties received during the taxation year from property located in the U.S. or from any interest in that property. Income from U.S. sources also includes rent or royalties for the use of, or the privilege to use, intangible property in the U.S., such as patents, copyrights, secret processes and formulas, goodwill, trademarks, franchises and similar property.

A spouse ' s income from work, other than income from an occupation or business, and a distributive share to a partner in the profits of a partnership, are treated as income of the spouse whose services produce the income, and that spouse must declare all of it on his or her separate return.

Income from an occupation or business, other than a distributive share to a partner in the profits of a partnership, is treated as income of the spouse who carries on the occupation or business, and that spouse must declare everything on his or her separate return.
The distributional share of a partner in the income (or losses) of a partnership is treated as the partner's income (or losses) and that spouse must declare it all on his or her separate return.

Income from a spouse's separate property (and not income from employment, income from an occupation or business, or income from distributive shares in the income (or losses) of a partnership) is treated as that spouse's income. That spouse must declare everything on his or her separate return. Use the appropriate community property law to determine what is separate property.
All other income from matrimonial property is treated in accordance with the laws governing the respective matrimonial property.

Residents and non-resident aliens are allowed gross income exclusions if they meet certain conditions. A gross income exclusion is usually income you receive that is not included in your U.S. income and is not subject to U.S. taxation. This chapter covers some of the most common exclusions allowed to residents and non-resident aliens.
Resident foreigners may be able to exclude the following items from their income.

If you are physically present in a foreign country or countries for at least 330 full days during any 12-month consecutive period, you may qualify for the foreign earned income exclusion. The exclusion is $126,500 in 2024. In addition, you may be able to exclude or deduct certain amounts for foreign dwellings. You may also qualify if you are a bona fide resident of a foreign country and a citizen or national of a country with which the United States has a tax treaty. For more information, see Publication 54.

A foreign country is any territory under the sovereignty of a government other than the United States. The term “foreign country” includes the territorial waters and airspace of the country, but not the international waters or airspace above them. It also includes the seabed and subsoil of the subsea areas adjacent to the country’s territorial waters over which it has exclusive rights under international law to explore and exploit natural resources. The term “foreign country” does not include U.S. territories. It does not include the Antarctic region.
