Non-resident foreigners may exclude the following items from their gross income:

Interest income that is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business is excluded from income if it derives from: Deposits (including certificates of deposit) with persons in the banking business; Deposits or withdrawal accounts in mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, homebuilding and loan societies and other savings institutions chartered and supervised as savings and loan societies or similar associations under state and federal law (if interest paid or paid-in is deductible by the society); and Amounts held by an insurance company under an agreement to pay interest thereon.

Interest on bonds of a state or political subdivision, the District of Columbia, or a U.S. territory is generally not included in income; however, interest on certain private activity bonds, arbitration bonds, and certain bonds that are not in registered form are included in income.

Interest and discount on the original issue (OID) that qualifies as interest on the investment securities portfolio is not subject to Chapter 3 (IRS) withholding under sections 1441 to 1443. However, such interest may be subject to withholding if it is a taxable payment and there is no exemption from Chapter 4 (IRS) withholding under sections 1471 to 1474. For more information, see the explanation of interest on the investment securities portfolio under Withholding on Specific Income in Publication 515, Withholding of Tax on Nonresident Aliens and Foreign Entities. To qualify as interest on the investment securities portfolio, interest must be paid on bonds issued after July 18, 1984, and otherwise be subject to withholding. For bonds issued after March 18, 2012, interest on the investment securities portfolio does not include interest paid on debts that are not in registered form. Prior to March 19, 2012, interest on the investment securities portfolio included interest on certain registered and unregistered (bearer) bonds if the bonds meet the requirements described below.

An obligation that would otherwise be considered recorded is not considered recorded at a given time if it can be converted at any time in the future to an obligation that is not recorded. For more information on whether obligations are considered recorded, see the explanation of interest from the investment portfolio under Withholding on Specific Income in Publication 515. to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to to

No documentation is required for interest on bearer bonds to qualify as interest from the investment portfolio, but in some cases you may need documentation for purposes of Form 1099 information and additional withholding of interest and certain dividend tax.

Payments to certain persons and contingent interest payments do not qualify as interest from the investment portfolio and you must withhold tax using the statutory rate for such payments, unless you apply some other exception, such as a treaty provision.

Interest on the investment securities portfolio does not include contingent interest. Contingent interest is one of the following: 1. Interest that is determined by reference to: Any receipt, sale or other cash flow of the debtor or related person; Income or gains of the debtor or related person; Any change in the value of the debtor or related person s property; or Any dividend, distribution of a partnership, or similar payment made by the debtor or a related person. For exceptions, see section 871(h)(4)(C). 2. Any other type of contingent interest identified by the Secretary of the Treasury in regulations.

Related persons include the following: Members of a family, including only siblings, half siblings, a spouse, ascendants (parents, grandparents, etc.), and direct descendants (children, grandchildren, etc.); Any person who is a party to an arrangement made with the primary purpose of avoiding the contingent interest rules; Certain corporations, partnerships and other entities. For details, see Nondeductible Loss in chapter 2 of Publication 544, Sales and Other Dispositions of Assets.

Contingent interest does not include interest paid or accrued on any fixed-term debt issued: On or before April 7, 1993; or After April 7, 1993, pursuant to a binding written contract in force on that date and at all times thereafter prior to the issuance of that debt.
The following dividend income is exempt from the 30% tax.

There is no 30% tax on dividends from U.S. sources you receive from a foreign corporation. See Exception under Dividends in chapter 2 for how to calculate the amount of dividends from U.S. sources. This exception does not apply to payments of dividend equivalents.

There is no 30% tax on interest-related dividends from sources within the United States that you receive from a mutual fund or other regulated investment corporation.ת The mutual fund will designate in writing which dividends are interest-related dividends.

There may be no 30% tax on certain short-term capital gains dividends from U.S. sources that you receive from a mutual fund or other regulated investment corporation. The mutual fund will designate in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends. This tax relief does not apply to you if you are present in the U.S. for 183 days or more during your tax year.

If you do not meet all three conditions, your income from providing personal services in the United States is income from U.S. sources and is subject to tax according to the rules in chapter 4. If your pay for these services is more than $3,000, the total amount is income from an occupation or business within the United States. To find out if your pay is more than $3,000, do not include any amounts you receive from your employer for advances or refunds of business travel expenses if you were required to account for, and did account for, these expenses to your employer. If the advances or refunds exceed your expenses, include the excess in your pay for these services. A “day” means a calendar day during which you are physically present in the United States.

Non-resident foreign exchange students and visitors present in the United States on an F, J, M or Q visa may exclude from gross income the salary received from a foreign employer. This group includes bona fide students, academics, apprentices, teachers, professors, research assistants, specialists or leaders in a field of specialized knowledge or skills or persons of similar description. It also includes the spouse of the foreigner and their minor children if they come with the foreigner or come to join the foreigner later. A non-resident foreigner temporarily present in the United States on a J visa includes an alien entering the United States as an exchange visitor under the Mutual Educational and Cultural Exchange Act of 1961.
The term “foreign employer” does not include a foreign government.Pay from a foreign government that is exempt from U.S. tax is explained in Chapter 10.
If you are unsure whether the annuity comes from a qualifying annuity plan or a qualifying trust, ask the person who made the payment.

Income of any kind that is exempt from U.S. tax under a treaty to which the United States is a party is excluded from its gross income; however, income on which tax is limited only by a treaty is included in gross income. See chapter 9.
You may exclude from your gross income winnings from legal bets initiated outside the United States on a pari-mutuel pool with respect to a live horse or dog race in the United States.

If you sold your primary home, you may be able to exclude up to $250,000 from the gain from the sale of your home. If you are married and filing a joint return, you may be able to exclude up to $500,000. For information on the requirements for this exclusion, see Publication 523. This exclusion does not apply if you are subject to the expatriate tax rules discussed in Chapter 4.

If you are a university degree applicant, you may be able to exclude from your income some or all of the amounts you receive as a qualifying scholarship. The rules discussed here apply to both residents and non-resident aliens. If a non-resident alien receives a grant that is not from U.S. sources, he or she is not subject to U.S. taxation. See Scholarships, Grants, Awards and Rewards in chapter 2 to determine if your grant is from U.S. sources. A scholarship or professional development scholarship is excluded from income only if: 1. you are a university degree applicant at an eligible educational institution and 2. you use the scholarship or professional development scholarship to pay qualified educational expenses.

You are a college graduate if: 1. You attend an elementary or high school or are pursuing an academic degree at a college or university or 2. You attend an accredited educational institution that is authorized to provide: 1. A program that is acceptable for full credit for a college or higher degree or 2. A training program to prepare students for paid employment in a recognized occupation.

An eligible educational institution is one that maintains a regular faculty and curriculum and has a regular enrollment of students attending the place where it carries out its educational activities.
This is true even if the fee has to be paid to the institution as a condition of enrolment or attendance.The scholarship or professional development amounts used to pay those costs are taxable.
The amount of a scholarship used to pay any non-qualifying expenses is taxable, even if the expense is a fee that must be paid to the institution as a condition of enrolment or attendance.

You cannot exclude from income the portion of any scholarship, professional development grant or tuition reduction that represents payment for past, present or future teaching, research or other services, even if all applicants for a university degree are required to provide the services as a condition of receiving the degree.

Resident and non-resident foreigners are taxed in different ways. Resident foreigners are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Non-resident foreigners are taxed based on the source of their income and whether or not their income is directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. The following explanations will help you determine if the income you receive during the tax year is directly related to a U.S. occupation or business and how the income is taxed.

Foreign residents are generally subject to tax in the same way as U.S. citizens. This means that their worldwide income is subject to U.S. taxation and must be reported on their U.S. tax return. Foreign residents' income is subject to the graduated tax rates applicable to U.S. citizens. Foreign residents use the Tax Table or Tax Calculation Worksheet in the Instructions for Form 1040 for U.S. citizens.

The difference between these two categories is that directly related income, after eligible deductions, is subject to tax at graduated rates. These are the same rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Non-directly related income is subject to a flat rate of 30% (or less under a treaty). If you were previously a U.S. citizen or resident alien, these rules may not apply. See Expatriate Tax, later in this chapter.

Generally, you must engage in an occupation or business during the tax year in order to consider income received in that year to be directly related to that occupation or business. Whether you engage in a U.S. occupation or business depends on the nature of your activities. The discussions below will help you determine if you are engaged in a U.S. occupation or business.

If you provide personal services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are usually considered to be engaged in a U.S. occupation or business. Certain compensation paid to a non-resident alien by a foreign employer is not included in gross income. For more information, see Services Provided to a Foreign Employer in chapter 3.
Other examples of participation in a U.S. occupation or business are listed below.

If you are temporarily present in the United States as a nonimmigrant on an F, J, M, or Q visa, and did not engage in an occupation or business, you are deemed to have engaged in a U.S. occupation or business if you have taxable income from participation in a scholarship or professional development grant, as described in section 1441(b). The taxable portion of any scholarship or professional development grant from a U.S. source of income is treated as directly related to an occupation or business in the U.S..
If you own and operate a business in the United States that sells services, products or merchandise, you are engaged, with certain exceptions, in an occupation or business in the United States.
If you are a member of a partnership that at any time during the tax year engages in a U.S. occupation or business, you are considered to engage in a U.S. occupation or business.
If you are the beneficiary of a estate or trust that is engaged in a U.S. occupation or business, you are treated as if you were engaged in the same occupation or business.

If your only U.S. business is the trading of stocks, securities or commodities (including hedging transactions) through a U.S. resident stock broker or other agent, you are not engaged in a U.S. occupation or business. For stock or securities transactions, this applies to any non-resident foreigner, including a stock and securities dealer or distributor. For commodity transactions, this applies to commodities that are normally traded on an organized commodity exchange and to transactions that are normally conducted on that exchange. This discussion does not apply if you have a U.S. office or other fixed place of business at any time during the tax year through which, or under the direction of which, you trade in stocks, securities or commodities.

You are not engaged in a U.S. occupation or business if the only business activity you conduct in the United States is to trade on your own account in stocks, securities or commodities. This applies even if the trade is conducted while you are present in the United States or if it is conducted by your employee or your broker or other agent. This does not apply to trading on your own account if you are a stock, securities or commodity dealer. However, this does not necessarily mean that, as a dealer, you are considered to be engaged in a U.S. occupation or business. Determine this based on the facts and circumstances of each case or the rules mentioned above under Trading in Stocks, Securities and Commodities.

If you are engaged in a U.S. occupation or business, any income, gain or loss for the tax year that you gain from U.S. sources (other than certain investment income) is treated as directly related income. This applies regardless of whether there is any connection between the income and the occupation or business being carried on in the U.S. during the tax year. The two requirements described under Investment Income below determine whether certain items of investment income (such as interest, dividends, and royalties) are treated as directly related to that business. In limited circumstances, some types of income from foreign sources may be treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. For an explanation of these rules, see Foreign Income below.

Use the two requirements below to determine whether an element of U.S. source income that was classified in one of the three categories listed above and received during the tax year is directly related to your U.S. occupation or business. If the requirements indicate that the income is directly related, you must include that income with your other directly related income. If the income is not directly related, you must include it with all other income explained under 30% Tax later in this chapter.
Generally, shares in a corporation are not treated as an asset used in, or held for use in, a U.S. occupation or business.
Under this requirement, if the conduct of the U.S. occupation or business was a significant factor in the production of the income, the income is considered directly related.

You are normally engaged in a U.S. occupation or business when you provide personal services in the United States. Personal services income that you receive in a tax year in which you engage in a U.S. occupation or business is directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. Income received in a year other than the year in which you provided the services is also directly related if it was received in the year in which you provided the services. Personal services income includes wages, salaries, commissions, fees, daily allowances, and employee allowances and bonuses. Income may be paid to you in the form of cash, services, or goods. If you engage in a U.S. occupation or business only because you provide personal services in the United States during the tax year, income and gains from assets, and gains and losses from the sale or exchange of capital goods, are generally not directly related to your occupation or business. However, if there is a direct economic relationship between your possession of the asset and your occupation or business of providing personal services, the income, gain, or loss is directly related.

If you provided personal services in the United States after 1986 and, in a subsequent tax year, receive distributions from a pension or retirement that are attributable to those services while you were a non-resident alien, those distributions are directly related income to the extent that they are attributable to contributions, whether or not you are engaged in a U.S. occupation or business in the year in which you receive the distributions from a pension or retirement.

The term "fixed place of business" generally means a place, site, structure, or other similar facility through which you engage in an occupation or business. The term "scheduled scheduled transportation" means a ship or aircraft that follows a published schedule with repeated navigations or flights at regular intervals between the same points for travel or flights that begin or end in the United States. This definition applies to both scheduled air transportation and charter air transportation. If the income does not meet the two above conditions, it is not directly related and is subject to tax using the 4% rate. See Transportation Tax later in this chapter.

All U.S.-sourced gains and losses that are generated from the operation of a business in the United States are directly related to an occupation or business in the United States. For example, gains from sales in the United States of inventory of goods acquired in this country or in a foreign country are income directly related to an occupation or business. A portion of the U.S.-sourced gains and losses of a partnership that is engaged in an occupation or business in the United States is also directly related to an occupation or business in the United States.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign partnership that engages (or is treated as engaging) in an occupation or business within the United States and disposes directly or indirectly of that interest, then the gain or loss from the disposal of that interest in the partnership may affect your federal tax liability. Pursuant to section 864(c)(8), your gain or loss from the sale, exchange, or other disposition of that interest in a partnership is treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business (“directly related gain” or “directly related loss”). However, the amount of the directly related gain or loss is limited by the apportionable portion of which would have been your directly related gain or loss if the partnership had sold all of its property at fair market value on the date of disposal. Section 864(c)(8) applies to sales, exchanges, or other dispositions on or after November 27, 2017. On November 6, 2020, final regulations under section 864(c)(8) were issued for transfers that occurred on or after December 26, 2018. See section 1.864(c)(8)-1(j) of the Regulationst.

Any income from a foreign source that is equivalent to any of the types of income described above is treated as directly related to an occupation or business in the United States. For example, interest and dividend equivalents from foreign sources are treated as directly related to an occupation or business in the United States if the income is derived by a foreign person in the active conduct of a banking, financing or similar business within the United States. l

Income you receive during the tax year that is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States, after allowable deductions, is subject to the tax rates applicable to U.S. citizens and residents. You can generally receive directly related income only if you are a non-resident alien engaged in an occupation or business in the United States during the tax year. However, if you receive payments from the sale or exchange of property, the provision of services or any other transaction during the tax year in which you are not engaged in an occupation or business in the United States, but such payments would have been treated as directly related income in the year in which the transaction occurred or the services were provided, then they will be treated as directly related income in the tax year in which you received them.

The 30% rate (or lower under a treaty) applies to the gross amount of profits, profits or fixed, determineable, annual or recurring income (FDAP) from a U.S. source. Income is fixed when paid in known amounts in advance. Income is determined when there is a basis for calculating the amount to be paid. Income can be periodic if paid from time to time. It does not have to be paid annually or at regular intervals. Income can be determined or recurring even if the period of time over which payments are made increases or decreases. Items specifically included as fixed or determineable income are interest (other than original issue discount), dividends, dividend-equivalent payments (defined in Chapter 2), rents, bonuses, annuities, salaries, wages and other compensation. An alternative (substitute) dividend or interest payment received under a securities lending or sale-repurchase transaction is treated the same as amounts received on a transferred security. Other items of income, such as royalties, may also be subject to the 30% tax. Some fixed or determineable income may be exempt from U.S. tax. See Chapter 3 if you are unsure if the income is taxable.

Generally, non-resident foreigners are subject to a 30% tax on gross gambling income earned in the U.S. if that income is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business and is not treaty exempt. However, no tax is levied on non-business gambling income earned by a non-resident foreigner from playing blackjack (21), baccarat (point and bank), craps, roulette or big-6 wheel in the U.S. Net gambling income earned in the U.S. that is directly related to a U.S. occupation or business by non-resident foreigners is subject to tax at graduated rates. This income is exempt under some tax treaties. See Table 1 of the Tax Treaty Tables, available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables, for a list of tax treaties that exempt gambling gains from U.S. tax. For more information, see Publication 915.

A non-resident alien must include 85% of any Social Security benefits (and the Social Security equivalent portion of the Tier 1 railroad retirement benefit) in fixed or determineable annual or periodic income from a U.S. source. Social Security benefits include monthly retirement, survivor, and disability benefits. This income is exempt under some tax treaties. See Table 1 in the Tax Treaty Tables, available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables, for a list of treaties that allow Social Security benefits to be exempt from U.S. tax. For more information, see Publication 915.

If you are not engaged in a U.S. occupation or business and have not established a tax year for a previous period, for purposes of the 183-day rule, your tax year is the calendar year. In addition, you must file your tax return on a calendar year basis. If you were in the U.S. for less than 183 days during the tax year, capital gains (other than gains listed above) are tax-exempt unless they are directly related to a U.S. occupation or business during your tax year.

Report your gains and losses from sales or exchanges of capital assets that are not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business on Schedule NEC (Form 1040-NR). Report your gains and losses from sales or exchanges of capital assets (including real property) that are directly related to a U.S. occupation or business on a separate Schedule D (Form 1040) or Form 4797, or both.

If you have income from real property located in the United States that you own or in which you have an interest and maintain for income-producing purposes, you may elect to treat all income from that property as income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. The election applies to you for all income from real property located in the United States that is maintained for income-producing purposes and for all income from any interest in such property. This includes rental income, royalties from mines, oil or gas wells or other natural resources. It also includes gains from the sale or exchange of domestic timber, coal or iron ore with an economic interest retained. You may make this election only for real property income that is not directly related to your U.S. occupation or business. If you make the election, you may claim deductions attributable to real property income and only your net real property income is subject to tax. This election does not treat a non-resident alien who is not otherwise engaged in a U.S. occupation or business as if he or she were engaged in a U.S. occupation or business during the year.

You can revoke the election without IRS approval by filing Form 1040-X for the year in which you made the election and for subsequent years. You must file Form 1040-X within 3 years of the date of filing your return or within 2 years of when the tax was paid, whichever is later. If this time period expired for the year of the election, you cannot revoke the election for that year. However, you can revoke the election for subsequent years only if you have IRS approval. For information on how to obtain IRS approval, see section 1.871-10(d)(2) of the Regulations.

This 4% tax applies to your gross transportation income from U.S. source. This only includes transportation income that is treated as derived from sources within the U.S. if the transportation begins or ends in the U.S. For transportation income from personal services, the transportation must be between the U.S. and a U.S. territory. For personal services of a non-resident alien, this applies only to income derived from, or in connection with, an aircraft.

Under this special rule, you are subject to tax on your gross income and net gains from U.S. sources at the incremental individual rates (with allowable deductions) for the period you were a non-resident alien, unless you were subject to a higher tax under section 871 (rules normally applied to the income of a taxable non-resident alien, explained above) after taking into account any applicable tax treaty benefits. For information on how to calculate this special tax, see Expatriation Tax, below.

If you are subject to this tax for any year in the period you were a non-resident alien, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The return must be filed by the due date (including extensions) of your U.S. income tax return for the year you became a U.S. resident again. If you have already filed returns for that period, you must file amended returns. You must attach a written statement to your tax return identifying the source of all your U.S. and foreign gross income and the types of income subject to this special rule.

The expatriation tax provisions apply to U.S. citizens who have renounced their citizenship and long-term residents (LTRs) who have terminated their residence. The section below describes the expatriation rules under section 877A that apply to persons who have expatriated on or after June 17, 2008. See Expatriation After June 16, 2008, below. If you expatriated before June 17, 2008, see Expatriation After June 3, 2004, and Before June 17, 2008 in Chapter 4 of Publication 519 of 2018 and the Instructions for Form 8854 of 2018. If you renounced your citizenship or terminated your long-term residence after June 3, 2004, and before June 17, 2008, you will still be considered a U.S. citizen or U.S. resident for tax purposes until you notify the Department of State or the Department of Homeland Security (as applicable) of your expatriation and file Form 8854 with the IRS.
Your expatriation date is the date you renounce your U.S. citizenship (in the case of a former citizen) or end your long-term residence (in the case of a former U.S. resident).

You must file an initial Form 8854 in the year you relinquish your U.S. citizenship or end your long-term residence, even if you are not a covered expatriate. In addition, you must file a Form 8854 annually after you expatriate if you are a covered expatriate and you: 1. Deferred the payment of market value tax (see Deferring the payment of market value tax) below; 2. Have an eligible deferred compensation item; or 3. Have an interest in an ungranted trust.
For more information about deferring payment, see the Instructions for Form 8854.

You are deemed to have renounced your U.S. citizenship on the earlier of the following dates: 1. the date you renounced your U.S. citizenship to a U.S. diplomatic or consular official (provided that the voluntary renouncement is later confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of citizenship); 2. the date you provided the Department of State with a signed statement of your voluntary renouncement of your U.S. citizenship confirming the delivery of an expatriation certificate (provided that the voluntary renouncement is later confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of citizenship); 3. the date the Department of State issued the certificate of loss of citizenship; 4. the date a U.S. court cancelled your certificate of naturalization.

You are deemed to have ended your long-term residence on the earlier of the following dates: 1. The date you voluntarily renounced your legal permanent resident status by filing Form I-407 with the Department of Homeland Security with a U.S. immigration or consular official. 2. The date you became subject to a final administrative order that you left your legal permanent resident status (or, if the order is appealed, the date of the final court order issued in connection with such administrative order). 3. The date you became subject to a final administrative order for deportation from the U.S. under the Immigration and Nationality Act. 4. If you were a dual resident alien in the U.S. and a country with which the U.S. has a tax treaty, the date you began to be treated as a resident of that country under the provisions of the tax treaty and notified the IRS of that treatment on Forms 8833 and 8854. See Effect of Tax Treaties in chapter 1 for more information on dual resident aliens.

If you expatriate after June 16, 2008, you are treated as a covered expatriate, and the expatriation rules under section 877A apply to you if you meet any of the following conditions: 1. The average annual tax on net income for the 5 years ended prior to the date of expatriation or termination of residence is more than $201,000 if you expatriate or terminate your residence in 2024. 2. Your net worth is $2 million or more on the date of your expatriation or termination of residence. 3. You did not certify on Form 8854 that you met all U.S. federal tax obligations for the 5 years prior to the date of your expatriation or termination of residence.

If you were a U.S. citizen who expatriated after March 18, 2010, you may be eligible for certain relief procedures that provide alternative means of meeting the tax compliance process. For more information, see Relief Procedures for Certain Former Citizens.

You may qualify for the exception described above if the following conditions apply: You became a U.S. citizen at birth and a citizen of another country and, as of the date of expatriation, continue to be a citizen of, and are subject to be resident of, that other country. You have been a resident of the U.S. for no more than 10 years during the 15-year tax period ending in the tax year during which the expatriation occurs. For the purpose of determining residence in the U.S., use the substantial presence requirement described in Chapter 1.

You may qualify for the exception described above if you meet both of the following requirements: You expatriated before you were 18½ years old You have been a resident of the United States for no more than 10 tax years before the expatriation occurred For the purpose of determining residence in the United States, use the substantial presence requirement described in Chapter 1.

In the year you expatriate, you are subject to income tax on the unrealized net gain (or loss) on your property as if the property had been sold at its fair market value on the day before the expatriation date (the “market value” tax). This applies to most property interests you held on the date of renunciation of citizenship or termination of residence. But see Exceptions, below. Gains from considered sales must be taken into account for the tax year of the considered sale regardless of other Internal Revenue Code laws. Considered sales losses must be taken into account to the extent otherwise provided under Internal Revenue Code laws. However, section 1091 (relating to the denial of losses on fictitious sales of stocks and securities) does not apply. The net gain that you otherwise have to include in your income is reduced (but not less than zero) by $866,000 if you expatriate or terminate your residence in 2024.

Instead, items (1) and (3) may be subject to withholding tax. In the case of item (2), you are treated as having received the present value of your accrued profit from the day before your expatriation date. In the case of item (4), you are treated as having received a distribution of your total interest in the account on the day before your expatriation date. See Notice 2009-85 and the Instructions for Form 8854 for more information.

After you have determined your foreigner status, the source of your income, and whether and how that income is taxed in the United States, your next step is to calculate the tax. The information in this chapter is not as extensive for resident aliens as it is for non-resident aliens. Resident aliens will need to obtain publications, forms, and instructions for U.S. citizens because the information for filing returns for resident aliens is generally the same as for U.S. citizens. If you are a non-resident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year, see chapter 6 for a discussion of dual resident aliens.

Non-resident aliens may claim some of the same itemized deductions that resident aliens may claim. However, non-resident aliens may claim itemized deductions only if they have income directly related to their occupation or business in the United States. There may be limitations that affect the amount of itemized deductions you can claim on Schedule A. See Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) or Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) — Detailed Deductions in Instructions for Form 1040-NR.

Foreign residents can claim the same itemized deductions as U.S. citizens using the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040). See the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) for more information. If you do not itemize deductions, you can claim the standard deduction for your marital status for return purposes. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 1040.

You can claim certain itemized deductions if you receive income directly related to your U.S. occupation or business. You can generally only include deductions and losses that are properly allocated and prorated to income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. You cannot include deductions and/or losses that are related to tax-exempt income or income not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. However, you can deduct certain charitable donations and losses due to a casualty or theft even if they are not related to your directly related income. Use Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) to claim itemized deductions. See Instructions for Form 1040-NR.

They can claim the standard deduction, provided they do not claim itemized deductions. If you are a student or business apprentice who qualifies for benefits under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Tax Treaty and has been affected by a major (major) disaster declared as such by the federal government in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/disaster), you may elect to increase your standard deduction by the amount of your net qualifying disaster losses related to your personal use property incidental losses on your 2024 tax return. Use Worksheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024. See Form 4684 of 2024 and its instructions for more information on tax benefits for net qualifying disaster losses related to your personal use property incidental losses.

You can deduct state and local income taxes you paid on income directly related to your occupation or business in the United States. Your deduction is limited to a combined total deduction of $10,000 ($5,000 if you are married and file a separate return). If you got a refund or rebate in 2024 for taxes you paid in a previous year, do not reduce your deduction by that amount. Instead, you have to include the refund or rebate in your income if you deducted taxes in the previous year and the deduction reduced your tax. See Recoveries in Publication 525 for details on how to calculate the amount to include in your income.

You can deduct your charitable donations or gifts to qualified organizations subject to certain limits. Qualified organizations include organizations that are religious, charitable, educational, scientific or literary in nature, or that work to prevent cruelty to children or animals. Certain organizations that promote national or international sports competitions for amateur players are also qualified organizations. For more information about the deduction of charitable donations, see Charitable Donations to U.S. Organizations under Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) – Detailed Deductions in Instructions for Form 1040-NR.

Donations made directly to a foreign organization are not deductible. However, you may deduct donations made to a U.S. organization that transfers funds to a foreign charity if the U.S. organization controls the use of the funds or if the foreign organization is only an administrative branch of the U.S. organization. Under a limited number of tax treaties, you may qualify for deduction of donations made to a foreign charity. See Publication 526 for details.

You may be able to deduct casualty and theft losses on your tax return. You can only deduct a casualty or theft loss that is not a business loss if the loss is attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government. If your casualty or theft loss is attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, you can deduct your loss even if your property is not related to an occupation or business in the United States. The property can be personal use property or income-generating property not related to an occupation or business in the United States. The property must be located in the United States at the time of the casualty or theft. Theft losses can only be deducted in the year you discover the loss. Use Form 4684 and its instructions to calculate your deductible casualty or theft loss. For more information, see Publication 547.

Foreign residents generally claim tax credits and report tax payments, including withholding, using the same rules as U.S. citizens. The following items are some of the credits you can claim. 1.

You can claim a credit, subject to certain limits, for income taxes you paid to or accrued with a foreign country on income from foreign sources. You cannot claim a credit for taxes you paid or accrued on excluded income from foreign sources. To claim a credit for income taxes you paid to or accrued with a foreign country, you will generally need to file Form 1116 together with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 514.

You could take this credit if you pay someone else to care for your qualifying child under the age of 13 who you claim as a dependent of yourself, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so that you can work or seek work.For more information, see Form 2441 and Publication 503.

You may qualify for this credit if you are 65 years of age or older or if you retired with a total and permanent disability.For more information about this credit, see Publication 524 and Schedule R (Form 1040).

You may qualify for these credits if you paid qualifying education expenses for yourself, your spouse, or your dependent. There are two education credits: the opportunity tax credit for Americans and the lifetime learning credit. You cannot claim these credits if you are married and file a separate return. Use Form 8863 to calculate the credit. For more information, see Publication 970. Non-resident aliens, see Education Credits under Non-Resident Aliens, below.

You may qualify for this credit (also known as the “saver’s credit”) if you made qualifying contributions to an employer-sponsored retirement plan or IRA in 2024. Use Form 8880 and its instructions to calculate the credit. For more information on the requirements to claim the credit, see Publication 590-A.

An adopted child is always treated as a child of your own. An adopted child includes a child who was placed in your home legally for lawful adoption. If you did not have an SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for 2024 on either your original return or your amended return. If your child did not have a valid work SSN issued before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child but you may claim the other dependents credit for this child. See Credit for other dependents, below. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions to calculate the credits.

The other dependents credit is for individuals who have dependents who cannot be claimed for the child tax credit. The qualifying dependent must be a U.S. citizen or resident foreign national and have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the due date to file their 2024 return (including extensions). See Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions for more information.

You may qualify for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualifying expenses paid to adopt a qualifying child. This amount may be allowed for the adoption of a child with special needs regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839, Qualified Adoption Expenses, with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR.
You can also claim certain taxes that you paid, are deemed to have paid, or were withheld from your income, and you can also claim some of the same credits that resident aliens can claim.

If you receive income from foreign sources that is directly related to an occupation or business in the United States, you may claim a credit for any income tax you paid to or accrued with a foreign country or U.S. territory on that income. If you do not have income from foreign sources that is directly related to an occupation or business in the United States, you may not claim credits against your U.S. taxes for taxes you paid to or accrued with a foreign country or U.S. territory. You may not take any credit for taxes levied by a foreign country or U.S. territory on your income from U.S. sources if those taxes were levied only because you are a citizen or resident of the foreign country or territory. If you claim a credit for foreign tax, you will generally need to attach a Form 1116. See Publication 514 for more information.

You could take this credit if you pay someone else to care for your qualifying child under 13 years of age whom you claim as your dependent, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so that you can work or seek employment. For definitions of these terms, see Publication 503. Married non-resident aliens can claim the credit only if they elect to file a joint return with a spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident as explained under How to Make the Choice in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married persons who do not live together (see Joint Return Test in Publication 503). The amount of your child and dependent care expenses that qualifies for the credit in any tax year cannot be greater than the amount of your U.S. employment income for that tax year. Earned income generally means wages, salaries, and professional fees for personal services rendered. For more information, see Publication 503.
Additional information on the opportunity tax credit for Americans is available at IRS.gov/AOTC.
Use Form 8880 to calculate the credit.For more information, see Publication 590-A.

An adopted child is always treated as a child of your own. An adopted child includes a child who was placed in your home lawfully for lawful adoption. If you did not have an SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit on your original or amended return. If your child did not have a valid work SSN issued before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for that child, but you may claim the other dependents credit for that child.

Dependent persons who cannot claim the child tax credit may still qualify you for the other dependents credit. This is a non-refundable credit of $500 per qualifying person. The qualifying dependent must be a U.S. citizen or national or a resident foreigner. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. To claim the other dependents credit, your dependents must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the due date to file their 2024 return (including extensions). Only U.S. nationals; residents of Canada, Mexico, and South Korea; or residents of India who were students or business apprentices who qualify for the benefits of Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Tax Treaty may claim the other dependents credit.

You may qualify for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualifying expenses paid to adopt a qualifying child. This amount may be allowed for the adoption of a child with special needs regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your Form 1040-NR. Married non-resident aliens can claim the credit only if they elect to file jointly with a spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident as explained under Non-Resident Spouse Treated as Resident in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married persons who do not live together (see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly in the Instructions for Form 8839).
If you paid the alternative minimum tax in a previous year, use Form 8801 and its instructions to see if you qualify for this credit.
You can claim the tax withheld during the year as a payment against your U.S. tax. Claim it on lines 25a to 25g of your Form 1040-NR. The withheld tax reduces any tax you owe with Form 1040-NR.

Any federal tax on income withheld from your wages during the tax year while you were a non-resident alien is allowed as a payment against your U.S. income tax liability for that year. You can claim the tax on withheld income regardless of whether you had an occupation or a business in the U.S. during the year, and whether the wages (or any other income) were related to an occupation or a business in the U.S. or not.

If you had two or more employers, you may claim a credit against your U.S. income tax liability for Social Security tax withheld in excess of the required maximum. See Social Security and Medicare Taxes in chapter 8 for more information.

If you are a shareholder in a mutual fund (or other regulated investment corporation (RIC)) or real estate investment trust (REIT), you may claim a credit for your share of any taxes paid by the corporation on its undistributed long-term capital gains. You will receive the information on a Form 2439, which you will need to attach to your return.

You may claim as a payment against any withholding tax on investments and other fixed or determineable income paid to you annually or periodically (FDAP). Fixed or determineable income includes interest income, dividends, rents, and royalties that you do not claim as directly related income. Wage or salary payments may be fixed or determineable income for you, but are usually subject to withholding as discussed above. Taxes on fixed or determineable income are withheld at a rate of 30% or less under a tax treaty.

If you are a foreign partner in a partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the directly related taxable income from the partnership. The partnership will provide you with a return on Form 8805 showing the withheld tax. A partnership whose shares are listed on the stock exchange may withhold on its current distributions of directly related income. In such a case, the partnership will provide you with a return on Form 1042-S. Claim the withheld tax as a payment on line 25e or 25g of Form 1040-NR, as applicable.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. partnership or foreign partnership that engages (or is treated as engaging) in an occupation or business within the United States and you directly or indirectly dispose of that interest resulting in a gain, then, for transfers that occur after 2017, the transferee will generally withhold and pay to the IRS on your behalf a tax equal to 10% of the amount received on the sale. The rules for withholding and paying this amount are similar to those for sales of U.S. real estate interests. You will receive a Form 8288-A showing the amount withheld that you can then claim on line 25f of your Form 1040-NR as a credit against the tax due on the gain. You may be able to provide certain information to the transferee to reduce or eliminate the withholding. For example, if an Internal Revenue Code non-recognition provision applies to all of the gain made on the transfer, the transferee may not have to withhold the tax if you provide a notice describing the application of a non-recognition provision. If you are an assignee who did not withhold under section 1446(f)(4), the partnership may withhold on distributions it makes to you. On November 30, 2020, Treasury Decision 9926, available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-51IRS#TD-9926 (as corrected at page 13191 of Federal Register volume 86), contained the final regulations (section 1446(f) regulations) related to the requirement of withholding and reporting under section 1446(f) was published.

You may claim as a payment any tax withheld in respect of the disposal of a U.S. real estate interest (or income treated as derived from the disposal of a U.S. real estate interest). See Real Property Gain or Loss in chapter 4, above. The buyer will give you a statement of the amount withheld on a Form 8288-A. Claim the withheld tax as a payment on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

If you are a non-resident alien who is a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are generally taxed in the same way as resident aliens. You must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR and report all your income from sources in and outside the United States. However, you may exclude income that is mentioned in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes other than income tax returning, you will be treated as a non-resident alien. For example, you are not allowed the standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot claim for a dependent unless that person is a U.S. citizen or national. There are also limits on what deductions and credits are allowed. See Non-Resident Aliens under Deductions, Detailed Deductions, and Tax Credits and Tax Payments in this chapter.

If you are a bona fide resident of Puerto Rico all year round, you may exclude from your gross income all income from sources within Puerto Rico (other than amounts for services rendered as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies). If you report your income on a calendar year basis and have no withholding-subject wages for 2024, file your return and pay your tax by June 16, 2025. You also have to make your first estimated tax payment for 2025 by June 16, 2025. You cannot file a joint tax return or make joint estimated tax payments. However, if you are married to a U.S. citizen or resident, see Non-Resident Spouse Treated as a Resident in chapter 1. If you accrue withholding-subject wages, the deadline for filing your U.S. income tax return is April 15, 2025. You also have to make your first estimated tax payment for 2025 by April 15, 2025. For information on withholding and estimated tax, see chapter 8.

If you are a bona fide resident of American Samoa for the whole year, you may exclude from your gross income all income from sources within American Samoa (other than amounts for services rendered as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies). An employee of the American Samoa government is not considered to be an employee of the United States government or any of its agencies for purposes of the exclusion. For more information about this exclusion, see Form 4563 and Publication 570.

You must calculate your income and file a tax return based on an annual accounting period called a “tax year.” If you have not previously established a regular tax year, your tax year is the calendar year. A natural tax year consists of 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a regular tax year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December or a year of 52 or 53 weeks) and are considered a U.S. resident in any calendar year, you will be treated as a U.S. resident for any part of your tax year that corresponds to that calendar year.

Your tax amount depends on your marital status for tax purposes. Your marital status for tax purposes is important in determining whether you can take certain deductions and credits. The rules for determining your marital status for tax purposes are different for resident and non-resident aliens.

Resident foreigners can use the same filing marital statuses that are available to U.S. citizens. See the instructions for your form or Publication 501 for more information about filing marital status.

Generally, you can file as a married person filing a joint return only if both you and your spouse were U.S. citizens or U.S. resident foreigners for the entire tax year, or if you choose to be a non-resident spouse treated as a resident, as explained in chapter 1.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry before the end of 2024, you may qualify to file as a qualifying surviving spouse and use the joint return tax rates. This applies only if you could have filed a joint return with your spouse for the year in which your spouse died. For more information about marital status for the purposes of filing as a qualifying surviving spouse, see Qualifying Surviving Spouse under Marital Status for Return Purposes in the Instructions for Form 1040 of 2024.

You may qualify as a head of household if you are unmarried or if you are considered unmarried on the last day of the year and you paid more than half of the cost of maintaining a home for you and a qualifying person. You must be a resident alien for the entire tax year. You are considered unmarried for this purpose if your spouse was a non-resident alien at any time in the year and your spouse does not elect to be treated as a resident, as explained in Chapter 1 under Non-Resident Spouse Treated as a Resident.
