Married non-resident foreigners who are not married to U.S. citizens or residents generally have to use the Married Separately Filers column on the Tax Table or Tax Calculation Worksheet when determining the tax on income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business.

Married non-resident aliens are usually not allowed to use the single column of the Tax Schedule or the Tax Calculation Worksheet. However, you may be able to file as a single person if you lived separately from your spouse for the last 6 months of the year and you are a resident of Canada, Mexico, or South Korea who is married, or if you are a U.S. citizen who is married. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR to see if you qualify. “U.S. citizen” is defined later in this section. A non-resident alien is generally not allowed to file as a married person who files jointly. However, a non-resident alien who is married to a U.S. citizen or resident may elect to be treated as a resident and file a joint return on a Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information about these options, see chapter 1. If you do not elect to file jointly, file Form 1040-NR and use the column of the Tax Schedule or the Tax Calculation Worksheet for married persons who file separately.

An individual who, despite not being a U.S. citizen, owes loyalty to the United States is considered a U.S. national.[1] In addition, U.S. nationals include American Samoans (American Samoa) and Normans (Northern Mariana Islands) who have chosen to become U.S. nationals rather than U.S. citizens.[2]

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry before the end of 2024, you may qualify to file as a qualifying surviving spouse and use the joint return tax rates. For more information about marital status for the purposes of filing as a qualifying surviving spouse, see Qualifying Surviving Spouse under Marital Status for Return Purposes in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR 2024. 1040-NR 2024

You cannot file as a head of household if you are a non-resident alien at any time during the tax year. However, if you are married, your spouse may qualify as a head of household if: your spouse is a resident alien or U.S. citizen for the entire tax year; you do not elect to be treated as a resident alien; and your spouse otherwise qualifies for this marital status for tax purposes, as explained above under Resident Aliens.

A nonresident foreign estate or trust using Form 1040-NR must use the tax rates in Schedule W in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR in determining income tax on income directly related to an occupation or business in the United States.

A non-resident alien who is a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year and is working temporarily in the United States must consult Bona Fide Residents of American Samoa or Puerto Rico at the end of this chapter for information about these special rules.

You must report each item of income that is taxable under the rules in Chapters 2, 3, and 4. For resident aliens, this includes income from sources both in and outside the United States. For non-resident aliens, this includes both income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business (subject to graduated tax rates) and income from sources within the U.S. that are not directly related (subject to a flat tax rate of 30% or less under a tax treaty).

Resident and non-resident aliens may claim similar deductions on their U.S. tax returns; however, non-resident aliens may generally claim only deductions relating to income directly related to their occupation or business in the U.S.

You can claim the same deductions that are allowed to U.S. citizens if you are a resident alien throughout the tax year. Although the discussion below under Non-Resident Aliens contains some of the same general rules and guidelines that apply to you, it is specifically for non-resident aliens. You must obtain the Instructions for Form 1040 for more information on how to claim your allowable deductions.

You may claim deductions to calculate your directly related taxable income (ECTI).• Generally, you cannot claim deductions related to income that is not directly related to your activities in the United States.• With the exception of certain detailed deductions, explained below, you may claim deductions only to the extent that they are related to your directly related income.•

You can deduct all ordinary and necessary expenses of carrying on your occupation or business in the United States to the extent that they are related to income directly related to that occupation or business. For information on other business expenses, see Guide to Business Expense Resources. 2012 Tax Returns.

If you paid interest in 2024 on a qualifying student loan, you may be able to deduct up to $2,500 of the interest you paid. You can usually claim the deduction if you meet all the requirements. The deduction is claimed on line 21 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR. To calculate the deduction, see the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information, see Publication 970.

If you have income directly related to an occupation or business in the United States, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualifying business income from your qualifying occupation or business, plus 20% of your qualifying dividends from a Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT) or income (loss) from a publicly traded partnership (PTP). For more information, see Line 13a in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information on the deduction for qualified business income, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and its appendices, and the corresponding instructions for the forms and appendices.

You may deduct losses resulting from transactions you have made for profit and have not been reimbursed by insurance, etc., to the extent that they relate to income directly related to an occupation or business in the United States.

If you are an educator who qualifies in 2024, you can deduct as an adjustment to your income up to $300 of unreimbursed qualifying expenses that you paid or incurred in 2024 for certain professional development courses and for books, supplies (other than for health or physical education course items not used in the performance of sport), computer equipment (including computer software and related services), and other supplementary equipment and supplies used in the classroom. For more information, see the instructions on your tax form. Qualifying expenses include amounts paid or incurred in 2024 for personal protective equipment, disinfectants, and other supplies used to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

The removal expense deduction is only available if you are a member of the U.S. Armed Forces on active duty and, due to a military order, move due to a permanent change of position. For more information, see Publication 3, Armed Forces’ Tax Guide. If you qualify, use Form 3903 to calculate the amount to be deducted.

Don't include in income the value of removal and storage services provided by the government due to a move that is on the basis of a military order resulting from a permanent change of position. Similarly, don't include in income amounts received as a relocation allowance, temporary accommodation expenses, temporary accommodation allowance, or moving allowance. For more information, see Publication 3.

If you are self-employed, you may be able to deduct contributions to a SEP plan, SIMPLE plan, or a qualifying retirement plan that provides common law retirement benefits for you and your employees, if any. To make deductible contributions for yourself, you must have net self-employment income that is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States. See Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Business, for more information.

You must include in your income any directly related interest income you receive or are credited to your account during the year. Do not reduce it for any penalty you have to pay because you withdraw funds prematurely from a term or fixed-term deposit. However, if the interest income is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States, you can deduct on line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) the amount of the premature withdrawal penalty charged by the bank. Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

If you do not enter your SSN, ITIN, or Adopting Taxpayer Identification Number (ATIN) in the Dependents section of your tax return when required, or if you enter an incorrect number, you may be denied certain tax benefits. See Identification Number above..

If you are a resident alien, a qualifying dependent includes your qualifying child or qualifying relative. There are five requirements that must be met for a child to be your qualifying child. There are four requirements that must be met for a person to be your qualifying relative. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 1040. If you do not enter the SSN, ITIN, or ATIN in the Dependents section of your tax return when required, or if you enter an incorrect number, you may be denied certain tax benefits. See Identification Number, above.

If you are a resident of Mexico or Canada, or a U.S. national, you can claim for each of your dependents who meet certain requirements. Residents of Mexico or Canada, or U.S. nationals, must use the same rules as U.S. citizens to determine who is a dependent. See Publication 501 for these rules.

If you are a non-resident foreigner who resides in South Korea (other than a South Korean government employee), you may be able to claim your child as a qualifying dependent. In addition to using the same rules as U.S. citizens to determine who is a dependent, under the South Korean tax treaty, the child must have lived with the non-resident foreigner in the United States at some point during the tax year.
Students and business apprentices who qualify for benefits under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Tax Treaty can claim for their dependents if they meet the same rules as U.S. citizens.

You have a dual residence tax year when you have been a resident alien and a non-resident alien in the same year. Dual residence does not refer to your citizenship; it refers only to your status as a resident in the United States. When determining your tax liability on U.S. income for a dual residence tax year, different rules apply for the part of the year in which you are a U.S. resident and the part of the year in which you are a non-resident. The most common dual residence tax years are the years of arrival and departure. See Aliens with Dual Residence in chapter 1. If you are married and choose to be a non-resident spouse treated as a resident, as explained in chapter 1, the rules in this chapter do not apply to you for that year.

If you are a resident alien on the last day of your tax year and report your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by April 15 of the year following the end of your tax year (but see TIP below). If you report your income on a non-calendar year basis, file your return by April 15 of the fourth month following the end of your tax year. In either case, file your return by sending it to the address for dual resident aliens listed on the back of the Instructions for Forms 1040 and 1040-SR. If you are a non-resident alien on the last day of your tax year and report your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by April 15 of the year following the end of your tax year if you receive wages that are subject to withholding. If you report your income on a non-calendar year basis, file your return by April 15 of the fourth month following the end of your tax year. If you did not receive withholding wages and report your income on a calendar year basis, file your return by June 15 of the year following the end of your tax year. If you report your income on a non-calendar year basis, file your return by June 15 of the sixth month following the end of your tax year. In either case, mail your return to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 If you attach a payment, send your return to: Internal Revenue Service P.O. Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303 If the due date for filing the return falls on a Saturday, Sunday or official holiday, the due date is the next day that is not Saturday, Sunday or a public holiday.

You must file your tax return on the basis of an annual accounting period called the tax year. If you have not previously established a tax year, your tax year is the calendar year. A calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you previously established a regular tax year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December, or a year of 52 or 53 weeks) and are considered a U.S. resident in any calendar year, you will be treated as a U.S. resident for any part of your tax year that falls within that calendar year.

During the part of the year in which you are a resident alien, you are subject to income tax from all sources. Income from sources outside the United States is subject to tax if you receive it while you are a resident alien. Income is taxable even if it was earned while you were a non-resident alien or if you became a non-resident alien after receiving it and before the end of the year. During the part of the year in which you are a non-resident alien, you are subject to taxes on income from U.S. sources and on certain income from foreign sources that is treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. The rules for treating income from foreign sources as directly related are explained in Chapter 4 under Foreign Income. Income from sources outside the United States that is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business is not taxable if you receive it while you are a non-resident alien. Income is not taxable even if it was earned while you were a resident alien or if you became a resident alien or U.S. citizen after receiving it and before the end of the year. Income from U.S. sources is taxable, regardless of whether you receive it as a resident alien or non-resident alien, unless it is specifically exempt under the Internal Revenue Code or a provision of a tax treaty. Generally, the provisions of tax treaties apply only to the part of the year in which you were a resident alien. See Chapter 9 for more information. In determining which income is subject to tax in the United States, you must consider exemptions under U.S. tax law, as well as reduced tax rates and exemptions provided by tax treaties between the United States and certain foreign countries. For a detailed explanation of tax treaties, see Chapter 9.
The following restrictions apply if you file a tax return for a dual-residence tax year or if you are a single-residence taxpayer.
You cannot take the standard deduction allowed on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, but you can itemize any deductions allowed.
You cannot use the column in the Tax Table or the Tax Calculation Worksheet for marital status for the purposes of the head of household return.

See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR to see if you qualify. A U.S. national is a person who, despite not being a U.S. citizen, owes loyalty to the United States. U.S. nationals include residents of American Samoa and the Northern Mariana Islands who have elected to have U.S. citizenship rather than become U.S. citizens.

As a dual-resident taxpayer, you may be able to claim a dependent on your tax return. A dependent is usually a qualifying child or a qualifying relative. You may be entitled to claim additional deductions and credits if you have a qualifying dependent. See the Instructions for Form 1040 or the Instructions for Form 1040-NR for more information. If you were a U.S. national or resident of Canada or Mexico, you can claim a dependent in the same way as U.S. citizens. If you are a resident of South Korea or India, see chapter 5.

All income from your period of residence and all income directly related to an occupation or business in the United States for your period of nonresidence, after allowable deductions, is added and taxed at the rates applicable to U.S. citizens and residents. Income that is not related to an occupation or business in the United States during your period of nonresidence is subject to the flat rate of 30% or a lower rate under a treaty. You cannot claim any deductions against this income.

During the part of the year in which you are a nonresident alien, 85% of any U.S. Social Security benefits (and the equivalent part of Tier 1 rail pension benefits) you receive are subject to the flat 30% tax, unless exempt or subject to a lower rate under a treaty. (See 30% Tax in Chapter 4.) During the part of the year in which you are a resident alien, part of the Social Security benefits and part of the equivalent Tier 1 rail pension benefits will be taxed at graduated rates if your modified adjusted gross income plus half of these benefits is more than a certain base amount. Use the Social Security Benefits Worksheet in the Instructions for Form 1040 to help you calculate the taxable part of your U.S. Social Security benefits and equivalent Tier 1 rail pension benefits for the part of the year in which you were a resident alien. If you received U.S. Social Security benefits while you were a nonresident alien, the SSA will send you Form SSA-1042S, which shows your combined benefits for the entire year and the amount of tax withheld. You will not receive separate reports for benefits received during your periods of residence and nonresidence in the United States. Therefore, it is important that you keep proper documentation of those amounts. You will need this information to complete your return correctly and calculate your tax liability. If you received rail pension benefits while you were a nonresident alien, the U.S. Railway Retirement Board (RRB) will send you Form RRB-1042S, Statement for Nonresident Alien Recipients of Payments by the Railroad Retirement Board, and/or Form RRB-1099-R, Annuities or Pensions by the Railroad Retirement Board.

As a dual resident alien, you can generally claim tax credits using the same rules that apply to resident aliens. There are certain restrictions that may apply. These restrictions are explained here, along with a brief explanation of the credits that individuals usually claim. You cannot claim education credits, EIC, or the elderly or disabled credit, unless you are married and choose to be treated as a resident throughout 2024 by filing a joint return with your spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident, as explained in Chapter 1.

If you have paid or are responsible for paying income tax to a foreign country on income from foreign sources, you may be able to claim a foreign tax credit. If you claim the foreign tax credit, you usually have to file Form 1116 with your income tax return. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 1116 and Publication 514.

You may qualify for this credit if you pay someone else to care for your qualifying child under 13 who you claim as a dependent, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so that you can work or seek employment. Dual-resident foreigners who are married can claim the credit only if they elect to file a joint return, as explained in chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married persons living separately. The amount of your child and dependent care expenses that qualify for the credit in any tax year cannot be greater than your earned income for that tax year. For more information, see Publication 503 and Form 2441.
Use Form 8880 to calculate the credit.For more information, see Publication 590-A.

An adopted child is always treated as a child of your own. An adopted child includes a child who was placed in your home legally for lawful adoption. If you did not have a SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for 2024 on your original or amended return. If your child did not have a valid work SSN issued before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child, but you may be able to claim the other dependents credit for this child. See Credit for other dependents below. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions to calculate the credits.

The Other Dependent Credit is for individuals who have dependents who cannot be claimed for the child tax credit. The qualifying dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national or U.S. resident foreigner and must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued on or before the due date to file their 2024 return (including extensions).

You may qualify for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualifying expenses paid to adopt a qualifying child. This amount may be allowed for the adoption of a child with special needs regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with the U.S. personal income tax return you file. Dual-resident foreigners who are married can only claim the credit if they elect the status of a non-resident spouse treated as a resident, as explained in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married persons living separately (see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly in the Instructions for Form 8839).

You may claim as payments against your U.S. income tax liability certain taxes that you paid, are deemed to have paid, or were withheld from your income, including: Withholding tax on wages earned in the United States, Taxes withheld at source on various items of income from U.S. sources other than wages, Estimated tax paid on Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES (NR), and Tax paid on Form 1040-C upon leaving the United States.
The U.S. income tax return you have to file as a dual resident alien depends on whether you are a resident alien or a non-resident alien at the end of the tax year.

You must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR if you are a dual-resident taxpayer who becomes a resident during the year and is a U.S. resident on the last day of the tax year. Enter “Dual-Status Return” at the top of the return. Attach a written statement to your tax return showing your income for the part of the year in which you are not a resident. You can use Form 1040-NR as the written statement, but be sure to enter “Dual-Status Statement” at the top of the page.

You must file Form 1040-NR if you are a dual-resident taxpayer who relinquishes your U.S. residence during the year and is not a U.S. resident on the last day of the tax year. Enter “Dual-Status Return” at the top of the return. Attach a written statement to your tax return showing your income for the part of the year in which you are a resident. You can use Form 1040 or 1040-SR for purposes of this written statement, but be sure to enter “Dual-Status Statement” at the top of the page. If you expatriated or ended your residence in 2024, you may have to file an expatriation return (Form 8854) with your tax return. For more information, see Expatriation Tax in chapter 4.

Any written statement you file must include your name, address, and TIN. You do not need to sign a separate written statement or annex accompanying your statement because your signature on the statement also applies to the supporting written statements and annexes. i

You can obtain an automatic 6-month extension to file your tax return (October 15 for calendar year taxpayers) if, by the filing deadline, you file Form 4868. For details, see Form 4868. An automatic 6-month extension to file your tax return does not extend the deadline to pay the tax. If you do not pay the amount due by the original filing deadline, you will owe interest on the amount of unpaid tax and may have to pay fines. An automatic extension of the deadline to file is allowed until June 15 if your main place of business and home in which you live is outside the United States and Puerto Rico by April 15. If you need more time at the end of the 2-month period, you may receive an additional 4-month extension if you file Form 4868 by June 15. In addition to the 2-month extension, out-of-country taxpayers (as defined in the Instructions for Form 4868) may request an additional discretionary 2-month extension of time to file their returns (December 15 for calendar year taxpayers). You will not receive any notice from the IRS unless your application is denied for non-time filing. The additional discretionary 2-month extension is not available for taxpayers who have an approved extension of time to file on Form 2350, Application for Extension to File the U.S. Personal Income Tax Return (for calendar year taxpayers).

You also have to file a return if you want to: Claim a refund of tax over-withheld or overpaid; or Claim the benefit of any deductions or credits. For example, if you do not have U.S. business activities, but have real estate income that you chose (opted) to treat as directly related income (explained in chapter 4), you must file a timely, true and accurate return to take any permitted deductions against that income. For more information about what is a timely return, visit When to File to Claim Deductions and Credits under When to File the Return, below.

Even if you have left the United States and filed Form 1040-C on departure, you still have to file an annual U.S. personal income tax return. If you are married and both you and your spouse are required to file a return, each of you must file a separate return. to

If a foreign person wholly owns a disregarded entity (DE), the domestic DE is considered a domestic corporation separate from its owner (the foreign person) to meet the limited requirements of section 6038A that apply to 25% of domestic corporations owned by foreigners. A foreign-owned domestic DE must file a Form 1120 with attached Form 5472 by the filing deadline (including extensions). The only information required for the Form 1120 to be considered complete is the name and address of the foreign-owned domestic DE and items B and E of Part 1. A foreign-owned domestic DE may have had a tax requirement prior to 2017 if it had a U.S. occupation or business or other activity that otherwise had a tax requirement. See the Instructions for Form 5472 for additional information and coordination with the return of Form 5472 by the domestic DE. Also note that because the domestic DE is generally a transparent entity, the foreign person will include (or continue to include) any of the tax items that are subject to reporting on Form 1040-NR. A DE (foreign or domestic) may also have tax requirements related to wage and goods of use taxes. See sections 301.7701-2(c)(2)(iv) and (v) of the Regulations.

If you are an employee and accrued wages subject to U.S. federal withholding tax, you will usually file your return by the 15th day of the fourth month after the end of your calendar year. For the calendar year 2024, file your return by April 15, 2025. If you are not an employee who accrued wages subject to U.S. federal withholding tax, you must file your return by the 15th day of the sixth month after the end of your calendar year. For the calendar year 2024, file your return by June 16, 2025.

If you are unable to file your return by the deadline, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing options explained in the Instructions for Form 4868. For the calendar year 2024, the deadline will be extended to October 15, 2025. If your original deadline is June 16, 2025, this will extend your deadline to December 15, 2025. You must file the extension request before the regular return deadline. An automatic 6-month extension to file your tax return does not extend the time to pay tax. If you do not pay the amount due by the original return deadline, you will owe interest on the amount of unpaid tax and may have to pay fines. See Form 4868 for more information.

The allocation of the following credits is not affected for this time requirement: Tax withheld credit. Excise duty credit on certain uses of gasoline and special fuels. Tax credit paid by a mutual fund (or other RIC) or REIT on undistributed long-term capital gains.

If your activities in the United States were limited and you do not believe you had any gross income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business during the year, you can file a protection return (Form 1040-NR) for the deadline explained above. By filing a protection return, you protect your right to receive the benefit of deductions and credits in the event that some or all of your income is subsequently determined to be directly related. You are not required to report any directly related income or any deductions on the protection return, but you must provide the reason for filing the return. If you believe some of your activities resulted in directly related income, file your return to report that income and related deductions before the usual deadline. To protect your right to claim deductions or credits from other activities, attach a written statement to that return explaining that you want to protect your right to claim deductions and credits if the other activities are subsequently determined to have produced directly related income. You can follow the same procedure if you believe you have no tax liability in the United States due to a U.S. tax treaty. Be sure to also complete Schedule OI, Item L (Form 1040-NR).

The IRS may waive the return deadline if you establish that, based on the facts and circumstances, you acted reasonably and in good faith by not filing a federal income tax return (including a protection return) and you cooperate with the IRS in determining your U.S. income tax liability for the tax year for which you failed to file a return.

If you are not attaching a payment, send Form 1040-NR to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 If you are attaching a payment, send your return to: Internal Revenue Service P.O. Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303

Report all income from U.S. sources, as well as income from other sources, on your return. For more information on filing returns from the U.S. Virgin Islands, contact the U.S. Virgin Islands Internal Revenue Office. If you are a bona fide U.S. Virgin Islands resident for your entire tax year and work temporarily in the U.S., you must pay your U.S. Virgin Islands income tax and file your federal income tax returns at the following address: Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802. Chapter 8 explains the U.S. wages of U.S. Virgin Islands residents.

If you are a bona fide resident of Guam or the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) for the entire tax year, you must file your return to, and pay any taxes due to, Guam or the CNMI. Report all income, including income from U.S. sources, on your return. You do not need to file a separate U.S. income tax return. Bona fide residents of Guam must file their Guam tax returns at the following address: Department of Revenue and Taxation Government of Guam P.O. Box 23607 Barrigada, GU 96921. If you find changes in your income, deductions, or credits after you mail your return, file Form 1040-X, Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return. Also use Form 1040-X if you were supposed to file Form 1040 or 1040-SR instead of Form 1040-NR or vice versa. Generally, an amended return to claim a refund must be filed within 3 years of the date you filed your original return or within 2 years of the time the tax was paid, whichever is later. A return filed before the deadline is deemed to have been filed on the deadline.

A transfer of funds through normal banking procedures that does not involve the physical transport of the currency or monetary instruments is not required to be reported.

Civil and criminal fines are provided for failure to report, reporting with material omissions or misstatements, or reporting false or fraudulently, and the full amount of currency or monetary instrument may be subject to seizure and confiscation.

You must file Form 8938 if the total value of those assets exceeds an applicable threshold (the “filing threshold”). The filing threshold varies depending on whether you live in the United States, are married, or file a joint federal income tax return with your spouse. Ownership of specified financial assets includes any financial account held by a foreign financial institution and, to the extent held for investment, any shares, securities, or other interest in a foreign entity and any financial instrument or contract with a non-U.S. issuer or counterparty. You may be liable to fines if you are required to file Form 8938 and fail to do so, or if you have a tax understatement due to any transaction involving an undisclosed foreign financial asset. For more information on filing Form 8939, see the Instructions for Form 8938.

If you fail to file your return and pay your taxes by the deadline, you may have to pay a fine. You may also have to pay a fine if you report significantly less taxes than you are due, if you file a frivolous (unfounded) tax document, or if you do not provide your TIN. If you provide fraudulent information on your return, you may have to pay a fine for civil fraud.

If you fail to file your return by the deadline (including extensions), you may have to pay a penalty for failure to file. The penalty is based on the tax that has not been paid by the deadline (excluding extensions). The penalty is usually 5% for each month or part of the month a return is overdue, but not more than 25%.

If an item on your return is attributable to a tax haven, there is no reduction for adequate disclosure; however, there is a reduction for a substantial authority position, but only if you reasonably believed that the tax treatment you chose was, more likely than not, the appropriate treatment.

To properly disclose facts relevant to the tax treatment you give to an item, use Form 8275. You must have a reasonable basis for treating that item the way you did. In cases of only substantially insufficient tax returns, items that meet the requirements of Revenue Procedure 2024-44, available at IRS.gov/irb/2024-52_IRB#REV-PROC-2024-44 (or the successor), are considered to be properly disclosed on your return. Revenue Procedure 2024-44 does not take into account the effect of changes in tax law for tax years beginning after December 31, 2024. If a line referred to in this revenue procedure is affected by such change and requires additional reporting, a taxpayer may be required to file Form 8275 or Form 8275-R, Regulation Disclosure Statement, for the applicable year as if the corporation filed a Form 8275 or Form 8275-R with respect to the tax position. However, the filing of a Form 8275 or Form 8275-R will not be treated as if the corporation filed a Form 1120, Uncertain Tax Position Statement. Use Form 8275-R to disclose items or positions that are contrary to the regulations.
For more information about undisclosed foreign financial assets, see section 6662(j) or the Instructions for Form 8938.

You will not have to pay a fine if you can prove a reasonable cause for the way you handled an item. You will also have to prove that you acted in good faith. This does not apply to a transaction that lacks economic substance.

You may have to pay a penalty if you make an incorrect claim for a refund or credit. The penalty is 20% of the amount rejected in the claim unless you can show a reasonable basis for the treatment you gave to an item. However, reasonable cause does not apply to an amount that has been rejected because it is economically unfounded. This penalty will not be calculated on any part of the amount rejected in the claim for the earned income credit or on which penalties for inaccuracy or fraud are charged.

You may have to pay a $5,000 fine if you file a frivolous tax return or other frivolous documents. A frivolous tax return is a return that does not include enough information to calculate the correct taxes or that contains information that clearly shows that the taxes you filed are materially incorrect. For more information about frivolous returns and other frivolous documents and a list of positions that are considered frivolous, see Notice 2010-33, available on page 609 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2010-17, at IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (or the most current one). You will have to pay the fine if you filed this type of return or document based on a frivolous position or a desire to delay or interfere with the administration of federal tax laws. This includes altering or crossing out the preprinted text that appears above the space where you sign. This fine is in addition to any other fines imposed by law.
If there is an underpayment of tax on your return due to fraud, a penalty of 75% of the underpayment for fraud will be added to the taxes due.

If you fail to include your Social Security Number (SSN) or IRS Personal Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) or another person’s SSN or ITIN as required on a tax return, written statement, or other document, you are subject to a $50 fine for each instance of failure. You are also subject to a $50 fine if you fail to give your SSN or ITIN to another person when required on a tax return, written statement, or other document. For example, if you have a bank account that accrues interest, you must give your SSN or ITIN to the bank. That number must appear on Form 1099-INT or other report that the bank sends to you. If you fail to give your SSN or ITIN to the bank, you are subject to a $50 fine. You may also be subject to “additional” income tax withholding. You will not have to pay the fine if you can prove that the failure was due to reasonable cause and not intentional negligence.
If your failure to file was due to fraud, your penalty is 15% for each month or part of the month that you are late with filing, up to a maximum of 75%.
If you file your return more than 60 days after the deadline or the deadline after an extension, the minimum penalty is $510 or 100% of the unpaid tax, whichever is less.
You will not have to pay the fine if you can prove that you failed to comply with the requirement to file your return on time for a reasonable cause and not by wilful negligence.

You will have to pay a default penalty of half (½) of 1% (i.e. 0.005) of the unpaid tax for each month or part of the month after the tax deadline. The penalty does not apply during the 6-month automatic extension period to file if you paid at least 90% of your tax due on or before the tax deadline and pay the remaining balance when you file. The monthly default penalty rate is half the regular rate, 1/4% (0.0025 instead of ½% (0.005)), if a instalment payment plan is in place for that month. You must have filed your return by the deadline (including extensions) to qualify for the reduced penalty. If you are issued a notice of intent to garnish, the fee will increase by 1% at the beginning of the first month from at least 10 days after the day the notice is issued. If an immediate payment notice and claim is issued, the rate will increase by 1% at the beginning of the first month from the day after the notice and payment claim is issued. The penalty cannot be more than 25% of your tax owed. You will not have to pay the penalty if you can show that you had a reasonable cause not to pay your taxes on time.

If both the filing penalty and the tax penalty (explained above) are due in any month, the 5% (or 15%) of the filing penalty will be reduced by the tax penalty. However, if you file more than 60 days after the deadline or the deadline after an extension, the minimum penalty is $510 or 100% of the unpaid tax, whichever is less. If you file your return more than 60 days after the deadline or the deadline after an extension, the minimum penalty is $510 or 100% of the unpaid tax, whichever is less.

The fine is 20% of the insufficient payment. The fine is 40% of any portion of the insufficient payment that is attributed to an undisclosed transaction lacking economic substance or an undisclosed transaction of a foreign financial asset. This fine shall not be imposed on any portion of an insufficient payment on which the fraud fine is imposed, as explained below.

The term “negligence” includes a failure to make a reasonable attempt to comply with tax law or to exercise common and reasonable care in preparing a return. Negligence also includes a failure to maintain proper records and documentation. You will not have to pay a penalty for negligence if you have a reasonable basis for defending the position you took or if you can demonstrate a reasonable cause and that you acted in good faith. The term “omission” includes any omission that is negligent, irresponsible (imprudent) or intentional.

You can avoid a fine for disregarding rules or regulations if you properly disclose a reasonably grounded position on your return. See Disclosure Statement, below. This exception does not apply to anything that can be attributed to a tax haven. It also does not apply if you fail to maintain proper records and documentation or if you do not properly corroborate items.

You may be subject to criminal prosecution (sued) for actions such as: 1. tax evasion; 2. intentional failure to file your return, provide information or pay taxes due; 3. fraud and false declaration; or 4. preparation and filing of fraudulent returns.

Assistance benefits related to extended disasters. Qualified disaster losses can be claimed on Form 4684, Casualties and Thefts. For more information, see Qualified disaster loss, below. Qualified wildfire assistance payments. Certain assistance payments received between 2020 and 2025 following an uncontrollable wildfire disaster are not taxable. For more information, see Qualified wildfire assistance payments, below. Assistance payments for the East Palestine train derailment. Certain assistance payments for the East Palestine, Ohio, train derailment on February 3, 2023 are not taxable. For more information, see Assistance payments for the East Palestine train derailment, below.

Limit on casualty losses or theft of personal use property. For the 2018 to 2025 tax years, if you are an individual, casualty losses or theft of personal use property that are not related to an occupation or business or a transaction for profit are deductible only if the loss is attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government.

This publication explains the tax treatment of casualty, theft, and loss of monetary deposits. A casualty occurs when your property is damaged by a disaster, such as a storm, fire, car accident, or other similar event. A theft occurs when someone steals your property. Loss of monetary deposits occurs when your bank declares insolvent or bankrupt (bankruptcy). This publication covers the following topics: Definitions of casualty, theft, and loss of monetary deposits. How to calculate the amount of your loss or gain. How insurance and other refunds you receive are tax treated. Deduction limits. How and when to report a casualty or theft. Special rules for losses in disaster areas.
For additional information on which form to use, see How to Report Profits and Losses below.

The three types of loss refer to a federally declared disaster, but the requirements are different for each type of loss. A “federally declared disaster” is one that the President of the United States has determined to qualify for federal assistance under the Stafford Act. A federally declared disaster includes (a) a declaration of a major disaster or (b) a declaration of an emergency under the Stafford Act.

A federal casualty loss of an individual is a casualty loss or theft of personal property that is attributable to a federally declared disaster. The loss must occur in a state that has received a federal disaster declaration. You are eligible to claim a casualty deduction if you suffered a federal casualty loss. If you suffered a casualty loss or theft of personal property that is not attributable to a federally declared disaster, it is not a federal casualty loss and you cannot claim a casualty deduction unless you qualify for the exception. Theft losses incurred in a transaction for profit may still be deductible. See the Caution paragraph under Deductible Losses below.

A disaster loss is a loss that is attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government and that occurs in an area that qualifies for assistance under a presidential declaration. The disaster loss must occur in a county that qualifies for public or individual assistance (or both). Disaster losses are not limited to an individual’s personal use property and can be claimed for an individual’s business or income-generating property and by corporations, S corporations and partnerships. If you suffered a disaster loss, you are eligible to claim a casualty deduction and you can elect to claim the loss in the previous tax year.

A qualifying disaster loss of an individual includes a casualty loss or theft of personal use property that is attributable to: A major (major) disaster declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act in 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; California wildfires in 2017 and January 2018; A major disaster declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act before February 19, 2020 for a disaster that occurred in 2018 or during 2019 but before December 21, 2019, and that did not continue after January 19, 2020 (except for those losses attributable to California wildfires in January 2018 (which have already received tax relief)); and A major disaster declared by the President during the period between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025 (inclusive); and a period of incident that began on or after December 28, 2019 and on or before December 12, 2024 and did not end after January 11, 2025.

For tax years 2018 to 2025, casualty losses of personal use property sustained by an individual are deductible only if they are attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government (federal casualty loss). Personal use property is any other than commercial or income-generating property. If the event in which you suffered a personal casualty loss (not attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government) occurred before January 1, 2018, but you did not sustain the casualty loss until January 1, 2018, or after that, the casualty loss is not deductible. See When to Report Gains and Losses, below, for more information about when a loss is sustained.

A casualty loss is not deductible, even to the extent that such loss does not exceed your casualty gains of personal use property, if the damage or destruction has been caused by: The accidental breakage of items such as glasses or fine tableware under normal conditions. A family pet (as explained below). A fire, if you deliberately initiate it or pay someone to initiate it. A motor vehicle accident, if it is caused by your negligence or deliberate act. This also applies if the act or negligence of another person acting on your behalf causes the accident. Progressive deterioration (as explained below). However, see Special Procedure for Corrosive Drywall Damage (Corrosive Drywall Damage) below.
Property loss due to damage caused by a family pet is not deductible as a casualty loss unless the requirements set out above under casualty are met.

Loss of property due to progressive deterioration is not deductible as a casualty. This is because the damage occurs as a result of a continuously operating cause or normal process, rather than a sudden event. Some examples of damage caused by progressive deterioration are: The continuous weakening of a building due to normal wind and weather conditions. The deterioration and damage caused to a burning water heater. However, rust and water damage to carpets and curtains from the burning of the heater is considered a casualty. Most drought property losses. For a drought-related loss to be deductible, it generally has to be incurred in the course of a trade or business or a transaction in which you are involved for profit. Termite or moth damage. Damage or destruction of trees, shrubs or other plants caused by fungi, diseases, insects, worms or similar pests. However, if sudden destruction occurs due to an unexpected or unusual infestation of beetles or other insects, it may result in a casualty loss.

Because casualty losses claimed under this special procedure are not attributable to a federally declared disaster, you can only deduct them to the extent that they do not exceed your casualty gains from personal use property. If you suffered property losses due to the effects of certain plasterboard imported and installed in homes between 2001 and 2009, you can deduct the costs of repairing damage to your home and appliances caused by corrosive plasterboard under this special procedure. Under this procedure, repair costs are considered casualty losses in the year you pay them. For example, repair costs paid in 2024 are deductible on your 2024 tax return and repair costs paid in 2023 are deductible on your 2023 tax return.

Individuals must report losses on income-generating property on Schedule A (Form 1040). Gains on business property and income-generating property are added to losses on business property and the net gain or loss is reported on Form 4797. On the other hand, if you are not required to file Form 4797, only enter the net gain or loss on the tax return on the line indicated for amounts from Form 4797 (for individuals filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR, this would be on line 4 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040)). Next to that line write “Form 4684.”

If the losses on business and income-generating property turn out to be greater than the gains on this type of property, add the losses on business property to the total gains on business and income-generating property. Report the net loss or gain as ordinary loss or gain on Form 4797. Alternatively, if you are not required to file Form 4797, only enter the net loss or gain on the tax return on the line indicated for amounts from Form 4797 (for individuals filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR, this would be on line 4 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040)). Next to that line write “Form 4684” (Form 4684). Individuals deduct on Schedule A (Form 1040) any loss of income-generating property. Partnerships and S-type corporations should see Form 4684 to find out where to report these gains and losses. If the losses on business and income-generating property are less than or equal to the gains on this type of property, report the net amount on Form 4797. You may also have to report the gain on Schedule D (Form 1040); this will depend on whether you have other transactions. Partnerships and S-type corporations should see Form 4684 to find out where to report these gains and losses.

If you have a casualty or theft loss, you must subtract from the property base any other insurance or reimbursements you receive and other deductible losses. The resulting amount will be the adjusted property base. If you make any of the adjustments to the base listed above, the amounts you spend on repairs to restore the property to its pre-casualty condition increase your adjusted base. Don't increase the property base with any qualifying disaster mitigation payments (explained above in the section Losses in Disaster Areas). If the casualty or theft deduction increases your deductions for that year to exceed your annual income, you may have a net operating loss (NOL). Generally, you can use a net operating loss to reduce your tax in a later year. You do not have to have a business to have a net operating loss due to a casualty or theft. The safest and easiest way to receive a tax refund is to combine e-filing with a direct deposit of your refund, which transfers your refund securely and electronically directly to your bank account. Using direct deposit also prevents your check from being lost, stolen, destroyed or returned to the IRS for non-delivery. Eight out of 10 taxpayers use direct deposit to receive their refunds. Tax-related identity theft occurs when someone steals your personal information to commit tax fraud. Your taxes may be affected if your Social Security Number (SSN) is used to file a fraudulent tax return or to claim a refund or credit. ה IRS does not initiate communications with taxpayers through email, text messages (including shortened links), phone calls or social media to ask for or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, banks or other financial accounts. 访 IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS's Identity Theft Information Center online, for information on identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If you have lost or stolen your SSN or suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what steps to take. Get a Personal Identity Protection Number (PIPN). PIPNs are six-digit numbers assigned to taxpayers to help prevent the misuse of your SSN in fraudulent tax returns. When you have an IPPIN, it prevents someone else from filing a tax return with your SSN.

U.S. tax payments must be made to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Digital assets are not accepted. Go to IRS.gov/Payments for information on how to make a payment using any of the following options: IRS Direct Pay: Individuals can pay their tax bills or make estimated tax payments directly from their savings or checking accounts. Use of IRS Direct Pay is free; there are no fees for using it. Debit card, credit card or digital wallet: Choose an approved processor to pay online or by phone. Electronic Funds Withdrawal: Schedule a payment when filing your federal tax return using tax preparation software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS): This is the best option for businesses. Requires registration with the EFTPS. Check or money order: Send your payment to the address listed in the notification or letter sent to you or in the instructions on the tax form you filed. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at a participating business. Same-day payment via electronic transfer: You can make a payment on the same day via electronic transfer from your financial institution. Check with your financial institution regarding availability, timing and cost.
