Taking money or property by fraud or misrepresentation constitutes theft if it is an illegal act under state or local laws.

For the 2018 to 2025 tax years, casualty losses of personal use property sustained by an individual are deductible only if they are attributable to a federally declared disaster (federal casualty loss). An exception to the rule limiting the deduction of casualty or theft losses of personal use property to federal casualty losses applies if you have casualty gains of personal use property. If so, you may deduct your casualty losses of personal use property not attributable to a federally declared disaster to the extent that they do not exceed your casualty gains of personal use property.

You cannot deduct as a theft loss the decrease in the value of shares you acquired in the open market for investment purposes if the decrease is caused by the disclosure of accounting fraud or other unlawful conduct by officers or directors of the entity that issued the shares. However, you may be able to deduct it as a capital loss on Schedule D (Form 1040) when you sell or exchange the shares or if the shares lose all of their value. to For more information about selling shares, worthless shares, and capital losses, see Chapter 4 of Publication 550.~

The mere disappearance of money or property does not constitute theft. However, an accidental loss or disappearance of property may be considered a casualty if it is the result of an identifiable event that occurs suddenly, unexpectedly, or unusually. The sudden, unexpected, and unusual events are defined in the section above titled casualty.
To deduct a casualty or theft loss, you must be able to prove that the casualty or theft occurred and you must be able to prove the amount you declare as a deduction as explained below.

If there is a loss due to a fortuitous event, you must be able to prove all of the following: that you owned the property or, if you rented it from someone else, were contractually liable to the owner for the damage. the type of fortuitous event (car accident, fire, storm, etc.) and the date it occurred. that the loss occurred as a direct result of the fortuitous event. that there is a claim for reimbursement with a reasonable expectation of receiving it. and that the loss occurred as a direct result of the fortuitous event.
For personal property, apply the deduction limits explained below to calculate the amount of loss you can deduct.

If you receive any insurance payment or other refund, you must subtract the amount of the refund when calculating the loss. The portion that is reimbursed to you is not a casualty or theft loss. If there is a claim for refund with a reasonable expectation of recovery in the year of the casualty, the loss is not sustained until you know with reasonable certainty that you will receive such refund. If you expect a partial or full refund of the loss, you must subtract the amount of the expected refund when calculating the loss. You must reduce the loss even if you do not receive the payment until a later tax year. See the section titled Refund Received After Deduction of a Loss below.

If your property is insured, you must submit a claim for the loss to the insurance company in a timely manner. If you do not submit a claim to the insurance company, you cannot deduct the entire loss that you have not recovered as a casualty or theft loss and can only deduct the part of the loss that is not covered by your insurance policy. The part of the loss that is not usually covered by insurance (e.g. a deductible) is not subject to this rule.
The most common type of refund is insurance payment for stolen or damaged property. Other types of refunds are explained below. See also the Instructions for Form 4684.

If you receive money from your employer's emergency fund in the event of a disaster and you need to use that money to rehabilitate or replace property on which you declare a casualty loss deduction, you must take that amount into account when calculating the casualty loss deduction.• Consider only the amount you used to replace the destroyed or damaged property.

If you receive tax-excluded cash gifts as a victim of a disaster and there are no limits on how you can use the money, do not reduce your casualty loss with this type of gift, even if you use the money to pay for repairs to property damaged in the disaster.

Do not reduce your casualty loss with insurance payments you received to cover living expenses in any of the following situations: If you lose use of your primary home due to a casualty If government authorities do not allow you access to your primary home because of a casualty or threat of a casualty and If you lose use of your primary home due to a casualty and if government authorities do not allow you access to your primary home because of a casualty or threat of a casualty.

The taxable portion of the insurance payment is included as income in the year in which you return to use your primary home or, if later, the year in which you receive the taxable portion of the insurance payment.

If you have a federal loan that has been cancelled (forgiven), see Cancelled Federal Loan, below, under Losses in Disaster Areas. If you have a federal loan that has been cancelled (forgiven), see Cancelled Federal Loan, below, under Losses in Disaster Areas. If you have a federal loan that has been cancelled, see Cancelled Federal Loan, below, under Losses in Disaster Areas.

If you calculated your casualty loss or theft loss using the expected refund amount, you may need to adjust your tax return for the tax year in which you actually receive your refund. This section explains the adjustments you may need to make. If you paid any amount to repair damage to a personal use residence with deteriorated concrete foundations and claimed a deduction on your original or amended income tax return and payments were made to you (or on your behalf to contractors) by the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC), you must include some or all of the payments in your gross income. See Announcement 2020-5, page 796 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2020-19, available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-19IRB#ANN-2020-5, for more information.

If you subsequently receive a refund that is more than you expected after claiming a deduction for the loss, you may have to include the amount of the additional refund in your income for the year in which you received it. However, if any part of the original deduction did not reduce your tax for the previous year, do not include that part of the refund amount in your income. Don't recalculate your tax for the year in which you claimed the deduction. To find out what additional refund amount you must include in your income, see Recoveries in Publication 525.
If you later receive a refund for the exact amount you expected to receive, you don't have to include any amount in your income and you can't deduct any additional loss.

There are two ways to deduct a loss of inventory due to a casualty or theft, including items you have for sale to customers. One way is to deduct the loss through the increase in the cost of goods sold, properly reporting the opening and closing inventory. Don’t rereport this loss as a casualty or theft loss. If you take the loss through the increase in the cost of goods sold, include any insurance or other refunds you receive for that loss in your gross revenue. The other way is to deduct the loss separately. If you do this, remove the inventory items that are affected from the cost of goods sold by making a decrease adjustment to the opening inventory or purchases. Reduce the loss by the refund you receive. Don’t include the refund in your gross revenue. If you don’t receive the refund at year-end, you cannot claim a loss as long as you have a reasonable expectation of recovering such amount of the loss.

If you are responsible for casualty damage to a property you rent, your loss is the amount you have to pay to repair the property minus any insurance or other reimbursement you receive or expect to receive.

If a single casualty or theft affects more than one item of property, you usually have to calculate the loss of each item separately, then add up the losses to determine the total amount of loss from that casualty or theft.

The fair market value (FMV) is the price at which you could sell your assets to a willing buyer when neither of you has to sell or buy and both know all the relevant facts.η The decrease in the fair market value used to calculate the amount of the casualty or theft loss is the difference between the fair market value of the assets immediately before and immediately after the casualty or theft occurred.η

10. Recovered Stolen Property is property that was stolen from you and then returned to you. If you recover property after you have included a theft loss deduction, you have to recalculate the loss using the lesser of the adjusted basis of the property (which is explained below) or the decrease in fair market value from the time immediately before it was stolen to the time it was recovered. Use this amount to recalculate the total loss for the year in which the loss was deducted. If the amount of the recalculated loss is less than the loss you deducted, you usually have to report the difference as income in the year in which you recovered it. But report the difference only up to the amount of the loss that reduced your taxes. For more information about the amount you must report, see Recoveries in Publication 525.

To determine the decrease in fair market value due to a casualty or theft, you usually need a competent (reliable) appraisal. However, other measures may also be used to establish certain decreases. See the topics Appraisals, Cleaning and Repair Costs, and Special Procedure – Safe Harbor Methods for Determining Losses from Theft or Casualty below.

You may use an appraisal used to obtain a federal government loan (or a federal loan guarantee) as a result of a federally declared disaster to determine the amount of your loss per disaster. For more information about disasters, see the section titled Losses in Disaster Areas below..

The cost of repairing damaged property is not part of the casualty loss. Neither is the cost of cleaning after a casualty. But you can use the cost of cleaning or making repairs after a casualty as a measure of the decrease in fair market value if all of the following conditions are met: The repairs are in fact made. The repairs are necessary to restore the property to its pre-casualty condition. The amount spent on repairs is not excessive. The repairs are made only to repair the damage. The value of the property after repairs are made is not, due to the repairs, greater than the value of the property before the casualty occurred.

The cost of restoring gardens to their original condition after a fortuitous event may indicate a decrease in fair market value. You may be able to measure the loss by what you spend on the following activities: Removing destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs, less any residual value you received for that item. Pruning and taking other steps to preserve damaged trees and shrubs. Replanting, if necessary, to restore the property to its approximate value before the fortuitous event occurred.

Books from various automotive organizations that include information about the model and manufacturer of your car can be helpful in calculating the value of your car. You can use the retail values of your vehicle that appear in the books and modify them based on factors such as mileage and the condition of your vehicle to calculate the value of your car. The prices are unofficial, but they may be helpful in determining the value of the car and suggesting relative prices that can be used as a comparison with current sales and offers in your area. If your car is not listed in those books, determine the value based on other sources. The offer you receive from a dealer for your car as part of the payment for a new one is usually not an estimate of its actual value.

To calculate the amount of theft or casualty loss, you usually have to determine the decrease in the fair market value of the lost or damaged property by means of a competent appraisal or by using the cost of repairs you actually make. However, the special safe harbor methods in the Revenue Procedure 2018-08, found on page 286 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02, allow you to determine the decrease in the fair market value in other ways. Accidental losses of personal use property held by an individual are deductible only if they are attributable to a federally declared disaster. An exception to the rule limiting the deduction of accidental losses or theft of personal use property applies if you have casualty gains from personal use property. If so, you can deduct your casualty losses of personal use property not attributable to a federally declared disaster to the extent that they do not exceed your casualty gains from personal use property.

The Revenue Procedure 2018-08, found on page 286 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02, available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02IRB#RP-2018-08, provides safe harbor methods that you can use to determine the amount of your theft or casualty losses of your personal residential real property and personal belongings. If you qualify to use and indeed use the safe harbor methods described in Revenue Procedure 2018-08, the IRS will not dispute your determination. The use of the safe harbor methods described in Revenue Procedure 2018-08 is not mandatory.

The replacement cost safe harbor method for federally declared disasters allows you to determine the fair market value of your personal belongings located in a disaster area immediately prior to a federally declared disaster to calculate the amount of your casualty or theft loss. To use the replacement cost safe harbor method, you first need to determine the current cost of replacing your personal belonging with a new one, and then reduce that amount by 10% for each year that you owned the personal belonging. See the Personal Belongings Valuation Table in the Revenue Procedure 2018-08. If you choose to use the replacement cost safe harbor method, then you must use that method for all of your personal belongings, with certain exceptions identified in the Revenue Procedure 2018-08. Each of these safe harbor methods is subject to additional rules and exceptions. For more information, see the Revenue Procedure 2018-08.

Your loss determined through the safe harbor methods must be reduced by the value of any remedy provided by a third party at no cost (e.g., work done by volunteers or through donations) to you and reduced by the amount of any insurance, reimbursement or other compensation received.

Attach a written document to Form 4684 stating that you used the Revenue Procedure 2018-08 to determine the amount of your casualty loss. Include the specific safe harbor method you used. When completing Form 4684, do not enter an amount on line 5 or line 6 for each property. Instead, enter the decrease in fair market value determined under the safe harbor method on line 7. For losses caused by Hurricane Harvey, Hurricane Irma, and Hurricane Maria, see the Revenue Procedure 2018-09, found on page 290 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02, available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02IRB#RP-2018-09, for the safe harbor method of cost indexes.

Generally, a residential real estate for personal use is the real estate, including improvements, that is owned by the individual who suffered a casualty loss and in which there is at least one residence for personal use. This does not include a residence for personal use if any part of it is used as rental property or if it has an office used for a trade or business or any transaction in which it is engaged for profit. For more details, see Revenue Procedure 2018-08. Safe harbor methods for residential real estate for personal use available through Revenue Procedure 2018-08 are: Estimated repair cost method De minimis method Insurance method Federally declared disaster method—contractor safe harbor method Federally declared disaster method—disaster loan appraisal method

The estimated cost of repair safe harbor method allows you to calculate the decrease in the fair market value of your personal residential real estate using the lesser of two repair estimates prepared by separate, independent, licensed contractors. The estimates must list the detailed costs of restoring your property to its condition immediately prior to the casualty. The estimated cost of repair safe harbor method is limited to casualty losses of $20,000 or less.

The insurance safe harbor method allows you to calculate the decrease in the fair market value of your personal residential real estate based on the estimated loss in the reports prepared by your homeowners insurance company or flood insurance company, which must establish the estimated loss you suffered from the damage or destruction of your property.

If the loss occurred in a disaster area and was due to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, then you can use the Contractor Safe Harbor Method or the Disaster Loan Appraisal Method. Under the Contractor Safe Harbor Method, you can use the cost for repairs specified in a contract prepared by an independent, licensed contractor to determine the decrease in the fair market value of your personal residential real estate. This Safe Harbor Method does not apply unless it is subject to a binding contract, signed by you and the contractor, setting out the detailed costs of restoring your personal residential real estate to its condition immediately before the casualty.

Under the Safe Harbor method of disaster loan appraisal, you may use a federal loan appraisal (or federal loan guarantee) that identifies your estimated loss as a result of a federally declared disaster to determine the decrease in the fair market value of your personal residential real estate.

Personal property generally includes items of tangible personal property of an individual who suffered a loss by casualty or theft, if those belongings are not used in a trade or business. Personal property does not include items whose value is maintained or increased over time or other types of property. For more details, see Revenue Procedure 2018-08. Safe harbor methods for personal property are the de minimis method and the replacement cost method for disasters declared by the federal government.
The following points should generally not be taken into account when calculating the decrease in the fair market value of your property.

The cost of protecting your property against a catastrophic event or theft is not part of the catastrophic event or theft loss. The amount you spend to protect your home from storms, whether on insurance or by placing planks over windows, is not part of the loss. If the property is a commercial property, these expenses can be deducted as business expenses. If you make permanent improvements to your property to protect it from a catastrophic event or theft, add the cost of these improvements to the base of the property. An example would be the cost of a dike to prevent floods.

You cannot increase the base on property for expenses you have incurred in connection with qualifying disaster mitigation payments (explained below under Disaster Area Losses), or deduct such expenses as business expenses.

Unforeseen expenses incurred due to a casualty or theft, such as personal injury treatment costs, temporary housing costs, or car rental costs, are not part of your casualty or theft loss, but may be deductible as business expenses if the damaged or stolen property is commercial property.

If a family portrait, inherited items or souvenirs have been damaged, destroyed or stolen, you have to base your loss only on the fair market value of these property, as limited by its adjusted base in ownership.• If you have a family portrait, inherited items or souvenirs, you have to base your loss only on the fair market value of these property, as limited by its adjusted base in ownership.

The decrease in the value of a property because it is located in or near an area affected by a fortuitous event or in an area that is likely to be affected by a fortuitous event again cannot be taken into account. Your loss is only for actual damage to the property. However, if your home is located in an area declared a disaster area by the federal government, see the section entitled Losses in Disaster Areas below.

Photographs taken after the casualty occurred will help establish the condition and value of the property after the damage. Photographs showing the condition of the property after it has been repaired, restored or replaced may also be helpful. Appraisals are used to calculate the decrease in fair market value due to a casualty or theft. For information about appraisals, see Appraisals under the How to Calculate the Decrease in Fair Market Value – Points to Consider section above. The costs of photographs and appraisals used to prove the value and condition of property damaged by a casualty are not part of the loss. They are expenses that will help you determine your tax liability. For the 2018 to 2025 tax years, these expenses are no longer deductible as miscellaneous itemized deductions.

The extent of investment you have in the property you own is the base. For the property you buy, the base is usually what it costs you. If you acquire property in some other way, for example, as an inheritance, gift, or non-taxable exchange, you have to calculate the base differently, as explained in Publication 551.

If you inherited property from someone who died in 2010 and the estate executor elected to make an election under section 1022 using Form 8939, Allocation of Increase in Basis for Property Acquired From a Decedent, special rules regarding the basis will apply to you. The estate executor of a deceased who died in 2010 may elect to apply a modified transferred basis treatment to the deceased’s acquired property. For more detailed information about the election under section 1022, see Notice 2011-66 on page 184 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2011-35 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2011-35IRB#NOT-2011-66). For information on optional safe harbor guidelines under section 1022, see Revenue Procedure 2011-41 on page 188 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2011-35 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2011-35IRB#RP-2011-41).

During the time you own your property, several events may occur that change the base. Some of these increase the base, such as extensions or permanent improvements to the property. Others, such as casualty losses and previous depreciation deductions, decrease the base. When you add the increases to the base and subtract the decreases from the base, the result is the adjusted base. ť For more information about how to calculate the base of your property, see Publication 551.

After calculating the amount of your casualty loss or theft, you need to calculate what percentage of the loss you can deduct. The casualty loss and theft deduction for personal use property is limited. For tax years 2018 through 2025, casualty losses of personal use property sustained by an individual are deductible only to the extent that they are attributable to a federally declared disaster. Accidental losses or theft of personal use property attributable to a federally declared disaster are limited under the $100 per casualty rule and the 10% rule explained below. The $100 and 10% rules are also summarized in Table 2. An exception to the rule (explained above), which limits the deduction of casualty losses or theft of personal use property to losses caused by a federally declared disaster, applies if you have casualty gains in the tax year. If so, you can reduce your casualty gains for any casualty losses not attributable to a federally declared disaster. The excess of such gains, if any, is used to reduce the losses attributable to a federally declared disaster. The 10% rule of your adjusted gross income applies to the remainder of the losses attributable to a federally declared disaster. Commercial and income-generating property losses are not subject to these rules. However, if the casualty loss or theft included a home you used for business purposes or rented to another person, your deductible loss may be limited. See the instructions for Section B in the Instructions for Form 4684. If the casualty loss or theft included property used in a commercial activity, your deductible loss may be limited.

Once you have calculated the loss of personal use property from a casualty or theft, as explained above, you must subtract $100 from that loss. This reduction applies to each total casualty or theft loss, including those losses that are not attributable to a federally declared disaster that you use to reduce your casualty gains of personal use property. It does not matter how many property items were affected by the event. Only a single reduction of $100 will apply.

In general, events that are closely related in origin cause a single casualty. A casualty is considered to be a single casualty when damage is caused by two or more directly related causes, such as wind damage and flood damage caused by the same storm. A single casualty can also cause damage to two or more properties, such as a tornado that causes damage to your home and the car parked at your entrance.

If two or more people (other than spouses filing jointly) suffer a loss of property on joint property, the $100 rule applies separately to each person. For example, if two sisters live in a house they bought together and have a casualty loss on the house, each sister must apply the $100 rule separately. l

You must subtract 10% of your adjusted gross income from your total federal casualty losses. Apply this rule after you have deducted $100 of each loss. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 4684. If you have casualty or theft losses and gains, see the section entitled Gains and losses below.

If the losses are greater than the recognized gains, subtract the gains from the losses and subtract from the result 10% of your adjusted gross income. The remainder, if any, will be the deductible loss of personal property. If you have losses not attributable to a federally declared disaster, see Line 14 in the Instructions for Form 4684, as they can only be used to reduce the profits. If you have qualifying disaster losses, see Line 15 in the Instructions for Form 4684 for more information.

If the recognized gains are greater than the losses, subtract the losses from the gains. The difference is considered a capital gain and must be reported on Schedule D (Form 1040). The 10% rule does not apply to gains. If you have losses not attributable to a federally declared disaster, see Line 14 in the Instructions for Form 4684.
To calculate a loss of real property you own for personal use, all improvements (such as buildings, ornamental trees, and the land with improved areas) are considered together.

If your personal property has been stolen or damaged or destroyed due to a casualty, you have to calculate your loss separately for each item you own. Then add these amounts to get the total loss. Subtract from the total loss $100 and 10% of your adjusted gross income to determine the deduction for your loss.

When a casualty includes real and personal property, you must calculate the loss separately for each type of property. However, a one-time reduction of $100 is applied to the total loss, and the 10% rule is then applied to calculate the casualty loss deduction. t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t t

When the property is used in part for personal purposes and in part for business or income-generating purposes, the casualty or theft deduction for the personal use part and the business or income-generating part must be calculated separately. Both must be calculated separately, since losses attributed to these two uses are calculated differently. When calculating each loss, allocate between the commercial and personal use of the property the total cost or base, the fair market value before and after the casualty or theft, and the amount covered by insurance or other reimbursements. The $100 and 10% rules apply only to the casualty or theft loss of the personal use part of the property.
Even if the decrease in the fair market value of your property is less than the adjusted basis of your property, use your adjusted basis to calculate your gain.

The amount you receive includes any amount of money plus the value of any property you receive, minus any expenses you incur in obtaining such reimbursement, and any reimbursement used to pay the full balance of a mortgage or lien on the damaged, destroyed or stolen property.

If you make a gain because your main home was destroyed, you can usually exclude the gain from your income as if you had sold or exchanged it. You could exclude up to $250,000 of the gain (up to $500,000 if you are married filing jointly). To exclude a gain, you usually have to have owned and lived in the home as your main home for at least 2 years within the 5-year period ending on the date it was destroyed. See Publication 523 for more information about this exclusion. If your gain is greater than the amount you can exclude, but you purchase replacement property, you may defer filing for such excess gains. See the section entitled Deferring the Return of a Gain below.

You usually have to report the gain as income in the year you receive the refund. However, you do not have to report your gain if you meet certain requirements and choose to defer the reporting of your gain according to the rules explained below in the Deferring the Reporting of a Gain section. For more information on reporting a gain, see the section entitled How to Report Losses and Gains below. If you have a casualty gain or theft on personal property and have chosen to defer the reporting of that gain (as explained below) and also have another casualty loss or theft of personal property, do not take the gains you are deferring into account when calculating the casualty loss or theft deduction. See the 10% Rule in the Limits of Deduction section above.

Do not report a gain if you receive as a refund property similar to or related to the destroyed or stolen property in terms of the service or use it provides. The basis on the new property is usually equal to the adjusted basis of the property you replace. You usually have to report the gain on the stolen or destroyed property if you receive money or other property as a refund. However, you can choose to defer the return of such gain if you purchase property similar to or related to the stolen or destroyed property in terms of the service or use it provides, within a certain replacement period described below. You can also defer the return of such gain if you purchase a majority interest (at least 80%) in a corporation that owns property similar to or related to the property in terms of the service or use it provides. See the section entitled Majority Interest in a Corporation below. If you have a gain on damaged property, you can defer the return of the gain if you spend the gain on restoring the property. To defer the return of the total gain, the cost of the replacement property must be at least equal to the refund you receive. Also, if the cost of the replacement property is less than the amount of the refund, you must include the gain in your income up to the amount equivalent to the unexpended refund.

In the case of casualties and thefts described in condition (3) above, gains may not be offset against losses in determining whether the total gain exceeds $100,000. If you are an investor-owner, the phrase “similar or related in service or use it provides” means that, to you, the replacement property must have a similar relationship in terms of the services or uses it provides in relation to the property you are replacing. You can determine this by answering the following questions: whether the property provides you with a similar service. the nature of the business risks with respect to the property. what the property requires of you in terms of management, service and relationship with tenants.

If the destroyed business or income-generating property was located in a federally declared disaster area, any tangible replacement property you acquire for use in a business is treated as similar or related in terms of the services or use it provides in relation to the destroyed property. The replacement property does not have to be in a federally declared disaster area. For more information, see the section entitled Losses in Disaster Areas below.

You may replace your assets by acquiring a majority interest in a corporation that owns similar or related assets in terms of service and use they provide in relation to your own damaged, destroyed or stolen assets. you may defer the declaration of total gain if the cost of the shares that give you a majority interest is at least equal to the amount received (redeemed) for your ownership. you own a majority interest if you own shares that have at least 80% of the combination of all votes for all classes of voting shares and at least 80% of the total number of any other kinds of shares.

You must attach a written document to your tax return for the year in which you made the gain that includes the following information: the date and details of the casualty or theft; any insurance or other reimbursements you received for the casualty or theft; how you calculated the gain; and the date and details of the accident.

If you acquired replacement property before filing your return for the year in which you made the gain, the written document must also include detailed information about the following: The replacement property. The deferred gain. The adjusted basis that reflects the deferred gain. Any gain you report as income.

Once you have acquired the qualifying replacement property that you have designated as such in a written document attached to your tax return, you cannot subsequently replace it with other qualifying property, even if you acquire the other property within the applicable replacement period. However, if you discover that the original replacement property was not qualifying property, you may (within the applicable replacement period) replace it with the new qualifying replacement property.

You must file an amended return (individuals can use Form 1040-X) for the gain tax year in any of the following situations: If you do not acquire replacement property within the required replacement period, including any extensions. On this amended return, you must report the gain and pay any additional tax that applies. If you acquire replacement property within the required replacement period, including any extensions, but at a lower cost than the amount you receive for the casualty or theft, on this amended return, you must report the portion of the gain that you cannot defer and pay any additional tax that applies.

The period for determining the tax on all gains ends 3 years after the date you notify the IRS director for your area of any of the following: you replaced the property you did not intend to replace the property you did not replace the property within the period for replacement you did not return the property to the IRS or did not return the property to the IRS.

Your legal liability may be determined when a recovery claim is settled, awarded, or dropped.

If you sell or transfer property, you must generally recognise any gain or loss for tax purposes, unless the property is your primary residence. You report the gain or deduct the loss on your tax return for the year in which you make the gain or loss. (You cannot deduct a loss on personal use property unless the loss was the result of a fortuitous event, as explained above.) However, if you sell or otherwise transfer property to the federal government, a state or local government, or an indigenous tribal government under a hazard mitigation program, you may defer the return of the gain if you purchase qualified replacement property within a certain period. The IRS may defer certain tax deadlines up to one (1) year for taxpayers affected by a federally declared disaster. Tax deadlines that the IRS may defer include those for filing income tax, use and consumption tax, and payroll tax returns; and it may also defer the deadlines for paying income tax, use and consumption tax, and payroll tax, and those for making contributions to a traditional IRA or Roth IRA. If the tax deadline is postponed, the IRS will announce this postponement in your area through a press release and, as necessary, through tax administrative rulings, tax administrative proceedings, notices, announcements, and other communications in the Internal Revenue Bulletin that may provide guidance.

If the IRS defers a tax period, the following taxpayers are eligible for this deferral: Any individual whose principal residence is located in a covered disaster area (as defined below). Any commercial entity or sole proprietor of a business whose principal place of business is located in a covered disaster area. Any individual who works in humanitarian aid and is affiliated with a recognized government or philanthropic organization and provides assistance in a covered disaster area. Any individual, commercial entity or sole proprietor of a business whose records are required to meet an already deferred tax period, provided that that documentation is maintained in a covered disaster area. The principal residence or principal place of business does not need to be located in a covered disaster area. Any estate or trust that has tax records required to meet an already deferred tax period, provided that that documentation is maintained in a covered disaster area. A spouse filing jointly with a taxpayer who is eligible for a deferral. Any individual, commercial entity or sole proprietor of a business not located in a covered disaster area but whose records are required to meet an already deferred tax period, are maintained in that covered disaster area. Any individual who has visited the covered disaster area and has died or suffered injury as a result of the disaster. Any other person who is determined by the IRS to have been affected by a federally declared disaster.

Certain taxpayers affected by federally declared disasters that occur after December 20, 2019 may be eligible for a mandatory 60-day deferral for certain tax deadlines such as filing and paying income, consumer and payroll taxes, and making contributions to a traditional IRA or Roth IRA. The period beginning on the earlier incident date specified in the disaster declaration and ending on the date that is 60 days after the earlier incident date or the date of the disaster declaration, whichever is later, is the period for which tax deadlines are deferred. For information on disaster assistance available in your area, including deferral, visit Around the Nation.
The IRS may reduce interest and fines on income taxes that have not been paid in full for the duration of any tax deferral.

Generally, you must deduct a casualty loss in the year of the disaster. However, if you have a casualty loss from a federally declared disaster that occurred in a public or individual aid-eligible area (or both), you can elect to deduct that loss on the return or amended return for the tax year immediately preceding the year of the disaster. If you make this election, the loss is treated as if it had occurred in the previous year. A list of public or individual aid-eligible areas (or both) can be found on the FEMA website at FEMA.gov/Disaster. You must make the election to report the casualty loss from the disaster in the previous year no later than six (6) months after the regular due date to file your original tax return (excluding extensions) for the year of the disaster. If you are a taxpayer who follows the calendar year to file your tax returns, you have until October 15, 2025 to amend your 2023 tax return to claim a casualty loss that occurred in the year of the disaster.

If you have already filed your tax return for the previous year, you can elect to claim a disaster loss against that year’s income by filing an amended return. Amended individual tax returns are filed on Form 1040-X. (See How to Report the Loss on Form 1040-X, below.) To make this election, complete Part I of Section D on Form 4684 for 2023 and attach it to your 2023 return or amended return on which you claim the disaster loss deduction. You must make the election to report the loss in the previous year no later than the date that is six (6) months after the regular due date to file your original tax return (excluding extensions) for the year of the disaster. If you are a taxpayer who follows the calendar year to file your tax returns, the due date to elect to take the 2024 disaster loss on your 2023 tax return and you wish to deduct the loss in the previous year, you must first file an amended return to remove the previously deducted loss. This amended return must be filed no later than the date you file your previous year’s return or amended return on which you include the disaster loss deduction. Reporting a qualifying disaster loss on the previous year’s tax return can result in a lower tax for that year, often resulting in or increasing a cash refund.

Complete Part II of Section D on Form 4684 for 2023 if you want to revoke the election of the year of the disaster to deduct the loss for a disaster that was declared as such by the federal government that you held in 2024 in the previous year. Attach the completed Section D to your amended return for the previous tax year (i.e., to an amended return for 2023 for the revocation of an election of the year of the disaster to deduct the loss for the disaster that you held in 2024). You must file your amended return for the revocation of the election on or before the date that is 90 days after the due date to make the election and no later than the date you file your return or amended return for the year in which you include the deduction for the disaster loss. On your amended return (revoking the election of the year of the disaster that you previously chose) you must recalculate your tax liability due as a result of the revocation of the election. You must pay or arrange to pay any taxes or interest due as a result of the revocation.

Qualified disaster losses of an individual include casualty losses or theft of personal property that are attributable to: A major (major) disaster declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act in 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; California wildfires in 2017 and January 2018; A major disaster declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act for a disaster that occurred in 2018 or during 2019 but before December 21, 2019, and that did not continue after January 19, 2020 (except for those losses attributable to California wildfires in January 2018 (which have already received tax relief)); A major disaster declared by the President during the period between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025; and a period of incident that began on or after December 28, 2019 and on or before December 12, 2024 and did not end after January 11, 2025.

The adjustment to the alternative minimum tax (AMT) by the standard deduction has been made retroactively inapplicable to qualified net disaster losses. To claim the EIC, you (and your spouse if you file a joint return) must have a valid SSN issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) for the due date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions). Your qualifying child must have a valid SSN issued for the due date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions) in order for you to claim a higher EIC amount based on that child. If you have at least one qualifying child who qualifies to be a qualifying child for purposes of claiming the EIC, but that child does not have a valid SSN issued for the due date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions), you may qualify to claim an EIC only for yourself if you otherwise qualify to claim it. For more information on how to complete the EIC Schedule (Form 1040) if your qualifying child or children do not have a valid SSN issued after the due date of your 2024 return (including extensions) or was issued solely to apply for or receive a federally funded benefit and you do not authorize them to work. An example of a federally funded benefit is Medicaid. If you, your spouse or child has a Social Security card with the phrase “Not Valid for Employment” printed on the card and your immigration status, your spouse or child has changed, so that the person is now a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, ask the SSA for a new Social Security card without that enrollment.

Tax-related identity theft occurs when someone steals your personal information to commit tax fraud. Your taxes may be affected if your Social Security Number (SSN) is used to file a fraudulent tax return or to claim a refund or credit. ה IRS does not initiate communications with taxpayers through email, text messages (including shortened links), phone calls or social media to ask for or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, banks or other financial accounts. 访 IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS's Identity Theft Information Center online, for information on identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If you have lost or stolen your SSN or suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what steps to take. Get a Personal Identity Protection Number (PIPN). PIPNs are six-digit numbers assigned to taxpayers to help prevent the misuse of your SSN in fraudulent tax returns. When you have an IPPIN, it prevents someone else from filing a tax return with your SSN.

Practitioner Priority Service® (PPS). The Practitioner Priority Service® (PPS) is a toll-free national hotline that provides support for practitioners with accounting-related questions. The toll-free telephone number for this service is 866-860-4259. Annual Tax Season Program and federal tax return preparer directory. The Annual Tax Season Program (AFSP) is a voluntary program under which limited practice rights are granted to tax return preparers who are not lawyers, chartered accountants, or registered agents. The IRS issues an Annual Tax Season Program compliance record for tax return preparers who obtain a certain amount of continuous education hours for the purpose of preparing for a particular tax year. Annual Tax Season Program participants do not have unlimited practice rights (unless they are also lawyers, chartered accountants, or registered agents). Their rights are limited to representing clients whose returns they have prepared and signed, but only before tax inspectors, customer service representatives, and IRS employees, including the Taxpayer Ombudsman Service. They may not represent clients whose returns they have not prepared or signed, or may not represent them previously to collection or appeal functions. The Internal Revenue Commissioner, or delegate, may authorize a person who is otherwise ineligible to practice with the IRS to represent another person in a particular matter. The prospective representative must apply for this authorization in writing to the Office of Professional Responsibility. However, it is granted only when there are extremely compelling circumstances. If granted, the Commissioner, or delegate, will issue a letter detailing the conditions relating to the appearance and the particular tax matters for which the authorization is granted. The authorization letter should not be confused with a letter from an IRS center informing a person that he or she has been assigned a number in the Centralized Authorization File (CAF). The issuance of a CAF number does not indicate that a person is recognized or authorized to practice with the IRS. It merely confirms that a centralized authorization file has been established for the person with that number.

An unregistered return preparer is a person who is not an attorney, CPA, registered agent, registered retirement plan agent, or registered actuary and who prepares and signs a taxpayer’s return as a paid preparer, or prepares a return but is not required (by return instructions or regulations) to sign it. Unregistered return preparers may represent taxpayers only before tax inspectors, customer service representatives, or similar IRS officials and employees (including the Taxpayer Ombudsman Service) and only during a review of tax returns that they prepared and signed prior to December 31, 2015. These preparers may not represent taxpayers before appeals officers, tax collection officers, advisors, or similar officials, or employees of the IRS or the Treasury Department. Furthermore, they may not enter into closing agreements, extend the statutory period for tax determinations or collection, sign voluntary waivers, or sign any document on behalf of a taxpayer. If such a preparer does not meet the requirements for limited representation, you may authorize him to inspect or request your tax information by filing Form 8821, Tax Information Authorization. Completing this form does not authorize the preparer to represent you before the IRS. For more information, see Form 8821 and its separate instructions. Annual Tax Season Program Compliance Record. Only unregistered return preparers who have a valid PTIN and have a compliance record for both the tax return year (2015 or later) subject to review and the year that the review is conducted may exercise representation under the following conditions: Unregistered return preparers who are not registered as a paid preparer or prepare a return but are not required (by return instructions or regulations) to sign it.

Generally, people lose their eligibility to practice with the IRS in the following ways: They fail to meet the requirements for renewal of registration (such as continuing professional education) They apply as registered agents to be listed in inactive retirement status They are suspended or disqualified by the Office of Professional Responsibility or determined to be ineligible to practice for violation of regulations made under Circular 230 or the rules of Tax Administrative Procedure 81-38 They lose their state license to practice as a lawyer or a registered accountant, regardless of the basis for the revocation.

The IRS will notify registered individuals and Annual Tax Season Program (AFSP) compliance record holders who do not meet the eligibility requirements for renewal. The notice will explain the reason for ineligibility and provide the individual with a strictly time-bound opportunity to provide information for reconsideration. The IRS will notify the individual of the renewal of the eligibility for renewal.

The registered person must submit a renewal request within 3 years and meet all renewal requirements after becoming inactive, otherwise at the end of the next renewal cyclet the registered person will be removed from the list and the status of the registration will be cancelled.

Registered persons who apply to be listed as inactive retirees will not be eligible to practice with the IRS. They must continue to meet all renewal requirements. They can be re-established in active enrollment status by filing an application for renewal and showing evidence that they have completed the hours of continuing professional education required for the enrollment cycle.

All persons who practice with the IRS are subject to disciplinary proceedings and are liable to censure, suspension, disqualification, or financial penalty for violating any of the regulations set out in Circular 230. This includes engaging in acts that demonstrate incompetence or bad conduct. For more information, see Incompetence and Bad Conduct under What are the Rules for Practice? below. Professionals who are suspended or disqualified under disciplinary proceedings may not represent taxpayers with the IRS during the period of suspension or disqualification. A professional may apply for reinstatement with the Office of Professional Responsibility on a specified period of suspension or after five years of disqualification, whichever is earlier. See What is Practice with the IRS? above. If the practitioner requests reinstatement, he or she may not practice with the IRS until the Office of Professional Responsibility grants reinstatement. The Office of Professional Responsibility may reinstate the practitioner: if, by his or her future conduct, he or she is not likely to violate the regulations. if granting reinstatement is not contrary to the public interest. subject to other conditions for a reasonable period.

The rules governing practice with the IRS are published in Part 10, Subtitle A, Section 31, of the Code of Federal Regulations and are published online as the Department of the Treasury’s Circular 230. The regulations are available at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals. A lawyer, CPA, registered agent, retirement plan registered agent or registered actuary authorized to practice with the IRS (referred to herein as the “practitioner”) and an appraiser have a duty to perform certain acts and are restricted from performing other acts. The “practitioner” may not be involved in bad-reputation conduct (which is specified below). Practitioners who fail to comply with the practice rules or who are involved in incompetent or bad-reputation conduct are subject to disciplinary action. In addition, unregistered return preparers must comply with the practice and conduct rules for the purposes of having the privilege of limited practice with the IRS. There are two specific sets of rules that apply, both set out in accordance with Circular 230: 1. Duties and restrictions for practice (Subpart B of Circular 230). 2. Conduct deemed to be a source of incompetence or bad-reputation (Subpart C of Circular 230).

Persons subject to Circular 230 must promptly disclose records or information upon the appropriate and lawful request of IRS officials or employees, except when the practitioner has reasonable grounds to believe in good faith that the information is privileged. Communication on tax advice between the federally authorized tax practitioner (see Internal Revenue Code section 7525) and a taxpayer is generally confidential to the same extent as it would be privileged between a taxpayer and a lawyer if the advice relates to: a tax matter of a non-criminal nature before the IRS; or a tax proceeding of a non-criminal nature brought by or against the United States in a federal court.

This protection for tax advice communications does not apply to written communications between a federally authorized tax practitioner and any other person, including a director, shareholder, officer, employee, agent or representative of a corporation if the communication involves the promotion of direct or indirect participation of such corporation in any tax haven.

A person under Circular 230 who becomes aware that his or her client has failed to comply with the income laws or has made an error or omission in any required return, document, affidavit or other document, is responsible to inform the client immediately of the failure, error or omission, and the consequences thereof.

Persons subject to Circular 230 must exercise due diligence when performing the following tasks: prepare or assist in the preparation, approval and filing of returns, documents, affidavits and other documents relating to IRS matters; determine the accuracy of oral or written representations made by such person to the Department of Treasury; determine the accuracy of oral or written representations made by such person to clients with respect to any matter administered through the IRS.

The presumption of due diligence applies in situations where the product of another person's work has been relied upon if, in a reasonably careful manner, the person was engaged, supervised, trained and evaluated, taking into account the nature of the relationship between the person under Circular 230 and the person.

Persons subject to Circular 230 may not endorse or otherwise negotiate any cheque (including directing or accepting payment by any means, electronic or otherwise, to an account owned or controlled by the practitioner, or a company or other entity with which the practitioner is associated) issued by the government to a client in respect of a federal tax obligation.

Persons complying with Circular 230 may be disqualified or suspended from practice with the IRS, or censured, for incompetence or bad-reputation conduct. A monetary fine may be imposed, in addition to any other discipline, on both individuals and their companies. The following list illustrates examples of conduct that is considered bad-reputation. Further examples are provided in section 10.51(a) of Circular 230. Being convicted of any offence under the internal tax laws or any offence involving dishonesty or breach of trust. Knowingly giving false or misleading information relating to federal tax matters or engaging in such activity. Seeking employment by prohibited means, as stipulated in section 10.30 of Circular 230. Intentionally failing to file a federal tax return, evading or attempting to evade any federal tax or payment, or engaging in such actions. Misappropriating, or failing to remit properly and on time, funds received from clients for a tax payment or other obligation due to the United States. Attempting directly or indirectly to influence the official action of IRS employees by the District of Columbia or any state, possession, territory, commonwealth or any federal court, or any federal agency, body or board. Knowingly assisting and inciting another person to practice with the IRS during a period of suspension, disqualification or ineligibility of that other person. Using offensive language, making false accusations or statements knowing they are false, circulating or publishing matters that are not true, or making false statements or accusations knowing they are false.

A qualified representative may substitute or delegate power of attorney to another qualified representative only if you specifically authorize such an act in the power of attorney. After a substitution has been made, only the newly recognized representative will be recognized as the taxpayer's representative. If a delegation of power of attorney has been made, the IRS will recognize both the original representative and the delegate to represent the taxpayer.

Your representative cannot enter into consents that allow the IRS to disclose the return or return information to a third party unless you specifically delegate this authority to your representative on Form 2848, line 5a.

A power of attorney generally terminates if you become incapacitated or incompetent. However, the power of attorney may continue in the event of your incapacity or incompetence if you authorize it on Form 2848(SP), line 5a, "Other Authorized Acts," and if your non-IRS permanent power of attorney meets all the requirements for acceptance by the IRS. See Non-IRS Powers of Attorney below.

Present a power of attorney when you want to authorize a person to receive your confidential tax information and to represent you with the IRS, whether or not the representative performs any of the other acts listed above in What is a Power of Attorney?. Most of the time, a power of attorney is required when you want to authorize another person to perform at least one of the following acts on your behalf: 1. Represent you at a meeting with the IRS. 2. Prepare and submit a written response to an IRS inquiry. 3.

Use Form 2848 to designate a qualified representative to act on your behalf with the IRS. The persons qualified to represent you with the IRS are listed in Part II. Representative's Statement of Form 2848. Your representative must complete this part of the form.

The IRS will not accept your non-IRS power of attorney if it does not contain all of the information listed above. You can sign and submit a completed Form 2848(SP) or a new non-IRS power of attorney that contains all of this information. If you cannot sign an acceptable replacement document, your proxy may perfect (make acceptable to the IRS) your non-IRS power of attorney by following the procedures described below.
The following tips are summaries of some of the line-by-line instructions for Form 2848(SP).

You can usually mail or fax a paper Form 2848(SP) directly to the IRS. To determine where to file Form 2848(SP), see the Where to File Form section in the Instructions for Form 2848(SP). If this form is for a specific use, mail or fax it to the office that is handling the matter. For more information about specific uses, see Line 4. Specific Use Not Registered in the (CAF) in the Instructions for Form 2848(SP).

If you choose to file a power of attorney by fax, make sure that the IRS office is equipped to accept this type of transmission. Your representative can file Form 2848(SP) electronically through the IRS website. For more information, your representative can visit IRS.gov/eServices. If you complete Form 2848(SP) for an electronic signature authorization, do not file it with the IRS. Instead, give it to your representative for storage.

Send any update or amendment to an existing power of attorney in writing. You are required to sign (or to sign for the persons authorized to sign on your behalf). To do so, send the updated Form 2848(SP) or non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS offices where you previously filed the originals, including the service center where the related return was filed or is to be filed. A qualified representative may substitute or delegate power of attorney if you specifically authorize him to substitute or delegate power of attorney in the original power of attorney. For the purpose of making a substitution or delegation, the representative must file the following documents at the IRS offices where the power of attorney was filed: 1. A written notice of substitution or delegation signed by the qualified representative. 2. A written statement by the representative made by the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney specifically authorizing the substitution or delegation.

A power of attorney that has been filed earlier under a new power of attorney relating to the same matter will be revoked, but the previous power of attorney will not be revoked under a new power of attorney if the new power of attorney specifically states that the previous power of attorney will not be revoked and if any of the following documents are attached to the new power of attorney: a copy of the previous power of attorney that is not revoked; or a written statement signed by the taxpayer specifying the name and address of each authorized representative under the previous power of attorney.

If you want to revoke a power of attorney that is in effect and do not want to appoint a new representative, you must write "REVOKE" at the top of the first page of Form 2848 with your current signature and date immediately below this entry. then you must mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the entry about the revocation to the IRS as indicated in the Where to File Form table in the Instructions for Form 2848 or, if the power of attorney is for a specific matter, to the IRS office that handles the matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney that you want to revoke, you must send the IRS a statement of revocation stating that the power of attorney was revoked, stating the matters and years or periods and stating the name and address of each qualified representative whose power of attorney is revoked. you must sign and date this statement. if you want to revoke the power of attorney completely, you must write "Remove all years/periods" instead of specifying the specific matters and years or periods.

If your representative wishes to withdraw from the representation, the representative must write "WITHDRAW" at the top of the first page of Form 2848(SP) with the current signature and date immediately below the entry. Then the representative must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the entry on withdrawal to the IRS as described in the section Revocation of the Taxpayer above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney that he or she wishes to withdraw, the representative must send the IRS a written statement indicating the withdrawal stating that the power of attorney is withdrawn, the subject matter and years or periods and the taxpayer's name, taxpayer identification number (TIN) and address (if known). The representative must sign and date the written statement. A student's power of attorney will be registered in the CAF system for 130 days from the date of receipt. If you authorize a student to represent you after that period, you must submit another updated Form 2848(SP).

A power of attorney will be recognized after the IRS receives and reviews it and determines that it contains the required information. However, until a power of attorney is entered into the CAF system, IRS staff may not be aware of the authority of the person you have appointed to represent you. Therefore, during this interim period, IRS staff may request that you or your representative bring a copy to any meeting with the IRS.
The way the power of attorney is processed or managed depends on whether it is a complete or incomplete document.

If Form 2848 is incomplete, the IRS will attempt to obtain the missing information by contacting you or your representative in writing or by phone. For example, if your signature or date of signature is missing, the IRS will contact you. If information about your representative is missing and there is sufficient information on the document for communication (such as an address or telephone number), the IRS will attempt to contact your representative. In any case, the power of attorney is not considered valid until all the required information is entered on the document. The person(s) appointed as your representative(s) for exercising your rights with the IRS will not be recognized until the document is complete and accepted by the IRS.

If the power of attorney is complete and valid, the IRS will take steps to recognize the representative. In most cases, this includes processing the document in the CAF system. The recording of the data in the CAF system allows the IRS to send copies of correspondence to the authorized representatives and to easily recognize the scope of the power of attorney granted.

After a valid power of attorney is presented, the IRS will recognize your representative. However, if the representative appears to be responsible for unduly delaying or impeding the prompt resolution of an IRS matter by failing to provide non-privileged information after repeated requests, the IRS may contact you directly. For example, in most cases where a power of attorney is recognized, the IRS will contact the representative to schedule appointments and provide lists of required documents. However, if the representative is unavailable, does not respond to repeated requests and does not provide the required documents (other than those considered privileged), the IRS may ignore your representative and contact you directly. If a representative engages in the conduct described above, the matter may be referred to the Office of Professional Responsibility for disciplinary action.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to ensure that your electronic payments are secure and reliable. You can make electronic payments online, by phone and via a mobile device using the IRS2Go application. Making payments electronically is quick, easy and processed much faster than sending a check or money order by mail. Go to IRS.gov/Payments to make a payment using any of the following options: IRS Direct Pay: Individuals can pay their tax bills or make estimated tax payments directly from their checking or savings accounts. Use of IRS Direct Pay is free; you will not have to pay any fees for using it. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved processor to pay online, by phone and via mobile device. Electronic withdrawal of funds: Offered only when filing your federal tax return using tax preparation software or through a professional tax preparation service. Federal Tax Electronic Payment System: The best option for businesses. Requires registration. Check or money order: Send your payment to the address indicated in the notice or letter sent to you or in the instructions on the tax form you filed. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at a participating business.
If you have not received your amended return, it may take up to three weeks from the date you filed your amended return to be registered in our system and up to 16 weeks to be processed.
Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TACs) provide interpreter service over the phone in more than 170 languages, and this service is free of charge for taxpayers.

Log in to IRS.gov/Account and click on English to securely view information about your federal tax account. See the amount you owe, pay online or request a payment agreement online. Access your tax files online. Review your payment history for the past 24 months. Log in to IRS.gov/SecureAccess and click on English to find out about the requirements of the identity verification process.

The fastest way to receive a tax refund is to combine e-filing with a direct deposit of your refund. When using direct deposit, your refund is securely transferred electronically directly to your bank account. Eight out of 10 taxpayers use direct deposit to receive their refunds. The IRS issues most refunds in less than 21 days.

Due to changes in legislation, the IRS cannot issue refunds earlier than mid-February of the year for returns where the earned income credit (EIC) or additional child tax credit (ACTC) was properly claimed. This delay applies to the refund in its entirety, not just the portion associated with these credits.

The fastest way to get a transcript of your tax return is to go to IRS.gov/Transcripts and click on English. Then click on Get a Transcript Online or Get a Transcript by Mail to order a copy of your transcript. If you prefer, you can: Order your transcript by calling 800-908-9946. Submit Form 4506-T or Form 4506T-EZ (both available at IRS.gov).

Access IRS.gov/Tools to use the following options: The Earned Income Credit Assistant (access IRS.gov/EITC Assistant) can help you determine if you are eligible to claim the earned income credit. The Online Application for an Employer Identification Number (access IRS.gov/EIN) helps you apply for an employer identification number (access IRS.gov/EIN). The Tax Withholding Estimator (access IRS.gov/W4AppES) estimates the amount that will be withheld from your paychecks for federal income tax purposes. The First-Time Homebuyer Credit Account Look-up provides information about your repayments and account balance. (access IRS.gov/Homebuyer). The Sales Tax Deduction Calculator (access IRS.gov/SalesTax) calculates the amount you can claim if you list deductions on Schedule A (Form 1040 or 1040-SR) and you did not keep receipts showing how much sales tax you paid.
